Authors: Blackert D., Cibrik J., Foster D.
Title: Aerobic soy-based cometabolism of halogenated hydrocarbons in groundwater
Source title: Battelle Press - 9th International In Situ and On-Site Bioremediation Symposium 2007
Affiliations: Key Environmental, Inc., Carnegie, PA, United States; Dow Chemical Company, South Charleston, WV, United States
Authors with affiliations: Blackert, D., Key Environmental, Inc., Carnegie, PA, United States; Cibrik, J., Dow Chemical Company, South Charleston, WV, United States; Foster, D., Key Environmental, Inc., Carnegie, PA, United States
Abstract: An aerobic cometabolism technique has been identified, developed, tested, and applied at ten sites within the United States between 2000 and 2007. This paper briefly describes the development, field technique, strengths, and limitations of the technology and presents a summary of the remediation results for each of the pilot- and full- scale applications. The technology was conceptually identified at a Union Carbide Corporation (UCC) facility in West Virginia during 2000 and has since been applied in bench-, field pilot-, and full-scale applications at ten different sites in four states. The technology involves the subsurface injection of a refined soy methyl ester, which serves as a fatty acid electron donor supporting microbial oxygenase enzyme production. The process is performed in conjunction with air sparging to distribute the methyl ester and maintain oxidizing conditions in the remediation area. The highly biodegradable substrate in the presence of oxidizing conditions and indigenous microorganisms supports the aerobic microbial generation of enzymes which have been demonstrated to rapidly oxidize halogenated hydrocarbon molecules. Bench-scale testing was performed to refine the physical and mechanical aspects of the technique and to evaluate various products and mixtures for use as a cometabolite. A commercially available soy oil mixture was developed and used in a multi-step process that combines liquid/liquid extraction and cometabolic processes to achieve rapid and highly cost effective reduction in aquifer contaminant concentrations. Target compounds have included several common halogenated hydrocarbons such as trichloroethene, di- chloroethene, tetrachloroethene, carbon tetrachloride, and chloroform, as well as several less common hydrocarbons and fluorocarbons. In nine of the ten applications, the technology resulted in rapid, cost-effective reduction in overall halogenated groundwater constituents of concern (COC). Halogenated hydrocarbon reductions of greater than 99 percent have been achieved in individual wells and up to 98 percent reductions in average site-wide concentrations have been achieved in as little as four months. In the single unsuccessful application, high pH (>11) is believed to have precluded the establishment of adequate microorganism populations to support the cometabolic process. The process described within this paper combines several proven technologies, including air sparging, liquid/liquid extraction, and biological cometabolism. Application of the technique during the past five years at several in situ field-pilot-test and full-scale remediation sites has resulted in rapid and dramatic decreases in groundwater COC concentrations.
Index Keywords: Air; Applications; Aquifers; Biodegradation; Bioremediation; Biotechnology; Carbides; Carbon tetrachloride; Cost effectiveness; Drying oils; Enzymes; Esterification; Esters; Fatty acids; Groundwater; Groundwater pollution; Groundwater resources; Halogenation; Hydrocarbon refining; Hydrocarbons; Hydrogeology; Petroleum refining; Pollution; Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons; Refining; Technology; Trichloroethylene; Underground reservoirs; Vegetable oils; Aerobic (CSTR); Air sparging; Bench scale; Contaminant concentrations; Electron donors; Enzyme production; high pH; Hydrocarbon molecules; In-situ; Mechanical aspects; Methyl esters; Oxygenase; Soy methyl ester (SME); Target compounds; Union Carbide (CO); United States; West Virginia; Organic compounds

Authors: Bleviss D.
Title: What multilateral banks (and other donors) can do to reduce greenhouse gas emissions: A case study of Latin America and the Caribbean
Authors with affiliations: Bleviss, D.
Abstract: Energy use and greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions from transportation are increasing more rapidly in developing countries than they are in the wealthier industrialized countries. Most strategies and policies under consideration to counter these trends, such as fuel economy standards, target the design of vehicles or the fuels they use. Multilateral development banks (MDBs) and other donor agencies have many opportunities to assist in the implementation of sustainable transportation strategies in developing countries to reduce the risk of climate change. These opportunities include tools directly available to limit carbon emissions from the transportation sectors of developing countries, as well as indirect tools that are oriented to other goals but that provide the co-benefit of reducing GHG emissions. A new tool to address transportation and climate change in developing countries is the Clean Development Mechanism (CDM), defined by the Kyoto Protocol, which recently entered into force. The CDM enables public and private entities in developed countries to invest in projects or programs in developing countries that reduce projected GHGs. Programs to reduce local air pollution, if focused on transportation systems, often reduce GHG emissions as well. © 2007 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.

Authors: Blomfelt F.
Title: FInnish forest industries federation, environment finish pulp and paper industry CO2 emissions below Kyoto level
Authors with affiliations: Blomfelt, F.
Abstract: The Finnish pulp and paper industry is using raw materials and energy efficiently in order to curb carbon-di-oxide (CO2). During 2006, 755,000 tons of recovered paper was used in Finland, 97% of it by the paper industry as raw materials. The pulp and paper industry in Finland invested around EUR 46 million in 206 on environmental improvements. Most of the effluents from the pulp and paper industry are treated in biological treatment plants, a few of which also treat sewage from surrounding community. The amount of waste sent to landfills has been reduced to a third and the volume of pulp and paper production has increased by about 50%. The recovery rate for paper and board at the mills was excellent in 2006, with close to 10% being recycled as raw material.

Authors: Bluett J., Bluett R., Carabotta K., Hoyle B., Macintosh K., Seeley R.
Title: The use of on-road measurements to improve understanding and management of vehicle fleet emissions in Australia
Source title: Proc. 14th International Union of Air Pollution Prevention and Environmental Protection Associations (IUAPPA) World Congress 2007, 18th Clean Air Society of Australia and New Zealand (CASANZ) Conf.
Affiliations: NIWA, Christchurch, NZ, New Zealand; DEC NSW, Sydney, NSW, Australia; DEC WA, Perth, WA, Australia; Queensland Transport, Brisbane, QLD, Australia; Department of the Environment and Water Resources, Canberra, ACT, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Bluett, J., NIWA, Christchurch, NZ, New Zealand; Bluett, R., DEC NSW, Sydney, NSW, Australia; Carabotta, K., DEC WA, Perth, WA, Australia; Hoyle, B., Queensland Transport, Brisbane, QLD, Australia; Macintosh, K., Queensland Transport, Brisbane, QLD, Australia; Seeley, R., Department of the Environment and Water Resources, Canberra, ACT, Australia
Abstract: Emissions from motor vehicles are the single most significant source of air pollution in many Australian urban areas. Improving our knowledge about the pollutants emitted by a range of vehicles is a high priority issue for authorities who are responsible for managing air quality in metropolitan cities. A monitoring programme being undertaken in Brisbane, Sydney and Perth during 2006-07 has produced a large and detailed database containing up to 50,000 on-road vehicle emission measurements. Vehicle emissions were measured using a remote sensing device (RSD). The pollutants CO, HC NO and UV smoke were sampled in the exhaust plumes of passing vehicles. Vehicle speed and acceleration were also measured and the number plate photographed. The number plate information was matched with emission measurements and then the emission data were analysed in detail. The RSD was linked to a driver feedback sign that instantaneously informed the driver about the state of their vehicle's emissions. This paper presents the preliminary results of measurements made in Brisbane, the first of the three cities monitored. The emissions of 20,000 vehicles are profiled by vehicle age, fuel type and purpose of use. The use of on-road vehicle emission measurements to validate emission factors, assess the effect of congestion and improve health impact assessments is examined. The utilisation of the data in the development and assessment of effective air pollution management strategies is discussed. The application of the RSD technology to a driver education programme is also explored. The paper concludes by presenting a summary of the planned outputs of this three city study which includes an interstate comparison of vehicle emissions profile.
Author Keywords: Clean Air Research Programme (CARP); Drive by testing; Exhaust measurements; Remote sensing device; Vehicle emissions

Authors: Bluett J., Bluett R., Carabotta K., Hoyle B., Macintosh K., Seeley R.
Title: The use of on-road measurements to improve understanding and management of vehicle fleet emissions in Australia
Source title: Proc. 14th International Union of Air Pollution Prevention and Environmental Protection Associations (IUAPPA) World Congress 2007, 18th Clean Air Society of Australia and New Zealand (CASANZ) Conf.
Affiliations: NIWA, Christchurch, NZ, Australia; DEC NSW, Sydney, NSW, Australia; DEC WA, Perth WA, Australia; Queensland Transport, Brisbane QLD, Australia; Department of the Environment and Water Resources, Canberra ACT, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Bluett, J., NIWA, Christchurch, NZ, Australia; Bluett, R., DEC NSW, Sydney, NSW, Australia; Carabotta, K., DEC WA, Perth WA, Australia; Hoyle, B., Queensland Transport, Brisbane QLD, Australia; Macintosh, K., Queensland Transport, Brisbane QLD, Australia; Seeley, R., Department of the Environment and Water Resources, Canberra ACT, Australia
Abstract: Emissions from motor vehicles are the single most significant source of air pollution in many Australian urban areas. Improving knowledge about the pollutants emitted by a range of vehicles is a high priority issue for authorities who are responsible for managing air quality in metropolitan cities. A monitoring program being undertaken in Brisbane, Sydney and Perth during 2006-2007 has produced a large and detailed database containing up to 50,000 on-road vehicle emission measurements. Vehicle emissions were measured using a remote sensing device. The pollutants CO, hydrocarbon, NO, and UV smoke were sampled in the exhaust plumes of passing vehicles. The data collected has potential uses beyond the outputs specified in the program. The vehicle emission data base can also be used to benefit collaborators' individual data and information requirements which include the validation of vehicle emission factors, enhancement of emission inventories and assessing the effect of congestion on emissions. The data collected in this program could be utilized for the development of effective vehicle focused air pollution management strategies. This is an abstract of a paper presented at the 14th International Union of Air pollution Prevention and Environmental Protection Associations World Congress 2007 (Brisbane, Queensland 9/9-13/2007).

Authors: Bluett R.
Title: Reducing vehicle refuelling emissions to improve air quality in the Sydney region
Source title: Proc. 14th International Union of Air Pollution Prevention and Environmental Protection Associations (IUAPPA) World Congress 2007, 18th Clean Air Society of Australia and New Zealand (CASANZ) Conf.
Affiliations: Department of Environment and Climate Change, PO Box A290, Sydney South, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Bluett, R., Department of Environment and Climate Change, PO Box A290, Sydney South, Australia
Abstract: Emissions associated with the refuelling of motor vehicles are a significant and growing source of VOC in Sydney. Sydney exceeds the national ozone goal on between 10 and 20 days/yr. VOC emissions attributable to passenger vehicles account for over 40% of regional VOC emissions. Refuelling emissions account for 7% of VOC emissions from passenger vehicles and 4% of total anthropogenic VOC emissions in the Sydney air shed. Passenger vehicle refueling emissions are growing at 1.5%/yr and are the largest uncontrolled emission source for Australian passenger vehicles. The Department of Environment and Climate Change has evaluated technologies that reduces refuelling emissions and found that the recovery of petrol vapor at the petrol pump is one of the most significant single actions available to substantially reduce VOC emissions in the Sydney region. At a cost of < than 0.25¢/L of petrol sold, vapor recovery at the petrol pump could reduce 5000 ton/yr of VOC in the Sydney region. This is an abstract of a paper presented at the 14th International Union of Air pollution Prevention and Environmental Protection Associations World Congress 2007 (Brisbane, Queensland 9/9-13/2007).
Author Keywords: Ozone; Refuelling emissions; Service stations; Smog; Stage 2 vapour recovery; Sydney region; VOCs; VR2
Index Keywords: Air pollution; Air quality; Electric breakdown; Environmental engineering; Environmental protection; Sustainable development; Weight control; Air pollution prevention; Australia; Clean air; Emissions (asphalt); International (CO); New zealand; Pollution

Authors: Bluett R.
Title: Reducing vehicle refuelling emissions to improve air quality in the Sydney Region
Source title: Proc. 14th International Union of Air Pollution Prevention and Environmental Protection Associations (IUAPPA) World Congress 2007, 18th Clean Air Society of Australia and New Zealand (CASANZ) Conf.
Affiliations: Department of Environment and Climate Change, PO Box A290, Sydney South, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Bluett, R., Department of Environment and Climate Change, PO Box A290, Sydney South, Australia
Abstract: Ground level ozone is formed in hot and sunny conditions when volatile organic compounds (VOCs) react with nitrogen oxides. Ozone is associated with increased hospitalisations for respiratory diseases and increased mortality. Sydney exceeds the national ozone goal on between 10 and 20 days per year. VOC emissions attributable to passenger vehicles account for over 40% of regional VOC emissions. Refuelling emissions account for 7% of VOC emissions from passenger vehicles and 4% of total anthropogenic VOC emissions in the Sydney air shed. Passenger vehicle refuelling emissions are growing at 1.5% per year and are the largest uncontrolled emission source for Australian passenger vehicles. This is despite the widespread adoption of technologies to control refuelling emissions in the US, Europe and Asia. To inform future decision-making on ozone management strategies, the Department of Environment and Climate Change has evaluated technologies that reduces refuelling emissions. The recovery of petrol vapour at the petrol pump is one of the most significant single actions available to substantially reduce VOC emissions in the Sydney region. At a cost of less than 0.25 cent per litre of petrol sold, vapour recovery at the petrol pump could reduce 5,000 tonnes of VOC per year in the Sydney region. This is a significant portion of the 30,000 tonnes per year reduction required for Sydney to comply with the national ozone goal.
Author Keywords: Ozone; Refuelling emissions; Service stations; Smog; Stage 2 vapour recovery; Sydney region; VOCs; VR2
Index Keywords: Air quality; Diseases; Filling stations; Ozone; Volatile organic compounds; Passenger vehicles; Refuelling emissions; Emission control

Authors: Blujdea V.
Title: Challenges and trade-offs in environmental and financial approaches of the afforestation of degraded lands
Affiliations: Forest Research and Management Institute, Sos. Stefanesti 128, Voluntari, 077190, Romania
Authors with affiliations: Blujdea, V., Forest Research and Management Institute, Sos. Stefanesti 128, Voluntari, 077190, Romania
Abstract: Significant areas of unproductive and marginal lands create important economic and environmental imbalances at local, regional and national level, in many Eastern Europe countries. Despite available scientific and technological solutions for their enhancement, existing large degraded areas require major financing. Afforestation of degraded lands is acknowledged as an activity where environmental and financial synergies occur, as it generates a real carbon sequestration potential, besides other associated benefits at local, regional and global level. An opportunity to value carbon sequestration potential is represented by the flexible mechanism of the Kyoto Protocol, Joint Implementation and Clean Development Mechanism (JI/CDM). An afforestation project includes several steps, that should ensure the integration of the project outcomes with social and environmental priorities at local, regional and global level, in the short, medium and long term, such as: Preparation, implementation (afforestation technology and plantation maintaining frame), plantation management (administration, planning, management); forest sustainability (local & regional integration); and project’s carbon commercial aspects (baseline, carbon projections and validation, monitoring plan, reporting, transfer of carbon units). Carbon accumulation performance of the plantations influences potential revenues. Afforestation projects oriented toward carbon sequestration are exposed to multiple risks due to their long run, like vulnerability to illegal cutting, risks associated with unsustainable management practices or those related to climate change itself, biodiversity loss or social pressure. © 2017, Environmental Science and Engineering. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Biodiversity; Carbon; Climate change; Economic and social effects; Emission control; Environmental technology; Finance; Project management; Reforestation; Carbon sequestration; Carbon sequestration potential; Clean Development Mechanism; Forest sustainability; Management practices; Plantation managements; Social and environmental; Technological solution; Sustainable development

Authors: Bodri L., Cermak V.
Title: Borehole Climatology
Affiliations: Eötvös University, Geophysics Department, Budapest, Hungary; Czech Academy of Sciences, Geophysical Institute, Sporilov, Czech Republic
Authors with affiliations: Bodri, L., Eötvös University, Geophysics Department, Budapest, Hungary; Cermak, V., Czech Academy of Sciences, Geophysical Institute, Sporilov, Czech Republic
Abstract: Climate for the 21st century is expected to be considerably different from the present and recent past. Industrialization growth combined with the increasing CO2 concentration in the atmosphere and massive deforestation are well above the values over the past several decades and are expected to further grow. Air temperature is rising rapidly well as does the weather variability producing frequent extreme events. Six of the ten warmest years occurred in the 1990s. Temperatures predicted for the 21st century ranges well above the present day value. The time period of the last 100-200 years covered by the direct meteorological observations is too short and does not provide material to reliably assess what may happen over the next hundred(s) years. A faithful prediction of the future requires understanding how climate system works, i.e. to reconstruct past climate much further in the past. Borehole paleoclimatology enables climate reconstruction of the past several millennia, unlike proxy methods provides direct past temperature assessment and can well broaden the areal range to the remote regions poorly covered with meteorological observations. Considerable debates have recently focused on the causes of the present-day warming, i.e. to distinguish between the natural and anthropogenic contribution to the observed temperature increase, eventually to quantify their regional distribution. Complex interpretation of borehole data with the proxies and additional socio-economic information can hopefully help. On observed data taken in various places all over the world we demonstrate suitable examples of the interaction between the subsurface temperature response to time changes in vegetation cover, land-use (farming) and urbanization. Precise temperature-time monitoring in shallow subsurface can further provide the magnitude of the present-day warming within relatively short time intervals. As far as we know, there exists so far no book dealing entirely with the subject of the Borehole climatology. Only relatively rarely this method is mentioned in otherwise plentiful literature on climate reconstruction or on climate modelling. There are, however, series of papers focussing on various borehole--climate related studies in numerous journals (e.g. Global and Planetary Change, Climate Change, Tectonophysics, Journal of Geophysical Research, Geophysical Research Letters, etc). Time to time a special issue appears to summarize papers on this topic presented during specialized symposia. Key Features - Description of a new useful alternative paleoclimate reconstruction method - A suitable source of information for those wishing to learn more about climate change - Material for lecturing and use in the classroom - Ample practical examples of borehole temperature inversions worldwide - Ample illustrations and reference list - Authors have a good knowledge of the problem based on more than 20 years of experience, one of them actually pioneered the method Key Features - Description of a new useful alternative paleoclimate reconstruction method - A suitable source of information for those wishing to learn more about climate change - Material for lecturing and use in the classroom - Ample practical examples of borehole temperature inversions worldwide - Ample illustrations and reference list - Authors have a good knowledge of the problem based on more than 20 years of experience, one of them actually pioneered the method. © 2007 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

Authors: Boielle N., Elder S.T., Raine R.R.
Title: Chassis dynamometer measurements of exhaust emissions from diesel-biodiesel (tallow sourced) fuelled buses
Source title: Proc. 14th International Union of Air Pollution Prevention and Environmental Protection Associations (IUAPPA) World Congress 2007, 18th Clean Air Society of Australia and New Zealand (CASANZ) Conf.
Affiliations: Energy and Fuels Research Unit, Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Auckland, Private Bag 92019, Auckland, New Zealand
Authors with affiliations: Boielle, N., Energy and Fuels Research Unit, Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Auckland, Private Bag 92019, Auckland, New Zealand; Elder, S.T., Energy and Fuels Research Unit, Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Auckland, Private Bag 92019, Auckland, New Zealand; Raine, R.R., Energy and Fuels Research Unit, Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Auckland, Private Bag 92019, Auckland, New Zealand
Abstract: Exhaust emissions from two in-service commercial buses fuelled with diesel-biodiesel blends were measured using steady-state and transient chassis dynamometer. Blends of 20 and 40% biodiesel were used. Hydrocarbon emissions reductions due to tallow methyl ester (TME) biodiesel blends up to 40% showed a strong load sensitivity with emissions reductions being greatest at light loads and reaching comparable levels to automotive diesel fuel (ADF) sulfur ADF at full rack operation. Some light load operating conditions resulted in particulate emissions with TME biodiesel blends exceeding the levels obtained with the reference ADF sulfur ADF. The results were not consistent between the two buses, suggesting that the different technology responds differently to the fuels. However, in general, reductions in all major emissions species were observed, with no conclusive change in power output or fuel consumption between the different fuel blends. This is an abstract of a paper presented at the 14th International Union of Air pollution Prevention and Environmental Protection Associations World Congress 2007 (Brisbane, Queensland 9/9-13/2007).
Author Keywords: Biodiesel; Bus emissions; Exhaust emissions; PM; Tallow methyl ester; Transient driving

Authors: Boielle N., Elder S.T., Raine R.R.
Title: Chassis dynamometer measurements of exhaust emissions from diesel-biodiesel (tallow sourced) fuelled buses
Source title: Proc. 14th International Union of Air Pollution Prevention and Environmental Protection Associations (IUAPPA) World Congress 2007, 18th Clean Air Society of Australia and New Zealand (CASANZ) Conf.
Affiliations: Energy and Fuels Research Unit, Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Auckland, Private Bag 92019, Auckland, New Zealand
Authors with affiliations: Boielle, N., Energy and Fuels Research Unit, Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Auckland, Private Bag 92019, Auckland, New Zealand; Elder, S.T., Energy and Fuels Research Unit, Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Auckland, Private Bag 92019, Auckland, New Zealand; Raine, R.R., Energy and Fuels Research Unit, Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Auckland, Private Bag 92019, Auckland, New Zealand
Abstract: Steady-state and transient chassis dynamometer measurements have been made of exhaust emissions from two in-service commercial buses fuelled with diesel-biodiesel blends. Blends of 20% and 40% biodiesel were used. The biodiesel was processed from tallow and met the New Zealand Standard 7500 for biodiesel fuels. Measurements include fuel consumption and exhaust emissions of CO2, CO, THC, NOx and PM. The steady-state measurements were taken at operating conditions corresponding to 3 engine speeds at full rack and 3 partial load/power points at a single engine speed. The transient tests were rapid accelerations to 80 km/h from standstill, representing typical acceleration of the bus on a flat road. Exhaust sampling was carried out using a full flow dilution tunnel with a constant volume sampler (CVS) system. Gaseous emissions were measured using laboratory grade emissions analysers including hot NOx and THC. Particulate samples were re-diluted using partial sampling off the full flow dilution system prior to measurement using gravimetric filter weighing. The results were not consistent between the two buses, which suggests that the different technology responds differently to the fuels. However, in general, reductions in all major emissions species were found, with no conclusive change in power output or fuel consumption between the different fuel blends.
Author Keywords: Biodiesel; Bus emissions; Exhaust emissions; PM; Tallow methyl ester; Transient driving
Index Keywords: Biodiesel; Esters; Exhaust gases; Fuel consumption; Gas emissions; Bus emissions; Tallow methyl ester; Transient driving; Bus transportation

Authors: Bondar D., Lynsdale C.J., Ramezanianpour A.A., Milestone N.B.
Title: Alkali-activation of natural pozzolan for geopolymer cement production
Source title: Sustainable Construction Materials and Technologies - International Conference on Sustainable Construction Materials and Technologies
Affiliations: Dept. of Civil and Structural Engineering, University of Sheffield, Sheffield, United Kingdom; Dept. of Civil Engineering, Amir Kabir University, Tehran, Iran; Dept. of Engineering Materials, University of Sheffield, Sheffield, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Bondar, D., Dept. of Civil and Structural Engineering, University of Sheffield, Sheffield, United Kingdom; Lynsdale, C.J., Dept. of Civil and Structural Engineering, University of Sheffield, Sheffield, United Kingdom; Ramezanianpour, A.A., Dept. of Civil Engineering, Amir Kabir University, Tehran, Iran; Milestone, N.B., Dept. of Engineering Materials, University of Sheffield, Sheffield, United Kingdom
Abstract: The challenge for the civil engineering community in the near future will be to realize structures in harmony with the concept of sustainable development, through the use of high performance materials of low environmental impact that are produced at reasonable cost. Geopolymer materials could provide a route towards this objective. The main benefit of geopolymer cement is their reduction in environmental impact as they use lesser amounts of calcium-based raw materials, have lower manufacturing temperature and use lower amounts of fuel, resulting in reduced carbon dioxide emissions for geopolymer cement manufacture by up to 80%-90%, in comparison with Portland cement. It is possible to use alkali-activated natural pozzolans to synthesize environmentally friendly and sound cementitious construction materials. This paper presents preliminary results of geopolymer using an activated Iranian natural pozzolan, namely Taftan. The formation of gel phase and the factors affecting this have been investigated using leaching tests, ICP-AES, FTIR, XRD and mechanical tests. © 2007 Taylor & Francis Group, London.

Authors: Booker D.R., Giannelli R.A., Hu J.
Title: Road test of an on-board particulate matter mass measurement system
Affiliations: Sensor'S, Inc.; NVFEL, U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, United States
Authors with affiliations: Booker, D.R., Sensor'S, Inc.; Giannelli, R.A., NVFEL, U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, United States; Hu, J., NVFEL, U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, United States
Abstract: In June 2005, the United States Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA) signed a final rule implementing in-use testing requirements for heavy-duty diesel (HDD) engines. The program requires manufacturers to measure gaseous and particulate matter (PM) exhaust emissions from diesel engines using portable emission measurement systems (PEMS) installed on vehicles. In order to measure PM emissions, a cooperative contract between Sensors, Inc. and the USEPA was commenced to develop a Proportional Particulate Mass Device (PPMD). It is comprised of three key elements: a micro-proportional sampling system (MPS) incorporating an exhaust flow-meter (EFM) and an eight element quartz-crystal microbalance (QCM) to measure particulate mass. Evaluation of the exhaust flow meter (EFM) at third-party facilities have shown that the mass emission data and flow data produced with the EFM correlates extremely well with traditional (non-portable) constant volume sampling (CVS) certification systems. A single element version of the QCM has been undergoing extensive testing in both CVS systems and in an on-board MPS based system. These tests include a 760 vehicle EPA sponsored emissions study in Kansas City and an on-board 5000 mile diesel truck study. Completing the list of key components of the PPMD is the MPS, of which the first unit was delivered to EPA in pre-production form in August 2005 for testing in HDD emission certification laboratories. This unit has subsequently been tested in a Coordinating Research Council (CRC) test project (E66) at Southwest Research Institute (SwRI) in San Antonio, Texas and during the aforementioned 5000 mile cross country road test. This document provides the results of the road trip from San Diego, CA to Ann Arbor, MI. Copyright © 2007 SAE International.
Index Keywords: Air pollution control equipment; Automobile manufacture; Diesel engines; Environmental Protection Agency; Flow measurement; Flowmeters; Quartz crystal microbalances; Roads and streets; Certification systems; Constant volume sampling; Emission measurement systems; Mass measurements; Particulate Matter; Southwest research institutes; Testing requirements; United states environmental protection agencies; Particulate emissions

Authors: Boriboonsomsin K., Barth M.
Title: Evaluating air quality benefits of freeway high-occupancy vehicle lanes in Southern California
Affiliations: College of Engineering, Center for Environmental Research and Technology, University of California at Riverside, 1084 Columbia Avenue, Riverside, CA 92507, United States
Authors with affiliations: Boriboonsomsin, K., College of Engineering, Center for Environmental Research and Technology, University of California at Riverside, 1084 Columbia Avenue, Riverside, CA 92507, United States; Barth, M., College of Engineering, Center for Environmental Research and Technology, University of California at Riverside, 1084 Columbia Avenue, Riverside, CA 92507, United States
Abstract: In the past decade, a variety of questions have been raised concerning the effectiveness of high-occupancy vehicle (HOV) lanes. In Southern California, recent evaluation studies on HOV lanes confirm the effectiveness of HOV lanes in several ways. However, little research has been performed to evaluate the air quality benefits of HOV lanes. This paper describes a study that examines operational differences in traffic dynamics between HOV lanes and mixed-flow (MF) lanes and evaluates their impacts on vehicle emissions. Four general HOV lane scenarios were identified: underutilized, neutral, well utilized, and overutilized. Extensive driving trajectories in both lane types for each scenario were collected. Their speed profile and joint speed-acceleration frequency distribution were analyzed and compared. Vehicle emissions and fuel consumption were then estimated with a state-of-the-art modal emissions model. The results show that HOV lanes produce lower emission rates per vehicle per mile in most cases, except when they are underutilized. When normalized by average vehicle occupancy, HOV lanes produce much lower emission rates per the same amount of travel demand, on the order of 10% to 70%. In almost every case, HOV lanes produce less emissions mass on a per-lane basis than MF lanes. Southern California freeway lane performance matrices show that on a typical weekday during the summer of 2005, HOV lanes operated mostly under Scenarios 1 and 2 during peak periods. Overall, they were well utilized about 14% to 17% of the time. According to the emissions estimates, the HOV lanes are considered effective in reducing vehicle emissions.
Index Keywords: Emission rates; High-occupancy vehicles; Emission control; Fuel consumption; Ground vehicles; Mathematical models; Particulate emissions; Roads and streets; Air quality

Authors: Borisova E., Uzunov Tz., Vladimirov B., Avramov L.
Title: Investigation of formalin influence over hard and soft biological tissues fluorescent spectra in vitro
Source title: Progress in Biomedical Optics and Imaging - Proceedings of SPIE
Affiliations: Institute of Electronics, Bulgarian Academy of Sciences, 72, Tsarigradsko chaussee Blvd., 1784 Sofia, Bulgaria; Dentistry Department, Medical University-Sofia, 1 G. Sofiiski Blvd., 1431, Sofia, Bulgaria; University Hospital Queen Jovanna, 8, Bjalo more str., Sofia, Bulgaria
Authors with affiliations: Borisova, E., Institute of Electronics, Bulgarian Academy of Sciences, 72, Tsarigradsko chaussee Blvd., 1784 Sofia, Bulgaria; Uzunov, Tz., Dentistry Department, Medical University-Sofia, 1 G. Sofiiski Blvd., 1431, Sofia, Bulgaria; Vladimirov, B., University Hospital Queen Jovanna, 8, Bjalo more str., Sofia, Bulgaria; Avramov, L., Institute of Electronics, Bulgarian Academy of Sciences, 72, Tsarigradsko chaussee Blvd., 1784 Sofia, Bulgaria
Abstract: In order to investigate the formalin influence over fluorescence properties of hard and soft biological tissues during conservation, emission spectra have been registered. Nitrogen laser at 337 nm and light-emitting diode with maximum at 405 nm have been used as excitation sources. For investigation of formalin influence over hard tissues, an experiment was made on teeth samples. Sound teeth were demineralized with a phosphoric acid for 10 seconds to obtain enamel structure near to the tooth lesion, and were fixed in formalin. Before and after teeth treatment spectra from the areas of interest were detected. There were not observed changes in the shape of the teeth spectra, related to the introduction of formalin fluorescence. Samples from mucosa of esophagus and stomach, where initially an ALA/Protoporphyrin IX diagnosis was applied, were used as soft tissue specimens. After fluorescent diagnosis in vivo biopsy samples were obtained from normal and cancerous areas and were conserved in formalin. Initially, spectrum observed has one autofluorescence maximum from the mucous tissue at 500-600 nm and secondary maxima from the protoporphyrin fluorescence at 635 nm and 720 nm, as well as pronounced minima at 540 and 575 nm related to hemoglobin absorption. After formalin conservation hemoglobin absorption was strongly reduced that increases mucous emission signal in green-yellow spectral region. Simultaneously the maxima at 635 nm and 720 nm were reduced. As conclusion we could say that formalin has negligible influence over fluorescence spectra of conserved hard tissues and has more pronounced influence over fluorescence spectra obtained in the case of soft tissue conservation, which has to be taking into account in measurements in vitro.
Author Keywords: Fluorescence spectroscopy; Formalin influence; Mucosa; Teeth
Index Keywords: Absorption; Fluorescence spectroscopy; Formaldehyde; Hemoglobin; Light emitting diodes; Porphyrins; Tooth enamel; Autofluorescence; Mucosa; Teeth; Tissue

Authors: Borken J., Steller H., Merétei T., Vanhove F.
Title: Global and country inventory of road passenger and freight transportation: Fuel consumption and emissions of air pollutants in year 2000
Affiliations: German Aerospace Center (DLR) - Transportation Studies, Rutherfordstr. 2, 12489 Berlin, Germany; Institute for Transport Sciences, Thán Károly u. 3-5, H-1119 Budapest, Hungary; Transport and Mobility Leuven, Vital Decosterstraat 67A/0001, 3000 Leuven, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Borken, J., German Aerospace Center (DLR) - Transportation Studies, Rutherfordstr. 2, 12489 Berlin, Germany; Steller, H., German Aerospace Center (DLR) - Transportation Studies, Rutherfordstr. 2, 12489 Berlin, Germany; Merétei, T., Institute for Transport Sciences, Thán Károly u. 3-5, H-1119 Budapest, Hungary; Vanhove, F., Transport and Mobility Leuven, Vital Decosterstraat 67A/0001, 3000 Leuven, Belgium
Abstract: This paper presents a comprehensive and validated inventory of road transport emissions worldwide. The bottom-up calculation correlates within 2% and 10% with fuel sales data in Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) and non-OECD regions, respectively; this adds credibility to the results. The inventory covers eight exhaust compounds emitted by five vehicle categories and five fuel types each. For many non-OECD countries, road transport exhaust emissions have been calculated for the first time at this level of detail. Furthermore, this paper provides a conservative estimate of primary particulate matter emissions from diesel and gasoline vehicles. The Group of Seven countries (Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, the United Kingdom, and the United States) together with Brazil, China, India, Mexico, and Russia account for more than three-quarters of all considered exhaust emissions, followed by major countries in the Middle East and Southeast Asia. Action in these 15 countries could reduce emissions for the whole region significantly. Exhaust control and maintenance can focus on motorized two-wheelers, buses, and heavy-duty trucks. The inventory is particularly suited for comparisons across countries and regions. Data uncertainties in transport volumes and real-world emissions, notably of hydrocarbon and particulate matter, should be reduced.
Index Keywords: Air pollution; Data reduction; Emission control; Fuel consumption; Gasoline; Particulate emissions; Exhaust compounds; Exhaust emissions; Road passengers; Freight transportation

Authors: Bosco S., Marchettini N., Pulselli R.M., Tiezzi E.
Title: European objectives in the post-Kyoto period and expectations for Venice
Affiliations: Department of Biosystems Sciences, Siena University, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Bosco, S., Department of Biosystems Sciences, Siena University, Italy; Marchettini, N., Department of Biosystems Sciences, Siena University, Italy; Pulselli, R.M., Department of Biosystems Sciences, Siena University, Italy; Tiezzi, E., Department of Biosystems Sciences, Siena University, Italy
Abstract: In January 2007, the Environmental Directorate of the European Commission released a preview of the results of a study on climate change and its consequences. Climate changes predicted for the next 20 years are already happening, as demonstrated by the latest scientific investigations, and are accelerating faster than predicted. The main novelty of the European report is that the European Union commits itself to promoting and leading the endeavour to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. EU countries are committed to a 30% autonomous unilateral decrease in emissions by 2020. This ambitious project should be a clear signal to the international community of the leading role Europe intends to play. The increase in temperature has a dramatic effect that will affect people living in coastal areas, and in Italy, the first glance is for the Venice situation. IPCC estimates suggest that increased annual temperatures and an increase in extreme precipitations in the Adriatic Sea will be the likely effects of global climate change. It becomes essential to be able to adapt to climate change and to plan an increase in resilience and a reduction of the costs of environmental damage. It is impossible to predict how climate change will unfold over the next 20-30 years, but it is nevertheless possible to protect our communities from the worst consequences to some extent.
Author Keywords: Climate change policy; European union; IPCC; Post-Kyoto period; Sea level rise; Stern review; Venice

Authors: Bosco S., Pulselli R.M., Bastianoni S.
Title: Renewable energy impact in reducing greenhouse gas emissions at local scale: The case study of South Tuscany geothermal fields
Source title: WIT Transactions on Ecology and the Environment
Affiliations: Department of Chemical and Biosystems Sciences, University of Siena, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Bosco, S., Department of Chemical and Biosystems Sciences, University of Siena, Italy; Pulselli, R.M., Department of Chemical and Biosystems Sciences, University of Siena, Italy; Bastianoni, S., Department of Chemical and Biosystems Sciences, University of Siena, Italy
Abstract: The energy sector is responsible for the majority of greenhouse gas emissions that cause global warming. The development of renewable energy is a central aim of the European Commission's energy policy. Italy has the principal high temperature geothermal deposits in the EU and alone represents 97.9% of the total European capacity in 2004. Tuscany has already reached the European goal of 25% of RES (Renewable Energy Source) established for 2010, thanks to the geothermal energy presence in its territory. Geothermal energy production in the South Tuscany area, which falls into the Siena and Grosseto Provinces, has been developed since 1969 and in 2004 had 2,360 GWh of net energy production. The aim of this paper is to point out the importance of geothermal energy in reducing greenhouse gases emissions at a local scale, carrying out emissions inventories of the concerned Provinces with the IPCC methodology. The electrical energy production in 2000 was enough to cover all the electrical energy consumptions in both Provinces. Applying a strictly geographical approach to the electrical energy consumption, the greenhouse gas net balances for both the Provinces decrease more than 50% that if we use a responsibility one. © 2007 WIT Press.
Author Keywords: Geothermal energy; Greenhouse gas emissions inventory; IPCC methodology; Local scale; Renewable energy
Index Keywords: emission control; emission inventory; energy policy; European Commission; fuel consumption; geothermal energy; greenhouse gas; local planning; renewable resource; Eurasia; Europe; Italy; Southern Europe; Tuscany

Authors: Bose R.K.
Title: Urban transport scenarios in South Asia: Energy and environmental impact of enhanced public transport systems
Affiliations: Regulatory Studies and Governance Division, Centre for Urban Systems and Infrastructure, Energy and Resources Institute, Darbari Seth Block, Lodhi Road, New Delhi 110 003, India
Authors with affiliations: Bose, R.K., Regulatory Studies and Governance Division, Centre for Urban Systems and Infrastructure, Energy and Resources Institute, Darbari Seth Block, Lodhi Road, New Delhi 110 003, India
Abstract: Motor vehicle ownership and utilization are growing rapidly in Asia, because of rapid urbanization and growing urban incomes. This sudden growth is resulting in increasing traffic congestion, fuel use, and CO2 emissions and in deteriorating air quality. This paper presents a common framework to explore scenarios of vehicle and energy use and emissions in three South Asian cities: Bangalore, India; Colombo, Sri Lanka; and Dhaka, Bangladesh. Scenarios are built by separately analyzing transportation activity (in tonne kilometers or passenger kilometers), modal structure (i.e., share of tonne kilometers or passenger kilometers occurring on each mode), modal energy intensity (in energy burned per tonne kilometer or passenger kilometer), and emission factors. Although the types of data available across cities vary widely and there are deficiencies and inconsistencies in the available data, the analysis suggests that motor vehicle use would roughly double in each city by 2020 in the business-as-usual scenario, largely because of expected income increases; fuel use and CO2 emissions would triple; and pollution loading would rise exponentially. An alternative scenario of slower vehicle and energy growth is explored, premised on substitution of personal vehicles with buses and reduction in traffic congestion. Consequently, fuel use and CO 2 emissions would only double in Bangalore and Dhaka, whereas in Colombo the increase would not be significantly lower than in the business-as-usual scenario. The cumulative carbon mitigation potential over a 15-year period would be 13% in Bangalore, 9% in Dhaka, and 2% in Colombo. The drop in pollution loading would be different in each city.
Index Keywords: Carbon dioxide; Emission control; Environmental impact; Gas emissions; Modal analysis; Urban planning; Emission factors; Modal energy intensity; Modal structure; Public transport systems; Motor transportation

Authors: Bose T.K., Hourri A., Champagne G.Y., Fournier R.P.
Title: Pathway for hydrogen in Urban transit system
Source title: NATO Security through Science Series C: Environmental Security
Affiliations: Hydrogen Engine Center Canada, Hydrogen Research Institute, UQTR, PO Box 500, Trois-Rivières, Que. G9A 5H7, Canada; Hydrogen Research Institute, Université du Québec à Trois-Rivières, PO Box, Trois-Rivières, Que. G9A 5H7, Canada; E-H2 (Energy-Hydrogen) Inc., Canada; Université du Québec à Trois-Rivières (UQTR); Hydrogen Research Institute, Université du Québec à Trois-Rivières, C.P. 500, Trois-Rivières, Que. G9A 5H7, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Bose, T.K., Hydrogen Engine Center Canada, Hydrogen Research Institute, UQTR, PO Box 500, Trois-Rivières, Que. G9A 5H7, Canada, Hydrogen Research Institute, Université du Québec à Trois-Rivières, C.P. 500, Trois-Rivières, Que. G9A 5H7, Canada; Hourri, A., Hydrogen Research Institute, Université du Québec à Trois-Rivières, PO Box, Trois-Rivières, Que. G9A 5H7, Canada; Champagne, G.Y., E-H2 (Energy-Hydrogen) Inc., Canada; Fournier, R.P., Université du Québec à Trois-Rivières (UQTR)
Abstract: According to the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), the average global temperature has risen over the last century. The changes in climate could adversely impact human health, agriculture, water resources, and ecosystems. Most national and international agencies have concluded that our use of carbon-rich fuel is responsible for global warming through the greenhouse effect. Automotive exhaust emissions are the largest single source of air pollution in the world today, especially in urban areas. Natural gas, a fossil fuel that offers substantial advantages over oil-derived fuels, can facilitate the transition to hydrogen fuel. Advanced natural gasfueled vehicles have the potential to reduce carbon monoxide and reactive hydrocarbon emissions substantially compared to gasoline vehicles. Further environmental benefits can be realized by using a blend of natural gas and hydrogen. Such an approach will help create an infrastructure for an eventual transition to hydrogen. © 2007 Springer.
Author Keywords: Fuel; Hydrogen; Natural gas; Transportation

Authors: Bouhot C.
Title: Greenhouse gas emissions and urban public transport
Source title: Proc. 14th International Union of Air Pollution Prevention and Environmental Protection Associations (IUAPPA) World Congress 2007, 18th Clean Air Society of Australia and New Zealand (CASANZ) Conf.
Affiliations: RATP, Département Environnement et Sécurité, 13 rue Jules Vallès, 75 011 Paris, France
Authors with affiliations: Bouhot, C., RATP, Département Environnement et Sécurité, 13 rue Jules Vallès, 75 011 Paris, France
Abstract: Every human activity generates greenhouse gas emissions (GHG), directly or indirectly linked to the consumption of fossil energy. In France, as in the majority of industrialized countries, transportation accounts for ∼ 25% of energy consumption and is responsible for an equally significant proportion of GHG emissions. A study was carried out to calculate the factors for GHG emissions for the different modes of urban public transport. All modes of public transport available in Paris and the Ile de France region were examined: bus (with distinctions made between the types of fuel used and the commercial routes); Metro; regional express railroad, and trams. The modes of rail transport offer very competitive energy efficiency and very low GHG emissions. These emission factors would still be lower than privately-owned transport or air transport using electric power produced in another European country. The unitary emissions of buses were 10-20 times greater than those of the modes of rail transport in France because the electric power is produced using a process that does not produce emissions. However, the energy efficiency of buses is doubled if the route is on a dedicated site with priority over the other modes of road transport. By improving the traffic conditions and the fill rates for urban public transport, the energy efficiency will be improved even more. By using the data gathered during the study, decision makers and technicians could can compare several solutions for public transport within an urban area, bring to the fore ways of reducing emissions or implement an effective transport policy with a limited impact on climate change. This is an abstract of a paper presented at the 14th International Union of Air pollution Prevention and Environmental Protection Associations World Congress 2007 (Brisbane, Queensland 9/9-13/2007).
Author Keywords: Emissions; Energy; Greenhouse gas; Inventory; Public transport
Index Keywords: Air pollution; Air quality; Electric breakdown; Environmental engineering; Environmental protection; Gas emissions; Global warming; Greenhouse gases; Leakage (fluid); Mass transportation; Sustainable development; Weight control; Air pollution prevention; Australia; Clean air; Green house gas (GHG) emissions; International (CO); New zealand; Urban public transport (PT); Pollution

Authors: Bouhot C.
Title: Greenhouse gas emissions and Urban public transport
Source title: Proc. 14th International Union of Air Pollution Prevention and Environmental Protection Associations (IUAPPA) World Congress 2007, 18th Clean Air Society of Australia and New Zealand (CASANZ) Conf.
Affiliations: RATP, Département Environnement et Sécurité, 13 rue Jules Vallès, 75 011 Paris, France
Authors with affiliations: Bouhot, C., RATP, Département Environnement et Sécurité, 13 rue Jules Vallès, 75 011 Paris, France
Abstract: Every human activity generates greenhouse gas emissions (GHG), directly or indirectly linked to the consumption of fossil energy. In France, as in the majority of industrialized countries, transportation accounts for approximately 25% of energy consumption and is responsible for an equally significant proportion of GHG emissions. The aim of this work is to calculate the factors for greenhouse gas emissions for the different modes of urban public transport. The calculations are based on the emission factors provided in the Bilan Carbone® method, a tool for calculating greenhouse gas emissions developed by the French Agency for the Environment and Energy Management (ADEME). All the modes of public transport available in Paris and the Ile de France region are examined: bus (with distinctions made between the types of fuel used and the commercial routes); Metro; regional express railroad (RER), and trams. This has revealed a wide diversity of factors for GHG emissions, which have still not been envisaged to date. The energy efficiencies of the modes of urban public rail transport are clearly revealed. Solutions for reducing GHG emissions caused by modes of bus transport are also highlighted by this study. Decision makers and technicians can compare several solutions for public transport within an urban area, bring to the fore ways of reducing emissions or implement an effective transport policy with a limited impact on climate change.
Author Keywords: Emissions; Energy; Greenhouse gas; Inventory; Public transport
Index Keywords: Decision making; Energy utilization; Gas emissions; Motor transportation; Fossil energy; Regional express railroad (RER); Urban public transport; Greenhouse gases

Authors: Boulard T.
Title: Greenhouse-crop system control for a sustainable plant production
Affiliations: INRA-URIH, 400, route des Chappes, 06903 Sophia Antipolis, France
Authors with affiliations: Boulard, T., INRA-URIH, 400, route des Chappes, 06903 Sophia Antipolis, France
Abstract: Control processes involved in greenhouse production concern several aspects of the production and must be considered globally and in mutual interaction. An analysis of the greenhouse production as forming a multilevel hierarchized system is presented. Using this grid of analysis, the recent developments in the field of greenhouse control processes are examined with respect to the information, criteria and control strategies that are taken into account in the three levels of the decision process: a) physical and chemical (climate, substrate) information and criteria related to the greenhouse environment; b) physiological and biological ones, related to crop behaviour and other biotic (bio aggressors and defenders) agents which were seldom considered in the control strategies; and, c) environmental, economical and social ones, related to sustainable crop production. Our focus was on control of the recycling of the nutrient solution, integrated pest management (IPM), temperature and more generally climate integration by plants. We concentrated on global approaches dealing with different levels of the decision process and allowing for example for the simultaneous setting and control of several parameters concerning the climate and/or the fertigation and/or the sanitary state of the plants. Finally, we analysed how the recent progress in control methodologies can answer to the new constraints involved by the sustainable development criteria and we outlined new prospects.
Author Keywords: Greenhouse; Sustainability

Authors: Bourgoin J.-P., Loiseau A., Nierengarten J.-F.
Title: Fullerenes and carbon nanotubes
Affiliations: Molecular Electronics Laboratory Service de Physique, De l'Etat Condensé CEA Saclay, 91191 Gif-sur-Yvette cedex, France; Laboratoire d'Etude des Microstructures (LEM), UMR 104 Onera-CNRS ONERA 72, 29 avenue de la Division Leclerc, 92322 Chatillon cedex, France; Groupe de Chimie des Fullèrenes et des Systèmes Conjugués, Laboratoire de Chimie de Coordination du CNRS, 205 route de Narbonne, 31077 Toulouse cedex 4, France
Authors with affiliations: Bourgoin, J.-P., Molecular Electronics Laboratory Service de Physique, De l'Etat Condensé CEA Saclay, 91191 Gif-sur-Yvette cedex, France; Loiseau, A., Laboratoire d'Etude des Microstructures (LEM), UMR 104 Onera-CNRS ONERA 72, 29 avenue de la Division Leclerc, 92322 Chatillon cedex, France; Nierengarten, J.-F., Groupe de Chimie des Fullèrenes et des Systèmes Conjugués, Laboratoire de Chimie de Coordination du CNRS, 205 route de Narbonne, 31077 Toulouse cedex 4, France
Abstract: Fullerenes and carbon nanotubes still represent a new field of study, since they were only identified in 1985 [1] and they have only been studied since 1990 in the case of fullerenes [2] and 1991 in the case of carbon nanotubes [3]. These two discoveries cast a completely new light on carbon as an element, and the international scientific community reacted immediately, with such vigour that two associated fields of research were born, which soon established their importance in the world of science, both from a fundamental standpoint and in terms of applications. To give an idea of the magnitude of the phenomenon, the subject is expanding exponentially if gauged by the number of publications: 2000 per year at present, having doubled between 1999 and 2002. This deep and long-lasting development is to a large extent due to the very special geometric characteristics of carbon nanotubes, with dimensions that are both nanometric and micrometric, leading to novel and versatile properties. For this reason, the related fields of research and applications are vast and ever more relevant to other branches of physics, chemistry and even biology. Nanotubes are thus particularly appropriate for scientific developments at the interface of these three disciplines. The aim in this chapter is to attempt to explain what fullerenes and nanotubes are, how they are synthesised and studied, what properties they have, and what the future prospects are, both in fundamental research and in applications.

Authors: Bourke P., Brockwell S., Faulkner P., Meehan B.
Title: Climate variability in the mid to late Holocene Arnhem land region, North Australia: Archaeological archives of environmental and cultural change
Affiliations: Centre for Archaeological Research, Australian National University, ACT 0200, Australia; Department of Archaeology and Natural History, Australian National University, ACT 0200, Australia; School of Social Science, University of Queensland, Brisbane Qld 4072, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Bourke, P., Centre for Archaeological Research, Australian National University, ACT 0200, Australia; Brockwell, S., Department of Archaeology and Natural History, Australian National University, ACT 0200, Australia; Faulkner, P., School of Social Science, University of Queensland, Brisbane Qld 4072, Australia; Meehan, B., Centre for Archaeological Research, Australian National University, ACT 0200, Australia
Abstract: A number of archaeologists have suggested that significant climatic change with environmental and social consequences occurred between 1000 and 400 years ago in the Indo-Pacific region. We investigate this premise by examining the archaeological record of changes in hunter-gatherer economies in three geographically distinct coastal regions of tropical northern Australia. These case studies support the argument that Aboriginal mollusc exploitation reflects the altered local ecological habitats that accompanied broader coastal environmental change over the last few thousand years. Overlap between the phases and timing of climatic and behavioural changes within each region suggests that, given regional variation in the nature and of these changes, there was an associated human response to late Holocene climatic variability. These case studies establish that archaeological and environmental evidence mutually support the argument for climate change influencing cultural change in northern Australia. We suggest that, while a direct physical link between environmental change and the interpretations of significant cultural change in the archaeological record have yet to be demonstrated unambiguously in this region, the analysis of mollusc exploitation has the potential to provide the direct link that is currently missing between changes in climate, environment and human responses over the last millennium.
Author Keywords: Arnhem land; Hunter-gatherer economies; Middens; Mollusc exploitation

Authors: Bowers B.J., Zhao J.L., Ruffo M., Dattatraya D., Sweetland V., Quet P.-F., Dushman N., Shi Y., McAulay J., Alberti I., Conti A., Beziat J.-C.
Title: Liquid fuel processor and PEM fuel cell power plant for vehicles
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Nuvera Fuel Cells, 20 Acorn Park, Cambridge, MA 02140, United States; RENAULT - DT2A - 68240, Renault, FR TCR GRA 0 75, Technocentre Renault - 1 avenue du Golf, 78288 Guyancourt, France
Authors with affiliations: Bowers, B.J., Nuvera Fuel Cells, 20 Acorn Park, Cambridge, MA 02140, United States; Zhao, J.L., Nuvera Fuel Cells, 20 Acorn Park, Cambridge, MA 02140, United States; Ruffo, M., Nuvera Fuel Cells, 20 Acorn Park, Cambridge, MA 02140, United States; Dattatraya, D., Nuvera Fuel Cells, 20 Acorn Park, Cambridge, MA 02140, United States; Sweetland, V., Nuvera Fuel Cells, 20 Acorn Park, Cambridge, MA 02140, United States; Quet, P.-F., Nuvera Fuel Cells, 20 Acorn Park, Cambridge, MA 02140, United States; Dushman, N., Nuvera Fuel Cells, 20 Acorn Park, Cambridge, MA 02140, United States; Shi, Y., Nuvera Fuel Cells, 20 Acorn Park, Cambridge, MA 02140, United States; McAulay, J., Nuvera Fuel Cells, 20 Acorn Park, Cambridge, MA 02140, United States; Alberti, I., Nuvera Fuel Cells, 20 Acorn Park, Cambridge, MA 02140, United States; Conti, A., Nuvera Fuel Cells, 20 Acorn Park, Cambridge, MA 02140, United States; Beziat, J.-C., RENAULT - DT2A - 68240, Renault, FR TCR GRA 0 75, Technocentre Renault - 1 avenue du Golf, 78288 Guyancourt, France
Abstract: Automakers are exploring many options for reducing vehicle CO2 emissions including PEM fuel cells that operate on hydrogen. While hydrogen infrastructure and storage remain as challenges, Renault and Nuvera Fuel Cells are developing advanced fuel processor technologies to generate hydrogen onboard vehicles using a variety of liquid fuels including conventional fuels (gasoline, diesel), bio-fuels (ethanol, bio-diesel), and synthetic fuels (gas to liquid). This fuel-flexibility could allow for evolutions of the fueling supply and also allow the same engine to operate on the local fuel of choice in markets around the world. This multi-year program has already made significant technology advances by customizing the chemical process train to give a fuel processor that is small enough and powerful enough for vehicle applications. The most recent fuel processor system continues the advances with a design that is being integrated into a lab-independent fuel cell power plant. Laboratory controls components have been replaced by integrated balance of plant (BOP) components to control the flows of fuel, air, and water as well as the thermal management and cooling. The program has produced fuel processors sized for up to 70 kWe of fuel cell power output and the current system is now exploring a lower power of 10 kWe to cover a variety of possible onboard applications. Reactor design and system integration are carefully considered in order to produce high-quality hydrogen-rich reformate gas that will not poison the fuel cell with CO or other contaminants.

Authors: Boyce B., MacCurdy D., Nortman P.
Title: SMUD-EnergyCS Plug-In Hybrid Electric Vehicle testing: A user's perspective
Source title: Electric Drive Transportation Association - 23rd Int. Electric Vehicle Symposium and Exposition 2007, EVS 2007 (Battery, Hybrid, Fuel Cell) Conf. Proc. - Sustainability: The Future of Transportation
Affiliations: Electric Transportation Group, Sacramento Municipal Utility District, 6301 S Street, Sacramento, CA 95817, United States; EnergyCS, 715 S. Myrtle Avenue, Monrovia, CA 91016, United States
Authors with affiliations: Boyce, B., Electric Transportation Group, Sacramento Municipal Utility District, 6301 S Street, Sacramento, CA 95817, United States; MacCurdy, D., Electric Transportation Group, Sacramento Municipal Utility District, 6301 S Street, Sacramento, CA 95817, United States; Nortman, P., EnergyCS, 715 S. Myrtle Avenue, Monrovia, CA 91016, United States
Abstract: In the summer of 2006, the Sacramento Municipal Utility District (SMUD) tested an EnergyCS Plug-in Prius conversion vehicle and a non-converted Toyota Prius in a side-by-side test format under real world driving conditions. Both vehicles are 2005 model year vehicles and both are equipped with identical data acquisition systems. Ten drivers were used in testing of the vehicles on the streets and freeways of Sacramento, California and 28 separate tests were conducted. The EnergyCS Plug-in Prius is a "blended" mode Plug-in Hybrid Electric Vehicle (PHEV) which normally operates in all-electric-mode at speeds below 34 miles per hour. The engine is programmed to turn on above 34 miles per hour as well as under heavy acceleration conditions below 34 miles per hour or during low battery conditions. Electric assist continues during all operating modes (engine off or engine on) as long as there is sufficient energy in the battery. The battery charge depleting assist range averaged approximately 40 to 45 miles for freeway driving conditions. Tests showed that the SMUD-EnergyCS Plug-in Prius averaged 98 miles per gallon for all accumulated summer driving (city, mixed and freeway). In addition, test data showed that fuel economy decreased significantly for short driving ranges less than 8 miles. The short trip fuel economy was attributed to increased engine operation to support heating of the engine/emission control system in order to meet emission targets. Fuel economy comparisons were made for cold starts and warm starts to confirm this phenomenon. Future test plans have been made to test different battery configurations that will provide comparative data for gasoline fuel economy as well as electricity use over the charge depleting range.
Index Keywords: Acceleration condition; At-speed; Battery condition; Cold start; Comparative data; Data acquisition system; Driving conditions; Driving range; Electricity use; Emission targets; Engine operations; Gasoline fuels; Operating modes; Plug-In Hybrid Electric Vehicle; Plug-ins; Plugin hybrid electric vehicles (PHEV); Sacramento , California; Sacramento municipal utility districts; Test data; Test plan; Toyota Prius; Warm start; Digital storage; Electric drives; Electric vehicles; Exhibitions; Fuel cells; Sustainable development; Fuel economy

Title: Results of PMIP2 coupled simulations of the Mid-Holocene and last glacial maximum - Part 2: Feedbacks with emphasis on the location of the ITCZ and mid- and high latitudes heat budget

Box 330 440, 28334 Bremen, Germany; Ramstein, G., Laboratoire des Sciences du Climat et de l'Environnement, Unité Mixte CEA-CNRS-UVSQ, Bât. 712, 91191 Gif-sur-Yvette Cedex, France; Valdes, P., School of Geographical Sciences, University of Bristol, Bristol, BS8 ISS, United Kingdom; Weber, L., Royal Netherlands Meteorological Institute, P.O. Box 201, 3730 AE De Bilt, Netherlands; Yu, Y., LASG, Institute of Atmospheric Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, P.O. Box 9804, Beijing 100029, China; Zhao, Y., School of Geographical Sciences, University of Bristol, Bristol, BS8 ISS, United Kingdom
Abstract: A set of coupled ocean-atmosphere(-vegetation) simulations using state of the art climate models is now available for the Last Glacial Maximum (LGM) and the MidHolocene (MH) through the second phase of the Paleoclimate Modeling Intercomparison Project (PM1P2). Here we quantify the latitudinal shift of the location of the Intertropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ) in the tropical regions during boreal summer and the change in precipitation in the northern part of the ITCZ. For both periods the shift is more pronounced over the continents and East Asia. The maritime continent is the region where the largest spread is found between models. We also clearly establish that the larger the increase in the meridional temperature gradient in the tropical Atlantic during summer at the MH, the larger the change in precipitation over West Africa. The vegetation feedback is however not as large as found in previous studies, probably due to model differences in the control simulation. Finally, we show that the feedback from snow and sea-ice at mid and high latitudes contributes for half of the cooling in the Northern Hemisphere for the LGM, with the remaining being achieved by the reduced CO2 and water vapour in the atmosphere. For the MH the snow and albedo feedbacks strengthen the spring cooling and enhance the boreal summer warming, whereas water vapour reinforces the late summer warming. These feedbacks are modest in the Southern Hemisphere. For the LGM most of the surface cooling is due to CO2 and water vapour.
Index Keywords: albedo; atmosphere-ocean coupling; carbon dioxide; climate modeling; heat budget; Holocene; Last Glacial Maximum; paleoclimate; precipitation (climatology); temperature gradient; tropical region; water vapor; Africa; Asia; Eurasia; Far East; Sub-Saharan Africa; West Africa

Authors: Brambilla M., Giacomelli P.
Title: Economic assessment of natural risks due to climate change. The case of an Italian mountain region
Source title: Landslides and Climate Change: Challenges and Solutions - Proceedings of the International Conference on Landslides and Climate Change
Affiliations: Università degli Studi di Milano, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Brambilla, M., Università degli Studi di Milano, Italy; Giacomelli, P., Università degli Studi di Milano, Italy
Abstract: This paper introduces the approach used to analyse the consequences of climate change on the Adda River basin (Lombardy, northern Italy); the area offers three main reasons of interest: it is one of the biggest in Italy; it is located in the richest region in the country and, thanks to its geomorphologic heterogeneity, could be affected by a wide range of natural hazards. The northern part,Valtellina, is a mountain area characterised by several hazards. The aim is to quantitatively assess the consequences of climate change on the socioeconomic system. The quantitative cause - effect approach is applied; climate change is the cause, and the effects are the outcomes on the social system. Such effects are described as "direct effects", directly tied up with "physical damages", and "indirect effects", due to the interruption of economic activities. Particular attention will be paid to extreme events; first of all, landslides. © 2007 Taylor & Francis Group.
