Authors: Decanio S.J.
Title: Distribution of emissions allowances as an opportunity
Affiliations: UCSB Washington, 1608 Rhode Island Avenue, Washington, DC, 20036, United States; Department of Economics, University of California, Santa Barbara, CA, 93106-9210, United States
Authors with affiliations: Decanio, S.J., UCSB Washington, 1608 Rhode Island Avenue, Washington, DC, 20036, United States, Department of Economics, University of California, Santa Barbara, CA, 93106-9210, United States
Abstract: Much of the debate on climate policy in the USA focuses on the gain or loss to the macroeconomy of alternative policies to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. However, the economy is made up of multiple individuals, not a single representative agent. This article reports the results of alternative ways of distributing emissions allocations across citizens. Macroeconomic effects interact with the policy for distribution, but the distributional weights are more important for the welfare of individual agents than the economy-wide effects of the emissions reductions. Egalitarian distributions of the emissions allowances have the potential to increase the welfare of most people, even if significant emissions reductions are mandated. Focusing on the distribution of emissions allowances (or the revenues generated from an emissions tax) rather than on aggregate GDP may provide guidance in identifying and implementing politically viable solutions to the climate change mitigation problem. © 2007 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Authors: Deglmann P., Ember E., Hofmann P., Pitter S., Walter O.
Title: Experimental and theoretical investigations on the catalytic hydrosilylation of carbon dioxide with ruthenium nitrile complexes
Affiliations: University of Heidelberg, Department of Organic Chemistry, INF 270, 69120 Heidelberg, Germany; GKP/M, BASF AG, 67056 Ludwigshafen, Germany; Karlsruhe Research Center, ITC-CPV, Molecular Catalysis, P.O. Authors with affiliations: Deglmann, P., GKP/M, BASF AG, 67056 Ludwigshafen, Germany; Ember, E., Karlsruhe Research Center, ITC-CPV, Molecular Catalysis, P.O. Box 3640, 76021 Karlsruhe, Germany, University of Erlangen, Institute of Inorganic Chemistry, Ergerlandstrasse 1, 91058 Erlangen, Germany; Hofmann, P., University of Heidelberg, Department of Organic Chemistry, INF 270, 69120 Heidelberg, Germany; Pitter, S., Karlsruhe Research Center, ITC-CPV, Molecular Catalysis, P.O. Box 3640, 76021 Karlsruhe, Germany; Walter, O., Karlsruhe Research Center, ITC-CPV, Molecular Catalysis, P.O. Box 3640, 76021 Karlsruhe, Germany
Abstract: Ruthenium complexes, mer-[RuX3(MeCN)3] and cis/trans-[RuX2-(MeCN)4] with X = Br, Cl, were investigated as precatalysts in homogeneously catalyzed hydrosilylation of CO2, The oxidation state of ruthenium and nature of the halide in the precatalysts were found to influence the catalytic activity in the conversion of Me2PhSiH to the formoxysilane Me2PhSiOCHO, with Ru III having chloride ligands being most active. Monitoring the reactions by in-situ IR spectroscopy in MeCN as the solvent indicates an interaction of the precatalyst with the silane prior to activation of CO 2. In the absence of CO2, hydrosilylation of the MeCN solvent occurs. Catalytic activity in CO2 hydrosilylation is enhanced by Me2PhSiCl, generated during reduction of RuIII in mer-[RuX3(MeCN)3] to RuII or, when added as promoter to RuII precatalysts. The reaction mechanism for the catalytic cycle has been calculated by DFT methods for the reaction of Me 3SiH. The key steps are: Transfer of the Me3Si moiety to a coordinated halide ligand, resulting in an LnRuH-(XSiMe3) intermediate → CO2 coordination → Me3Si transfer to CO2 → reductive elimination of formoxysilane product. This reaction sequence is more favorable energetically for chloride complexes than for the analogous bromide complexes, which accounts for their differences in catalytic activity. Calculations also explain the rate increase observed experimentally in the presence of Me2PhSiCl. A parallel reaction pathway leads to (Me3Si)2O as a minor byproduct which arises from the condensation of two initially formed Me3SiOH molecules. © 2007 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA.
Author Keywords: Carbon dioxide fixation; Homogeneous catalysis; Hydrosilylation; Ruthenium
Index Keywords: Carbon dioxide; Catalyst activity; Complexation; Hydrosilylation; Ligands; Oxidation; Carbon dioxide fixation; Formoxysilane; Homogeneous catalysis; Precatalysts; Ruthenium compounds

Authors: Del Greco S.A., Lott N., Ray R., Dellinger D., Jones P., Smith F.
Title: Surface data processing and integration at NOAA's national climatic data center
Affiliations: NOAA, National Climatic Data Center, 151 Patton Avenue, Asheville, NC 28801, United States; Global Science and Technology, West Virginia Division, Fairmont, WV, United States
Authors with affiliations: Del Greco, S.A., NOAA, National Climatic Data Center, 151 Patton Avenue, Asheville, NC 28801, United States; Lott, N., NOAA, National Climatic Data Center, 151 Patton Avenue, Asheville, NC 28801, United States; Ray, R., NOAA, National Climatic Data Center, 151 Patton Avenue, Asheville, NC 28801, United States; Dellinger, D., NOAA, National Climatic Data Center, 151 Patton Avenue, Asheville, NC 28801, United States; Jones, P., Global Science and Technology, West Virginia Division, Fairmont, WV, United States; Smith, F., Global Science and Technology, West Virginia Division, Fairmont, WV, United States
Abstract: The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) National Climatic Data Center (NCDC) is responsible for the stewardship of global climatological data to support the Global Earth Observation System of Systems (GEOSS). In the past, these data were processed through Quality Assurance/Control (QA/QC) systems that were primarily network-specific with no standard for rules/algorithms applied to similar parameters across the different observing networks. Therefore, NCDC implemented a plan to integrate surface climatological data into a common format and data model and process these data through one processing system that capitalizes on network independent standardized QA/QC algorithms and procedures. NCDC developed an Integrated Surface Data (ISD) format and database and a new QA/QC processing system, the Integrated Surface Data Processing System (ISDPS). ISD and ISDPS integrate QA/QC algorithms into a unified system. Numerous historical datasets have been fully integrated into ISD. Data from several sources and networks, totaling nearly 20,000 active observing sites, are now operationally processed (eg, daily) through ISDPS. These sources include NOAA's Automated Surface Observing System (ASOS), the Automated Weather Observing System (AWOS), global hourly and synoptic data from the Air Force Combat Climatology Center (AFCCC), U.S. Navy station data, the National Cooperative Observers (COOP) Network, and the Climate Reference Network (CRN). Additional historical datasets will be integrated into ISD, and additional data sources and networks will gradually be integrated into ISDPS. NCDC is working with partners (National Weather Service, Regional Climate Centers, State Climatologists, National Center for Atmospheric Research, AFCCC, etc.) to continue developing network-independent standards for QA/QC and to further expand ISD. We will describe these efforts, focusing on the QC processing system, data integration, and future plans for ISDPS and ISD.

Authors: Delgado M., Pérez-Camacho A.
Title: Comparative study of gonadal development of Ruditapes philippinarum (Adams and Reeve) and Ruditapes decussatus (L.) (Mollusca: Bivalvia): Influence of temperature
Affiliations: Institut de Recerca i Tecnologia Agroalimentaries, Centre de Aqüicultura, Carretera del Poble Nou, Km. 5.5, E-43540 Sant Carles de la Rápita, Tarragona, Spain; Instituto Español de Oceanografía, Muelle de Animas s/n, E-15001 A Coruña, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Delgado, M., Institut de Recerca i Tecnologia Agroalimentaries, Centre de Aqüicultura, Carretera del Poble Nou, Km. 5.5, E-43540 Sant Carles de la Rápita, Tarragona, Spain; Pérez-Camacho, A., Instituto Español de Oceanografía, Muelle de Animas s/n, E-15001 A Coruña, Spain
Abstract: Laboratory experiments were used to study the influence of temperature on the reproductive behaviour of two species of clam, Ruditapes decussatus and Ruditapes philippinarum, during their adaptation to the temperature conditions of Galician coastal waters. In both species the rate of gonadal development was directly related to the increase in temperature. At 14°C the reproductive behaviour was similar, both species needing over 2 months to mature. At 18*C, the rate of gonadal development of R. philippinarum was greater than that of R. decussatus. Nevertheless, the results of this study confirm that both species have adapted perfectly to the temperature conditions of the Galician Rias, though certain differences between the reproductive behaviour of these species were detected. R. philippinarum accumulates oocytes prior to their partial or total emission, while in the case of R. decussatus gametes are liberated continuously. In the early-phases of its development, the gonad of R. philippinarum is highly heterogeneous in nature, with up to 3 reproductive states being present at the same time, while in R. decussatus gonadal development is much more uniform. Another major difference concerns the phenomenon of reabsorption, common in R. philippinarum but very rare in R. decussatus. These characteristics may well result in a greater reproductive activity in R. philippinarum than in R. decussatus, and a longer reproduction period in the former. They may also represent a certain advantage for the adaptation of the foreign species (R. philippinarum) over the native species (R. decussatus) to the temperature conditions of the Galician Rias.
Author Keywords: Gonadal development; Hermaphroditism; Histology; Ruditapes decussatus; Ruditapes philippinarum; Temperature

Authors: Delin G.
Title: Twenty-four years of research at the Bemidji, Minnesota, crude-oil spill site
Source title: Battelle Press - 9th International In Situ and On-Site Bioremediation Symposium 2007
Affiliations: U.S. Geological Survey, Mounds View, MN, United States
Authors with affiliations: Delin, G., U.S. Geological Survey, Mounds View, MN, United States
Abstract: In 1983, the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) began an interdisciplinary research project at a crude-oil spill site near Bemidji, Minnesota, which became contaminated from a 1979 pipeline break. Scientists from the USGS and several academic institutions have been conducting research on the physical, chemical, and biological processes controlling the transport and fate of petroleum hydrocarbon contaminants in the subsurface at this site. Results of 24 years of research have provided fundamental knowledge, new tools, and new techniques that have been applied in remediating similar sites worldwide. The Bemidji research project was one of the first to document that the extent of crude-oil contamination can be limited by natural attenuation, and also was the first to document the importance of anaerobic degradation of hydrocarbons, particularly through iron reduction. Bemidji researchers developed a "freezing drive shoe" for collecting undisturbed cores below the water table that has been used at numerous other research sites. A two-dimensional, multispecies, solute-transport model (BIOMOC) was developed for the research site to analyze the evolution of the ground-water contaminant plume. Initial remediation of the site, completed about 24 years ago, removed approximately 60% of the spilled oil. A second period of pump-and-treat remediation conducted by the pipeline company from 1998-2005 is being evaluated by the research team. Other current research topics include the processes of diffusion, volatilization, and biodegradation in the unsaturated zone, microbe-mineral interactions, stimulation of degradation by iron reducing bacteria; and use of in situ microcosms for precise rate determinations. The research team currently is evaluating the processes of diffusion, volatilization, and biodegradation in the unsaturated zone. In addition, the USGS is collaborating with the pipeline company and the local regulatory agency to promote research and education at the site while also protecting the environment. As a part of this effort, we are interested in developing new collaborations with researchers, industry, consultants, regulators, teachers, or students on the development and testing of conventional, alternative, or enhanced in situ remediation strategies at the Bemidji site.

Authors: Delion D.S., Litta R.J., Wyss R.
Title: Decay rules in proton emission
Affiliations: Horia Hulubei National Institute of Physics and Nuclear Engineering, POB MG-6, Bucharest-Mǎgurele, Romania; KTH, Alba Nova University Center, SE-10691 Stockholm, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Delion, D.S., Horia Hulubei National Institute of Physics and Nuclear Engineering, POB MG-6, Bucharest-Mǎgurele, Romania; Litta, R.J., KTH, Alba Nova University Center, SE-10691 Stockholm, Sweden; Wyss, R., KTH, Alba Nova University Center, SE-10691 Stockholm, Sweden
Abstract: We give a simple relation, connecting the logarithm of the half-life, corrected by the centrifugal barrier, with the Coulomb parameter in proton decay processes. The reduced experimental data lie on two straight lines as a result of a sudden change in the nuclear shape, marking two regions of deformation, divided by the charge number Z = 68. This feature provides a powerful tool to assign experimentally quantum numbers in proton emitters. © 2007 American Institute of Physics.
Author Keywords: Angular momentum; Coulomb function; Half-life; Proton emission

Authors: Dembicki D., Netzer D., Wallsgrove C.
Title: Petrochemicals from bitumen
Authors with affiliations: Dembicki, D.; Netzer, D.; Wallsgrove, C.
Abstract: Integration of olefins and butadiene production with petroleum refining operation is not a new concept. However, integration of olefins production with bitumen upgrading refining is a new concept. A study for the government of Alberta Hydrocarbon Upgrading Task Force that includes industry sponsors such as Dow and Nova (major ethylene producers in the province of Alberta) was carried out. The overall concept was upgrading of high sulfur, hydrogen deficient, bitumen from Northern Alberta. This was assumed to be processed in the Edmonton area, to produce fuel products, i.e., diesel, kerosene, and gasoline. The economics of the fuel products was considerably enhanced by integrated production of olefins, pyrolysis gasoline, and butadiene by steam cracking from advantageous feed streams. These were co-products from the refining conversion units and substantially improved the overall economics of the proposed complex. A discussion covers the overall flow scheme; the rationale for selection of the major processing routes; conceptual economics; alternative scenarios in arriving at the overall complex configuration; economic analysis and model; ammonia, synthesis gas, CO2, sulfur, and hydrogen; economic issues related to diesel, kerosene, ethylene and olefins; working capital concerns; license fees and land costs; construction adjustments; water cooling; and steam and power generation. This is an abstract of a paper presented at the AIChE Spring Meeting - 19th Ethylene Producers Conference (Houston, TX 4/22-27/2007).

Authors: Dembicki D., Netzer D., Wallsgrove C.
Title: Petrochemicals from bitumen
Authors with affiliations: Dembicki, D.; Netzer, D.; Wallsgrove, C.
Abstract: Integration of olefins and butadiene production with petroleum refining operation is not a new concept. However, integration of olefins production with bitumen upgrading / refining is a new concept which has recently been developed as a study. The study was for the government of Alberta Hydrocarbon Upgrading Task Force (HUTF) which includes industry sponsors such as Dow and Nova - major ethylene producers in the province of Alberta. The overall concept is upgrading of high sulfur, hydrogen deficient, bitumen from Northern Alberta. This is assumed to be processed in the Edmonton area, to produce fuel products: diesel, kerosene and gasoline. These are produced by conventional refining and conversion processing. Hydrogen, mainly for the various hydroprocessing units, is produced by gasification of petroleum coke. The economics of the fuel products is greatly enhanced by integrated production of olefins, pyrolysis gasoline and butadiene by steam cracking from advantageous feed streams. These are co-products from the refining conversion units and therefore substantially improve the overall economics of the proposed complex. The entire complex is driven by electric power, produced by combustion of low value solid fuels in fluidized bed boilers. Incremental energy is supplied by coal. The gasification of coke is integrated with the coal fired steam generators. This energy integration is unique in that all of the major compressors are driven by electricity and all of the high pressure steam goes to a central power island. Since the incremental energy is coal derived ($0.73 per million BTU cost), the economical approach temperature for the cross exchangers is larger which also results in lower capital. The two most positive attributes to the overall economics are: 1. Bitumen is valued at only 41% on a volume basis (35% on weight basis) of West Texas Intermediate crude. 2. Almost 25% reduction in capital investment resulted from integrated production of petrochemicals, hydrogen and electric power as opposed to the traditional stand alone upgrading/refining and power units. Given all the above, with appropriate (conservative) contingency and escalation, the projected ROI is about 20% per year after Canadian federal and provincial taxes The paper presents the overall flow scheme and the rationale for selection of the major processing routes. Conceptual economics are presented, and several alternative scenarios are discussed in arriving at the overall complex configuration. Integration of olefins and butadiene production with petroleum refining operation is not a new concept. However, integration of olefins production with bitumen upgrading / refining is a new concept which has recently been developed as a study. The study was for the government of Alberta Hydrocarbon Upgrading Task Force (HUTF), which includes industry sponsors such as Dow and Nova - major ethylene producers in the province of Alberta. The basis was to consider such a complex in the area of Edmonton, Alberta.

Authors: Dennis R.S.
Title: Continuous ion exchange for wyoming CBM produced-water purification: Proven experience
Source title: SPE E and P Environmental and Safety Conference 2007: Delivering Superior Environmental and Safety Performance, Proceedings
Affiliations: Severn Trent Services Inc.
Authors with affiliations: Dennis, R.S., Severn Trent Services Inc.
Abstract: Water is pumped from thousands of shallow wells in the Powder River Basin of Wyoming to extract methane contained in coal bed seams, commonly referred to as coal bed methane or CBM. Over 2 barrels of water are pumped to produce a thousand cubic feet (MCF) of gas. The only environmental problem associated with the production of this clean burning domestic fuel is that the water's sodium bicarbonate content is so high that its discharge to the environment is harmful to both plant and animal life. EMIT Water Discharge Technology LLC and Severn Trent Services, Inc. have teamed together to apply one of STS's technologies for the purification of this produced water. The Higgins Loop Continuous Ion Exchange (CIX) System utilizes cation resins in an efficient mode to remove sodium from the water and concentrate it into a very small brine stream for disposal. The process also reduces the water's bicarbonate content by evolving carbon dioxide gas from the low sodium treated water under slightly acidic pH conditions. Purified water is then neutralized with limestone. This step increases its calcium content and makes the water more suitable for use in irrigation, human consumption, ranching and for aquatic life in rivers and creeks. The CIX process was first demonstrated in April, 2003 in a well field north of Sheridan, WY. Since then, EMIT has placed 15 more CIX Systems in operation in both Wyoming and Montana treating over 180,000 barrels per day of water. The technology has been accepted by both the gas producers and state regulators as the best available technology (BAT) and most economical process for CBM produced water treatment. This paper describes the reasons for produced water treatment, the purification process and the overall benefits to the industry and environment. Copyright 2007, Society of Petroleum Engineers.
Index Keywords: Carbon dioxide; Environmental impact; Ion exchange; Methane; Waste disposal; Water treatment; Best available technology (BAT); Coal bed seams; Continuous Ion Exchange system; Purification

Authors: Dennison J.R., Hoffmann R.C., Abbott J.
Title: Triggering threshold spacecraft charging with changes in electron emission from materials
Source title: Collection of Technical Papers - 45th AIAA Aerospace Sciences Meeting
Affiliations: Physics Department, Utah State University, Logon, UT 84322-4415, United States; Physics Department, Materials Physics Group, UMC 4415, United States; Materials Physics Group, UMC 4415
Authors with affiliations: Dennison, J.R., Physics Department, Utah State University, Logon, UT 84322-4415, United States, Physics Department, Materials Physics Group, UMC 4415, United States; Hoffmann, R.C., Physics Department, Utah State University, Logon, UT 84322-4415, United States, Materials Physics Group, UMC 4415; Abbott, J., Physics Department, Utah State University, Logon, UT 84322-4415, United States, Materials Physics Group, UMC 4415
Abstract: Modest changes in spacecraft charging conditions can lead to abrupt changes in the spacecraft equilibrium, from small positive potentials to large negative potentials relative to the space plasma; this phenomenon is referred to as threshold charging. It is well known that temporal changes of the space plasma environment (electron plasma temperature or density) can cause threshold charging. Threshold charging can also result from by temporal changes in the juxtaposition of the spacecraft to the environment, including spacecraft orbit, orientation, and geometry. This study focuses on the effects of possible changes in electron emission properties of representative spacecraft materials. It is found that for electron-induced emission, the possible threshold scenarios are very rich, since this type of electron emission can cause either positive or negative charging. Alternately, modification of photon- or ion-induced electron emission is found to induce threshold charging only in certain favorable cases. Changes of emission properties discussed include modifications due to: contamination, degradation and roughening of surfaces and layered materials; biasing and charge accumulation; bandstructure occupation and density of states caused by heat, optical or particle radiation; optical reflectivity and absorptivity; and inaccuracies and errors in measurements and parameterization of materials properties. An established method is used here to quantitatively gauge the relative extent to which these various changes in electron emission alter a spacecraft's charging behavior and possibly lead to threshold charging. The absolute charging behavior of a hypothetical flat, two-dimensional satellite panel of a single material (either polycrystalline conductor Au or the polymeric polyimide Kapton™ H) is modeled as it undergoes modification and concomitant changes in spacecraft charging in three representative geosynchronous orbit environments, from full sunlight to full shade (eclipse) are considered.
Index Keywords: Computational geometry; Degradation; Electron emission; Parameterization; Phase equilibria; Photons; Plasmas; Juxtaposition; Roughening; Space plasma; Spacecraft charging; Spacecraft

Authors: Deprost R., Bernard J., Riviere E., Leclerc N., Schillinger C.
Title: Chapter 2.4 Atmo-rhenA: a common air quality modelling system in the Upper Rhine Valley
Authors with affiliations: Deprost, R.; Bernard, J.; Riviere, E.; Leclerc, N.; Schillinger, C.
Abstract: The ASPA is in charge of regional air quality assessment and forecast (measurements and modelling), emission inventory realisation and gridding, and population information. In the frame of the European INTERREG III program, it is working together with the networks of Baden Württemberg (Landesanstalt für Umwelt, Messungen und Naturschutz Baden-Württemberg, LUBW) and Basel (Lufthygieneamt beider Basel, LHA) towards a "common air quality assessment and information system in the Upper Rhine Valley". The current and last step of the project is the set up of a common regional air quality modelling platform (simulation and forecast), which completes the bilingual website presenting daily measurements of the networks. The Atmo-rhenA platform is based on the CHIMERE (Institut Pierre Simon Laplace, IPSL, http://euler.lmd.polytechnique.fr/chimere) chemistry-transport model (CTM) and the MM5 meteorological model (National Centre for Atmospheric Research, NCAR). It is fed up with a detailed transboundary inventory update on the domain, integrating a speciation of non-methane volatile organic compounds (NMVOC) (Sambat et al., 2004) and particulate matter (PM) (Pregger et al., 2004) worked out by IER (Institut für Energiewirtschaft und Rationelle Energieanwendung) and CITEPA (Centre Interprofessionnel Technique d'Etudes de la Pollution Atmosphérique). Daily forecasts for the Upper Rhine Valley are operational since the beginning of 2005 and will be soon available on Internet. Indicators on the forecasting performances of the platform are calculated thanks to comparison with the routine measurements. Further, Atmo-rhenA allows the study of ozone production in the Upper Rhine Valley and the simulation of the impact of emission reduction scenarios on ozone peaks. For instance it has been used to assess the impact of a local short-term scenario (application of emergency measures) and of European long-term scenarios from the European Clean Air For Europe (CAFE) programme, both applied on the transboundary emission cadaster. © 2007 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

Authors: D'Errico G., Ettorre D., Lucchini T.
Title: Comparison of combustion and pollutant emission models for di diesel engines
Affiliations: Politecnico di Milano, Dipartimento di Energetica, Milan, Italy
Authors with affiliations: D'Errico, G., Politecnico di Milano, Dipartimento di Energetica, Milan, Italy; Ettorre, D., Politecnico di Milano, Dipartimento di Energetica, Milan, Italy; Lucchini, T., Politecnico di Milano, Dipartimento di Energetica, Milan, Italy
Abstract: In this work two significant approaches with different level of complexity for Diesel combustion modeling have been analyzed and implemented by the authors in the same open-source code, OpenFOAM: the Eddy Dissipation model and the PaSR (Partially Stirred Reactor) model. Concerning the latter, the potentialities and accuracy of the ISAT (In-Situ Adaptive Tabulation) algorithm, recently implemented by the authors into OpenFOAM, to reduce significantly the required computational time, were evaluated. Similarly, different models to predict pollutant emissions are revised and tested, due to considering the need to fulfill the future emission regulations imposing further reductions in NO x and soot. The mentioned models were applied to simulate a selection of significant Constant-Volume Diesel Combustion test-cases from the Engine Combustion Network database [1]. These data are particularly worth of interest since they have a public domain access, providing a framework for collaborative comparisons, and they include detailed information about pressure rise, liquid penetration length, ignition delay, lift-off length and soot distribution. The selected and simulated conditions consider n-heptane as fuel and include different oxygen concentrations and thermodynamic states (ambient density and temperature). Finally a real engine configuration was considered and the obtained results were compared against cylinder pressure data and pollutant concentrations. Copyright © 2007 SAE International.
Index Keywords: Combustion; Cylinder configurations; Diesel engines; Engine cylinders; Heptane; Open source software; Open systems; Pollution; Soot; Cylinder pressure data; Eddy dissipation models; Emission regulation; Engine configuration; Oxygen concentrations; Pollutant concentration; Situ adaptive tabulation; Thermodynamic state; Automobile engines

Title: Comparison of Combustion and Pollutant Emission Models for di Diesel Engines
Affiliations: Politecnico di Milano, Dipartimento di Energetica, Milano, Italy

Authors: Deutsch F., Janssen L., Mensink C., Torfs R., Vankerkom J.
Title: Supporting PM10 and PM2.5 air quality policies for Belgium and Europe in 2010 and beyond by means of scenario calculations
Source title: Proc. 14th International Union of Air Pollution Prevention and Environmental Protection Associations (IUAPPA) World Congress 2007, 18th Clean Air Society of Australia and New Zealand (CASANZ) Conf.
Affiliations: VITO, Flemish Institute for Technological Research, Boeretang 200, B-2400 Mol, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Deutsch, F., VITO, Flemish Institute for Technological Research, Boeretang 200, B-2400 Mol, Belgium; Janssen, L., VITO, Flemish Institute for Technological Research, Boeretang 200, B-2400 Mol, Belgium; Mensink, C., VITO, Flemish Institute for Technological Research, Boeretang 200, B-2400 Mol, Belgium; Torfs, R., VITO, Flemish Institute for Technological Research, Boeretang 200, B-2400 Mol, Belgium; Vankerkom, J., VITO, Flemish Institute for Technological Research, Boeretang 200, B-2400 Mol, Belgium
Abstract: The regional air quality model EUROS has been extended and used to calculate concentrations of PM10 and PM2.5 for Europe for the years 2002, 2010 and 2015 using recent emission scenarios. The obtained results for Belgium show decreases in PM-concentrations of 5 - 26% between 2002 and 2010, depending on the location. The contribution of anthropogenic sources in Flanders to annual averaged PM10 concentrations amounts to 17% in 2002 and 15% in 2010 on average. Results for 2015 indicate a further decrease in PM10 and PM2.5 for Europe. The most important contribution to PM10 concentrations originates from agricultural activities in Flanders, whereas the sector "traffic" is the dominant source for anthropogenic PM2.5 in Flanders.
Author Keywords: Abatement strategies; Aerosols; Air quality modelling; Emission scenarios; Fine particulate matter; PM10; PM2.5

Authors: Devasirvatham V., Cornish P.S.
Title: Precision application of water for peri-urban horticulture
Authors with affiliations: Devasirvatham, V.; Cornish, P.S.
Abstract: Vegetables are grown in the peri-urban zone throughout Australia on various soil types and in various climates. In order to grow vegetables throughout the year, irrigation is generally needed to supplement natural precipitation. Peri-urban horticulture in the Sydney region supplies fresh vegetables, cut flowers, turf and other farm produce. Competition for water and environmental impacts (e.g. nutrient-rich runoff and drainage) will increasingly influence access to water and its price, giving rise to the need for improved irrigation techniques. Subsurface Drip Irrigation (SDI) provides higher water use efficiency and crop yields and has the potential to reduce the risk of drainage and runoff with their environmental risks. However, SDI has potential disadvantages like poor germination or crop establishment and uneven wetting pattern. Research is needed to solve these problems and produce vegetables in an environmentally acceptable way. Copyright © 2007 Inderscience Enterprises Ltd.
Author Keywords: Drip irrigation; Germination; Peri-urban; Subsurface drip; Sydney basin

Authors: Dhanuka S.K., Driscoll J.F., Mongia H.C.
Title: Structures in a non-reacting and reacting model gas turbine combustor
Affiliations: Department of Aerospace Engineering, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI  48109, United States; GE Aircraft Engines, Cincinnati, OH  45215, United States
Authors with affiliations: Dhanuka, S.K., Department of Aerospace Engineering, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI  48109, United States; Driscoll, J.F., Department of Aerospace Engineering, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI  48109, United States; Mongia, H.C., GE Aircraft Engines, Cincinnati, OH  45215, United States
Abstract: Measurements were made in a gas turbine combustor experiment that contains a novel GE TAPS fuel injector, in order to develop an experimental database for the evaluation of Large Eddy Simulations. The combustor was designed to be optimized for LES modeling; it is nearly axisymmetic and has well-defined boundary conditions. It includes several interesting complexities that are a challenge to modeling efforts. There are regions of lean premixed prevaporized combustion (the main flame) and regions of nonpremixed combustion (the pilot flame). High-pressure chemistry occurs and flames propagate into highly preheated reactants. A large degree of unsteadiness is associated with the recirculation zone, vortex shedding and shear layers, which make the LES modeling approach attractive. The GE TAPS fuel injector has been demonstrated previously to provide significantly reduced emissions while still providing wide stability limits. The experiment provides optical access and relatively large mass flow rates of pre-heated air at elevated combustor pressures. PIV was used to investigate the flow field, including the size and strength of the shear layers and recirculation zone and the vorticity distribution. The degree of unsteadiness was quantified by recording the large difference between the instantaneous and average flow fields. The PIV work to date also indicates the way in which the heat release from the pilot flame alters the flow field.
Index Keywords: Combustors; Flow fields; Fuel injection; Gas turbines; Large eddy simulation; Shear flow; Experimental database; Gas turbine combustor; High-pressure chemistry; Lean premixed prevaporized combustions; Nonpremixed combustion; Recirculation zones; Stability limit; Vorticity distribution; Combustion

Authors: Dhungel B., Maier J., Scheffknecht G.
Title: Emission behaviour during oxy-coal combustion
Affiliations: Institute of Process Engineering and Power Plant Technology (IVD), University of Stuttgart, Pfajfenwaldring 23, 70569 Stuttgart, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Dhungel, B., Institute of Process Engineering and Power Plant Technology (IVD), University of Stuttgart, Pfajfenwaldring 23, 70569 Stuttgart, Germany; Maier, J., Institute of Process Engineering and Power Plant Technology (IVD), University of Stuttgart, Pfajfenwaldring 23, 70569 Stuttgart, Germany; Scheffknecht, G., Institute of Process Engineering and Power Plant Technology (IVD), University of Stuttgart, Pfajfenwaldring 23, 70569 Stuttgart, Germany
Abstract: This paper highlights major results during oxy-coal combustion in a 20 kW electrically heated once through PF furnace when using medium volatile bituminous coal from South Africa and Lignite coal from Eastern Germany. Emissions during oxy-coal combustion with different input O2 concentrations have been established. Results have demonstrated that emission behaviour during oxy-coal combustion with 27% 02/73% CO2 is almost similar to air-blown combustion. Fuel NOX reduction potential during oxy-coal combustion with the application of oxidant-staging by utilising over-fire oxidant have also been established and includes in-flame measurement of NOX precursors like HCN and NH3 as well. Results strongly indicate that fuel-NOx formation mechanism in fuel rich condition during oxy-coal combustion is similar to air-blown combustion and the state-of the art Low NOX technology is applicable to reduce NOX emissions under oxy-coal conditions as well. Fate of NO recycled back into the furnace during staged as well as un-staged combustion have been investigated by injecting known concentration of NO into the furnace and there are firm evidences that reduction of recycled NOX is completely dependent on local stoichiometry, the time available to interact with hydrocarbon radicals and the location of injection of NO. Investigation carried out so far on the fate SO2 when using Lignite coal has revealed that recycled SO2 is not reduced at all in the high temperature radiative section of the furnace. However, depending on the combustion condition, between 5-20% SO2 is reduced in the fluegas path where the temperature is around 450°C. Results also indicate that due to SO2 accumulation in the furnace, the H2S concentration during oxy-coal combustion is around 2.5 times more than corresponding air-fired combustion.
Author Keywords: CO2 capture; Fate of recycled NO; NOx formation; Oxy-fuel firing; SO2 formation
Index Keywords: Air pollution; Bituminous coal; Coal; Coal industry; Combustion; Concentration (process); Fuels; Furnaces; Hydrocarbons; Lignite; Organic compounds; Oxidants; Recycling; Reduction; Smoke; Stoichiometry; Theorem proving; Thermochemistry; CO2 capture; Fate of recycled NO; NOx formation; Oxy-fuel firing; SO2 formation; Coal combustion

Authors: Di Domenico M., Gerlinger P., Aigner M.
Title: Numerical investigation of soot formation in laminar ethylene-air diffusion flames
Source title: Proceedings of the ASME Turbo Expo
Affiliations: Institute of Combustion Technology, 70569 Stuttgart, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Di Domenico, M., Institute of Combustion Technology, 70569 Stuttgart, Germany; Gerlinger, P., Institute of Combustion Technology, 70569 Stuttgart, Germany; Aigner, M., Institute of Combustion Technology, 70569 Stuttgart, Germany
Abstract: In this work a new soot formation model is used to predict temperature, species and soot concentrations in laminar ethylene-air diffusion flames. The gas-phase chemistry is described by elementary reactions with transport equations solved for any species. The chemical paths yielding to soot are modeled by a sectional approach for Polycyclic Aromatic Hydrocarbons (PAHs). Soot dynamics is described by a two-equation model for soot mass fraction and particle number density. Phenomena like nucleation, growth and oxidation have been included both for PAHs and soot. Moreover, PAH-PAH and PAH-soot collisions are taken into account. Species, PAH and soot transport equations are implemented in the in-house DLR-THETA CFD code. The laminar, ethylene-air diffusion flame investigated experimentally by McEnally and coworkers (2000) is simulated in order to validate the model. An analysis of the main flame's features as well as the interaction between them and the soot chemistry will be given. A qualitative correlation between local stoichiometric values and soot formation rate is assessed. In order to study the sensitivity of the combustion model to simulation parameters like the inlet temperature and kinetic mechanism, additional simulations are performed. Results are also compared with experimental data in terms of temperature, species mole fractions and soot volume fraction axial profiles. Copyright © 2007 by ASME.
Index Keywords: Elementary reactions; Particle number density; Transport equations; Ethylene; Flame research; Mathematical models; Nucleation; Oxidation; Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons; Volume fraction; Soot

Authors: Di Filippo P., Riccardi C., Gariazzo C., Incoronato F., Pomata D., Spicaglia S., Cecinato A.
Title: Air pollutants and the characterization of the organic content of aerosol particles in a mixed industrial/semi-rural area in central Italy
Affiliations: DIPIA-ISPESL, Via di Fontana Candida 1, 00040 Monteporzio Catone RM, Italy; IIA-CNR, Via Salaria km 29.300, 00016 Monterotondo Scalo RM, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Di Filippo, P., DIPIA-ISPESL, Via di Fontana Candida 1, 00040 Monteporzio Catone RM, Italy; Riccardi, C., DIPIA-ISPESL, Via di Fontana Candida 1, 00040 Monteporzio Catone RM, Italy; Gariazzo, C., DIPIA-ISPESL, Via di Fontana Candida 1, 00040 Monteporzio Catone RM, Italy; Incoronato, F., DIPIA-ISPESL, Via di Fontana Candida 1, 00040 Monteporzio Catone RM, Italy; Pomata, D., DIPIA-ISPESL, Via di Fontana Candida 1, 00040 Monteporzio Catone RM, Italy; Spicaglia, S., DIPIA-ISPESL, Via di Fontana Candida 1, 00040 Monteporzio Catone RM, Italy; Cecinato, A., IIA-CNR, Via Salaria km 29.300, 00016 Monterotondo Scalo RM, Italy
Abstract: Both regulated and unregulated air pollutants were detected during an intensive seasonal sampling campaign in a mixed industrial/semi-rural area on the outskirts of Rome, Italy, at two sites located opposite a hospital waste incinerator, downwind according to the direction of the prevailing local winds. Concentrations of pollutants were significantly lower than in urban atmospheres. The composition of particulate organic material indicated a heavy biogenic impact, accompanied by a lower contribution from petroleum-related processes. Both PAH and nitro-PAH group compositions of particulates were used to assess the nature and relative importance of sources. Both sites showed that different and diffuse sources contributed to local pollution with a significant contribution from traffic, proving that the hospital waste incinerator was not the main pollution source in this area. Among unregulated compounds, a series of positional isomers of nitro-PAHs and other organic compounds associated with particulate matter were investigated. In particular, 1- and 3-nitrophenanthrene identification was carried out, and they proved to be the most abundant nitro-PAHs. © The Royal Society of Chemistry.

Authors: Dietiker J.-F., Hoffmann K.A.
Title: Numerical investigation of turbulent shear layers in jet exhaust flows
Source title: Collection of Technical Papers - 37th AIAA Fluid Dynamics Conference
Affiliations: Department of Aerospace Engineering, Wichita State University, Wichita, KS 67260-0044, United States; AIAA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Dietiker, J.-F., Department of Aerospace Engineering, Wichita State University, Wichita, KS 67260-0044, United States, AIAA, United States; Hoffmann, K.A., Department of Aerospace Engineering, Wichita State University, Wichita, KS 67260-0044, United States, AIAA, United States
Abstract: Detached-Eddy-Simulation is performed to investigate the effect of V-shaped chevrons to enhance mixing in shear layers and jet flows. The advantage of enhanced mixing is the potential reduction in noise emission. The flow solver Cobalt is used to carry out the three-dimensional, unsteady, computations. The Spalart-Allmaras turbulence model behaves as the Sub-Grid-Scale model. Results indicate that the presence of chevrons at the trailing edge of a splitting plate have little influence on a planar shear layer. For the supersonic jet flow emanating from a cylinder, three trailing edge geometries were Investigated: straight edge (no chevrons), 8 chevrons, and 2 chevrons. The 8-chevron configuration did not modify substantially the flow field, whereas the 2-chevron geometry increased the size of the core region and decreased the level of pressure fluctuations. Finally, a jet emanating from a cylinder with tapered chevrons was investigated. The 2-chevron configuration resulted in an elliptic-like jet that enhanced the mixing between the flow and its surroundings.
Index Keywords: Jet exhaust flows; Potential reduction; Turbulent shear layers; V-shaped chevrons; Computation theory; Computational geometry; Computer simulation; Eddy currents; Exhaust systems (engine); Jets; Turbulent flow

Authors: Dieuaide-Noubhani M., Alonso A.P., Rolin D., Eisenreich W., Raymond P.
Title: Metabolic flux analysis: recent advances in carbon metabolism in plants.
Affiliations: UMR 619 Biologie du Fruit, INRA Université Bordeaux 2, IBVM, BP 81, 33883 Villenave d'Ornon, France
Authors with affiliations: Dieuaide-Noubhani, M., UMR 619 Biologie du Fruit, INRA Université Bordeaux 2, IBVM, BP 81, 33883 Villenave d'Ornon, France; Alonso, A.P., UMR 619 Biologie du Fruit, INRA Université Bordeaux 2, IBVM, BP 81, 33883 Villenave d'Ornon, France; Rolin, D., UMR 619 Biologie du Fruit, INRA Université Bordeaux 2, IBVM, BP 81, 33883 Villenave d'Ornon, France; Eisenreich, W., UMR 619 Biologie du Fruit, INRA Université Bordeaux 2, IBVM, BP 81, 33883 Villenave d'Ornon, France; Raymond, P., UMR 619 Biologie du Fruit, INRA Université Bordeaux 2, IBVM, BP 81, 33883 Villenave d'Ornon, France
Abstract: Isotopic tracers are used to both trace metabolic pathways and quantify fluxes through these pathways. The use of different labeling methods recently led to profound changes in our views of plant metabolism. Examples are taken from primary metabolism, with sugar interconversions, carbon partitioning between glycolysis and the pentose phosphate pathway, or metabolite inputs into the tricarboxylic acid (TCA) cycle, as well as from secondary metabolism with the relative contribution of the plastidial and cytosolic pathways to the biosynthesis of terpenoids. While labeling methods are often distinguished according to the instruments used for label detection, emphasis is put here on labeling duration. Short time labeling is adequate to study limited areas of the metabolic network. Long-term labeling, when designed to obtain metabolic and isotopic steady-state, allows to calculate various fluxes in large areas ofcentral metabolism. After longer labeling periods, large amounts of label accumulate in structural or storage compounds: their detailed study through the retrobiosynthetic method gives access to the biosynthetic pathways of otherwise undetectable precursors. This chapter presents the power and limits of the different methods, and illustrates how they can be associated with each other and with other methods of cell biology, to provide the information needed for a rational approach of metabolic engineering.
Index Keywords: carbon; glutamic acid; terpene; article; chemistry; heterotrophy; metabolism; plant; Carbon; Glutamic Acid; Heterotrophic Processes; Metabolic Networks and Pathways; Plants; Terpenes; MLCS; MLOWN

Authors: Dittenhoefer A.C., Ellis H., Hirtler M., Egan B.A.
Title: A modeling methodology to estimate the potential for ground-level fogging from wet-scrubbed plumes
Source title: 100th Annual Conference and Exhibition of the Air and Waste Management Association 2007, ACE 2007
Affiliations: Enviroplan Consulting, 81 Two Bridges Road, Fairfield, NJ  07004, United States; Egan Environmental Inc., 75 Lothrop St., Beverly, MA  01915, United States
Authors with affiliations: Dittenhoefer, A.C., Enviroplan Consulting, 81 Two Bridges Road, Fairfield, NJ  07004, United States; Ellis, H., Enviroplan Consulting, 81 Two Bridges Road, Fairfield, NJ  07004, United States; Hirtler, M., Enviroplan Consulting, 81 Two Bridges Road, Fairfield, NJ  07004, United States; Egan, B.A., Egan Environmental Inc., 75 Lothrop St., Beverly, MA  01915, United States
Abstract: New federal and state requirements for major SO2 emission reductions such as the CAIR program have resulted in an increase in the use of wet Flue Gas Desulfurization (FGD) systems particularly for electric generating units. Installation of a wet FGD system results in a substantial increase in the emissions of water vapor and liquid water. This increases the potential for plume-induced ground-level fogging in the vicinity of these plants. A modeling methodology was developed to estimate the potential for the occurrence of ground-level fogging due to this increased water vapor and liquid water emissions from wet-scrubbed plumes. This methodology can be applied to assist a source in the determination of a stack height that will minimize the fogging impacts of wet-scrubbed plumes. The methodology consists of: 1. Air dispersion modeling of the water vapor and liquid water emissions from the source 2. Post-processing of model-predicted ground-level water vapor concentrations to determine the probability of fogging and/or icing occurrence. This paper discusses this methodology and provides examples of its application. It is directed to those government and private sector officials as well as those environmental groups and the general public concerned with the impact of new FGD systems on plume fogging in the surrounding area.
Index Keywords: Emission control; Fog dispersal; Liquids; Water vapor; Air dispersion model; Emission reduction; Environmental groups; Generating unit; ITS applications; Modeling methodology; Water vapor concentration; Wet flue gas desulfurization; Waste management

Authors: Dolben G.
Title: EU energy review - State of plans and EURELECTRIC's views
Affiliations: European Affairs of AEP, United Kingdom; EURELECTRIC, WG Energy Policy, Brussels, Belgium; Energy Policy and Generation, EURELECTRIC, Brussels, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Dolben, G., European Affairs of AEP, United Kingdom, EURELECTRIC, WG Energy Policy, Brussels, Belgium, Energy Policy and Generation, EURELECTRIC, Brussels, Belgium
Abstract: Europe's and indeed the world's energy demand is growing. Europe must ensure secure access to primary energy sources, and use the available resources in the most energy- and cost-efficient way. Given the threat posed by climate change, EURELECTRIC believes that Europe must, as a priority, seek an international greenhouse gas reduction agreement by industrialised countries and transitional economies. The most cost-efficient way to meet reduction commitments is through the continuing development of emissions trading. If Europe is to continue enjoying secure energy supplies, policies must promote diversity of energy sources and technologies.

Authors: Donovan P., Manning J.
Title: Strategy for efficient automotive climate control
Affiliations: Waterford Institute of Technology, Ireland
Authors with affiliations: Donovan, P., Waterford Institute of Technology, Ireland; Manning, J., Waterford Institute of Technology, Ireland
Abstract: The main objective of the research presented in this paper is a proof of concept of a vehicle independent control strategy based around currently available state of the art climate control system components to supply air to the vehicle cabin at the correct temperature and humidity level whilst improving overall efficiency. To fulfill this requirement, the operation of state of the art in climate control system components and sensors was investigated. A generic vehicle independent control strategy was devised using fuzzy logic to effectively control the complex and non-linear system while maximizing the inherent efficiency improvement characteristics of the state of the art components and sensors. This paper provides an overview of the proposed system and a selection of test results. Copyright © 2007 SAE International.
Index Keywords: Climate control; Control systems; Efficiency; Fuzzy logic; Linear systems; Vehicles; Automotive climate control; Efficiency improvement; Independent control; Overall efficiency; Proof of concept; State of the art; Temperature and humidities; Vehicle cabin; Humidity control

Authors: Doroshkevich A.G., Wall F., Ripp G.S.
Title: Magmatic graphite in dolomite carbonatite at Pogranichnoe, North Transbaikalia, Russia
Affiliations: Geological Institute, SB RAS, Sakhanovoy st. 6a, Ulan-Ude 670047, Russian Federation; Department of Mineralogy, The Natural History Museum, Cromwell Road, London SW7 5BD, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Doroshkevich, A.G., Geological Institute, SB RAS, Sakhanovoy st. 6a, Ulan-Ude 670047, Russian Federation; Wall, F., Department of Mineralogy, The Natural History Museum, Cromwell Road, London SW7 5BD, United Kingdom; Ripp, G.S., Geological Institute, SB RAS, Sakhanovoy st. 6a, Ulan-Ude 670047, Russian Federation
Abstract: A recently discovered dolomite carbonatite at Pogranichnoe, North Transbaikalia, Russia, dated at 624 ± 3 Ma, contains xenoliths of calcite-bearing dolomite carbonatite with graphite spherulites. Apatite and aegirine are the other rock-forming minerals. Chemically the carbonatites are ferrocarbonatite and ferruginous calciocarbonatite. The graphite forms <1 mm up to 1.5 mm diameter spherulites, with Raman spectra similar to published spectra of microcrystalline, amorphous carbon and disordered graphite, with G and D bands at 1,580-1,600 cm-1 and at around 1,350 cm-1. Alteration has formed Fe-bearing calcite to Ca-bearing siderite compositions not previously reported in nature around the graphite along cracks and fractures. Mineral and stable isotope geothermometers and melt inclusion measurements for the carbonatite all give temperatures of 700°-900°. It is concluded that the graphite precipitated from the ferrocarbonatite magma. There are three candidates to control the precipitation of graphite (a) a redox reaction with FeII in the magma, (b) potential presence of organics in the magma (c) seeding of, or dissolution in, the magma of graphite/diamond from the mantle, and further work is required to identify the most important mechanism(s). Graphite in carbonatite is rare, with no substantial published accounts since the 1960s but graphite at other localities seems also to have precipitated from carbonatite magma. The precipitation of reduced carbon from carbonatite provides further evidence that diamond formation in carbonate melts at high mantle pressures is feasible. © Springer-Verlag 2006.
Author Keywords: Dolomite carbonatite; Graphite; Transbaikalia
Index Keywords: carbonatite; dolomite; graphite; isotopic composition; magmatism; melt inclusion; precipitation (chemistry); stable isotope; Eurasia; Russian Federation; Transbaikalia

Authors: D'Ovidio G.
Title: Design of a hybrid power plant for city buses
Affiliations: University of L'Aquila, Faculty of Engineering, Monteluco di Roio, 67100 L'Aquila, Italy
Authors with affiliations: D'Ovidio, G., University of L'Aquila, Faculty of Engineering, Monteluco di Roio, 67100 L'Aquila, Italy
Abstract: This paper presents a preliminary system design for a no-emission hybrid power plant for city buses working in a "dense grid" transportation network with short, regular stop spacing. The vehicle is driven by two electric motors powered by a hybrid unit composed of a fuel cell and flywheel energy storage system that takes into account the characteristics of urban routes. The advantages and disadvantages of flywheel technology on board a vehicle are examined and discussed and an in-depth study of the proposed hybrid architecture was performed by analyzing and measuring the main power components for a small sized city bus with a 15 passenger capacity. © 2007 WEVA Journal.
Author Keywords: Buses; Flywheel; Fuel cell vehicles; Public transport

Authors: Dowden M.J.
Title: Climate change adaptation: A multi-disciplinary challenge
Source title: Construction and Building Research Conference of the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors, COBRA 2007
Affiliations: Clarkselgal LLP, One The Forbury, Reading, Berkshire RG1 3EB, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Dowden, M.J., Clarkselgal LLP, One The Forbury, Reading, Berkshire RG1 3EB, United Kingdom
Abstract: With each new set of climate change projections and scenarios, the need for adaptation as well as mitigation has become more pressing. Climate change adaptation is now an explicit element of law and policy at regional, national and supra-national levels. Of all climate change issues adaptation presents perhaps the most significant and immediate set of challenges to academics, policymakers and practitioners. Rational and effective climate change adaptation depends upon communication between disciplines ranging from climate change scientists to planners, architects to valuers, legal academics to practising lawyers. This paper seeks to identify the key elements of an effective climate change adaptation toolkit, and to highlight the increasingly important role played by inter-disciplinary groups and partnerships in formulating and delivering adaptation strategies. It argues that there is considerable scope (and need) for further cooperation, not least in areas such as the valuation of green building features and in the delivery of climate resilient developments.
Author Keywords: Adaptation; Climate; Law; Planning; Valuation
Index Keywords: Adaptation; Adaptation strategies; Climate; Climate change adaptation; Climate change projections; Green buildings; Key elements; Law; Multi-disciplinary; Policy makers; Laws and legislation; Planning; Resource valuation; Surveying; Climate change

Authors: Downie M., Race J., Seevam P.
Title: Transport of CO2 for carbon capture and storage in the UK
Affiliations: Newcastle University
Authors with affiliations: Downie, M., Newcastle University; Race, J., Newcastle University; Seevam, P., Newcastle University
Abstract: Some of the technical issues that need to be considered for the development of a UK CO2 transport infrastructure, in the post demonstration phase of carbon capture and storage, capable of mitigating the emission of greenhouse gases while allowing the continued use of fossil fuels are presented. To grasp the issues relating to the transport of CO2, it is necessary to be aware of its physical properties. For the issues relating to the transport of CO2 by ship, the most efficient way to transport CO2 is in supercritical or dense phase because it has a higher density in these states. The practice of transporting liquefied gas, such as LPG and LNG, is well established and they can be carried in fully refrigerated, semi-pressurized, or fully pressurized ships. For the issues relating to transport by pipelines, captured CO2 must be transformed to dense phase by compression above its critical point prior to transport by pipeline, which itself will be determined by the impurities present in the flow. The major sources of CO2 emissions and potential sinks in the UK to be used in EOR or simply for storage are shown. The major sources are mostly coal/gas/oil fired power stations and some large industrial concerns such as steel and cement works. Thus, in order for carbon capture and storage to perform its function as a bridging technology to a carbon neutral future in the UK, these issues must be addressed with considerable urgency if CO2 transportation is not to impose a bottleneck on its implementation.
Index Keywords: Energy policy; Enhanced recovery; Greenhouse gases; Offshore oil fields; Offshore power plants; Storage (materials); Carbon capture; Carbon neutral technologies; Enhanced oil recovery; Sinks; Carbon dioxide

Authors: Du B., Pollard R., Rainani M., Graney P., Elter J.F.
Title: Impact of cold start and hot stop on the performance and durability of a Proton Exchange Membrane (PEM) fuel cell
Affiliations: Plug Power, Inc., 968 Albany-Shaker Road, Latham, NY 12110, United States
Authors with affiliations: Du, B., Plug Power, Inc., 968 Albany-Shaker Road, Latham, NY 12110, United States; Pollard, R., Plug Power, Inc., 968 Albany-Shaker Road, Latham, NY 12110, United States; Rainani, M., Plug Power, Inc., 968 Albany-Shaker Road, Latham, NY 12110, United States; Graney, P., Plug Power, Inc., 968 Albany-Shaker Road, Latham, NY 12110, United States; Elter, J.F., Plug Power, Inc., 968 Albany-Shaker Road, Latham, NY 12110, United States
Abstract: Rapid fuel cell performance degradation was observed after just 30 cold start/hot stop cycles. Relativ; humidity (RH) was found to be the primary operating parameter associated with the rapid voltage decay during this thermal cycling. It was found that repeated thermal cycling could affect the RH inside a fuel cell and, consequently, alter the water activity of membrane/ionomer. We propose an extension of the generally accepted reverse-current carbon corrosion mechanism to account for the RH effects. The rapid voltage decay was linked te a RH-dependent cathode carbon corrosion process which was attributed to a lag in the ionomer/membrane hydration state during the thermal cycling. It has been demonstrated that one can reduce the carbon corrosion rate by avoiding the combination of cold starts and hot stops. Recommended strategies for mitigation are discussed in the context of the corrosion mechanism. © The Electrochemical Society.
Index Keywords: Carbon; Corrosion rate; Thermal cycling; Carbon corrosion; Cold start; Corrosion mechanisms; Fuel cell performance degradations; Hydration state; Operating parameters; Reverse currents; Water activity; Proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFC)

Authors: Dypvik H., Wolbach W.S., Shuvalov V., Widicus Weaver S.L.
Title: Did the MjØlnir asteroid impact ignite Barents Sea hydrocarbon source rocks?
Source title: Special Paper of the Geological Society of America
Affiliations: Department of Geosciences, University of Oslo, P.O. Box 1047, Blindern, No 0316 Oslo, Norway; Department of Chemistry, DePaul University, 1036 W. Belden Avenue, Chicago, IL 60614, United States; Institute of Geosphere Dynamics, Russian Academy of Sciences, Building 1, 38 Leninsky Prospect, 119334 Moscow, Russian Federation; Departments of Chemistry and Astronomy, University of Illinois, Roger Adams Lab 164, Urbana, IL 61801, United States
Authors with affiliations: Dypvik, H., Department of Geosciences, University of Oslo, P.O. Box 1047, Blindern, No 0316 Oslo, Norway; Wolbach, W.S., Department of Chemistry, DePaul University, 1036 W. Belden Avenue, Chicago, IL 60614, United States; Shuvalov, V., Institute of Geosphere Dynamics, Russian Academy of Sciences, Building 1, 38 Leninsky Prospect, 119334 Moscow, Russian Federation; Widicus Weaver, S.L., Departments of Chemistry and Astronomy, University of Illinois, Roger Adams Lab 164, Urbana, IL 61801, United States
Abstract: Organic-rich shales of Late Jurassic age make up the main source rock for oil and gas in large parts of the Arctic. These sediments, which locally may contain more than 15% total organic carbon (TOC), covered the target area of the MjØlnir impact. We suggest that the extreme richness of organic matter and highly volatile components in the target rock resulted in colossal and intense fires in the impact area, both in the air and on the seafloor. This hypothesis is supported by numerical simulations and explains the large quantities of soot that have been found in samples associated with the MjØlnir impact. © 2008 The Geological Society of America. All rights reserved.

Authors: Eastwood P.G., Morris T., Tufail K., Winstanley T., Hardalupas Y., Taylor A.M.K.P.
Title: The effects of fuel-injection schedules on emissions of NOx and smoke in a diesel engine during partial-premix combustion
Affiliations: Ford Motor Company, United Kingdom; Imperial College London, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Eastwood, P.G., Ford Motor Company, United Kingdom; Morris, T., Ford Motor Company, United Kingdom; Tufail, K., Ford Motor Company, United Kingdom; Winstanley, T., Ford Motor Company, United Kingdom; Hardalupas, Y., Imperial College London, United Kingdom; Taylor, A.M.K.P., Imperial College London, United Kingdom
Abstract: Our aim was to quantify, through engine calibration, benefits in emissions of NOx and smoke, and effects on Specific Fuel Consumption (SFC) and noise, whilst operating with partial-premix combustion. Tests were conducted using a current passenger car diesel engine in series production; thus highlighting limitations in contemporary engine hardware. By scheduling three fuel injections - hereafter designated early (90-62obTDC), middle (49-31obTDC) and late (39-15obTDC) - we sought to quantify the effect of injection timing (with constant fuel-demand) on engine performance. These results were then compared to those obtained with the same engine running under conventional diesel combustion. All tests were conducted at a desired steady-state operating point of 2000 rpm and 3 bar BMEP. The timing of the three injection events had different effects on combustion, as follows. With timing of the early injection, emissions of NOx and smoke were least affected. With middle injection, fuel mass delivered and emissions of NOx were more sensitive to the chosen timing than with the early and late injections. This plausibly relates to interactions between rail-pressure fluctuations and the timing of the injection event. With the timing of the late injection, measured fuel mass was unaffected (due to lack of rail-pressure interactions), but emissions of smoke were modified significantly. This could be explained by the interaction of the late-arriving liquid "slug" of fuel in the main combustion event i.e., insufficient opportunity was furnished for much evaporation or premixing to occur. Optimum partial premix (at the above operating point) reduced emissions of NOx, compared with the conventional-combustion baseline, by 60%, for similar levels of smoke emissions. However, an increase of 27% in SFC was observed, together with a noticeable increase in combustion noise (60% based on cylinder-pressure rise rate), plausibly due to the higher percentage of premix burn. Copyright © 2007 SAE International.
Index Keywords: Diesel engines; Fuel consumption; Fuel injection; Fuels; Nitrogen oxides; Passenger cars; Smoke; Conventional combustions; Cylinder pressures; Different effects; Engine calibration; Engine performance; Series production; Specific fuel consumption; Steady-state operating; Combustion

Authors: Eckhardt S., Breivik K., Manø S., Stohl A.
Title: Record high peaks in PCB concentrations in the Arctic atmosphere due to long-range transport of biomass burning emissions
Affiliations: Norwegian Institute for Air Research, Kjeller, Norway; University of Oslo, Department for Chemistry, Oslo, Norway
Authors with affiliations: Eckhardt, S., Norwegian Institute for Air Research, Kjeller, Norway; Breivik, K., Norwegian Institute for Air Research, Kjeller, Norway, University of Oslo, Department for Chemistry, Oslo, Norway; Manø, S., Norwegian Institute for Air Research, Kjeller, Norway; Stohl, A., Norwegian Institute for Air Research, Kjeller, Norway
Abstract: Soils and forests in the boreal region of the Northern Hemisphere are recognised as having a large capacity for storing air-borne Persistent Organic Pollutants (POPs), such as the polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs). Following reductions of primary emissions of various legacy POPs, there is an increasing interest and debate about the relative importance of secondary re-emissions on the atmospheric levels of POPs. In spring of 2006, biomass burning emissions from agricultural fires in Eastern Europe were transported to the Zeppelin station on Svalbard, where record-high levels of many air pollutants were recorded (Stohl et al., 2007). Here we report on the extremely high concentrations of PCBs that were also measured during this period. 21 out of 32 PCB congeners were enhanced by more than two standard deviations above the long-term mean concentrations. In July 2004, about 5.8 million hectare of boreal forest burned in North America, emitting a pollution plume which reached the Zeppelin station after a travel time of 3-4 weeks (Stohl et al., 2006). Again, 12 PCB congeners were elevated above the long-term mean by more than two standard deviations, with the less chlorinated congeners being most strongly affected. We propose that these abnormally high concentrations were caused by biomass burning emissions. Based on enhancement ratios with carbon monoxide and known emissions factors for this species, we estimate that 130 and 66 μg PCBs were released per kilogram dry matter burned, respectively. To our knowledge, this is the first study relating atmospheric PCB enhancements with biomass burning. The strong effects on observed concentrations far away from the sources, suggest that biomass burning is an important source of PCBs for the atmosphere.
Index Keywords: atmospheric pollution; biomass burning; boreal forest; emission; organic pollutant; PCB; pollutant source; pollutant transport; Arctic; Svalbard; Svalbard and Jan Mayen

Authors: Edelmann M., Gedan-Smolka M., Heinrich G., Lehmann D.
Title: Highly flexible low temperature polyallophanate powder coating with an excellent weathering resistance
Source title: Proceedings of 2007 International Conference on Advanced Fibers and Polymer Materials, ICAFPM 2007
Affiliations: Leibniz Institute of Polymer Research Dresden, Hohe Straße 6, D-01069 Dresden, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Edelmann, M., Leibniz Institute of Polymer Research Dresden, Hohe Straße 6, D-01069 Dresden, Germany; Gedan-Smolka, M., Leibniz Institute of Polymer Research Dresden, Hohe Straße 6, D-01069 Dresden, Germany; Heinrich, G., Leibniz Institute of Polymer Research Dresden, Hohe Straße 6, D-01069 Dresden, Germany; Lehmann, D., Leibniz Institute of Polymer Research Dresden, Hohe Straße 6, D-01069 Dresden, Germany
Abstract: In view of the commencement of the VOC-guidelines, regulating the reduction of the emission of organic compounds, emission free powder coatings become an attractive alternative to solvent based and even waterborne coating systems. Within the scope of several research projects new powder coating systems and catalyzed processes were developed. Highly flexible powder coatings with excellent mechanical properties can be cured completely at temperatures below 150°C. Furthermore a two step curing process was developed for a new processing technology. Two dimensional metal sheets (e.g. aluminum) can be coated at low temperatures and then formed directly into complex units. This strategy reduces the use of cost intensive and ecologically harmful cleaning processes. If required an independent second curing process can be followed up at higher temperatures, e.g. to enhance the stability of the coated units. At the state of the art no forming stable powder coating system is available for coil coating processes, so there is a high demand of developmental work which can be realized on the basis of the two step curing together with fast application and curing technologies.
Author Keywords: Low temperature curing; Powder coatings; Pre-coating; Weatherability
Index Keywords: Aluminum coatings; Curing; Mechanical properties; Organic solvents; Temperature; Coil coating process; Curing technology; Low-temperature curing; Pre-coating; Processing technologies; Two-dimensional metals; Weatherability; Weathering resistance; Powder coatings

Authors: Edwards S.
Title: Role of organic agriculture in preventing and reversing land degradation
Affiliations: Institute for Sustainable Development, P.O. Box 171, code 1110, Addis Ababa, Ethiopia
Authors with affiliations: Edwards, S., Institute for Sustainable Development, P.O. Box 171, code 1110, Addis Ababa, Ethiopia
Abstract: Soil erosion and desertification are the physical expressions of land degradation, while the social and economic impacts are degraded lifestyles and pernicious poverty. An understanding of how to maintain healthy soil is essential to reverse and prevent land degradation. Organic agriculture is a whole system approach based upon a set of processes resulting in sustainable ecosystems, safe food, good nutrition, animal welfare and social justice. It is more than just a system of production that includes or excludes certain inputs, particularly agro-chemicals, because it builds on and enhances the ecological management skills of farmers, fisher folk and pastoralists. Practicing organic or agro-ecological agriculture requires ecological knowledge, planning and commitment to work with natural systems, rather than trying to change them. IFOAM (International Federation of Organic Agriculture Movements) is an organization that promotes such sustainable agricultural systems. The application and upholding of the principles of organic agriculture can help ensure that agriculture can be continued throughout the world while contributing to the prevention and reversal of land degradation, combating poverty and building a fairer world order for all people. In 2004, IFOAM published a scoping study on “The Role of Organic Agriculture in Mitigating Climate Change”. The study looked at how organic agriculture could contribute to reducing green house gas (GHG) emissions and mitigate the impacts of climate change. Organic agriculture minimizes carbon dioxide emissions from agricultural ecosystems, and can also contribute to carbon sequestration because of the systematic application of manure and compost from animal and crop residues, crop-legume rotations, green manuring with legumes, and agroforestry with multipurpose leguminous trees. Soil is the most important sink for methane where high bacterial activity oxidizes it. Controlled anaerobic digestion of animal manure can contribute significantly to reducing methane emissions. Nitrous oxide emissions are minimized in an organic system. In 1996, the Institute for Sustainable Development started to work with local farming communities and local development agents and experts in Tigray, northern Ethiopia, to rehabilitate their environment and raise crop yields through using compost. Since 1998, ISD has monitored the impact of compost on crop yields in farmers’ fields. Overall, compost generally doubles the yield from fields that have not had any input. In most cases it also gives a higher yield than the use of chemical fertilizer. Other benefits from using compost include increased moisture retention capacity of the soil and reduced crop pest problems. © 2017, Environmental Science and Engineering. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Agricultural robots; Anaerobic digestion; Animals; Carbon dioxide; Carbon dioxide process; Composting; Crops; Economic and social effects; Ecosystems; Fertilizers; Forestry; Gas emissions; Global warming; Greenhouse gases; International cooperation; Manures; Methane; Nitrogen oxides; Soils; Sustainable development; Agricultural ecosystems; Carbon dioxide emissions; Ecological agricultures; International federation; Moisture retention capacity; Nitrous oxide emissions; Social and economic impacts; Sustainable agricultural system; Organic carbon

Authors: Edwards S.
Title: Role of organic agriculture in preventing and reversing land degradation

The principles behind organic agriculture are also used in programs and projects focused on overcoming food insecurity, rural poverty and environmental degradation. In 2003, IFOAM reported that over 40,000 farms covering 235,000 ha of land were growing certified organic products in Africa. © 2007, Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg.
