Authors: O'Neill C.M., Wolf E.E.
Title: Dual bed distributive membrane reactor for the oxidation of hydrocarbons
Affiliations: University of Notre Dame, 182 Fitzpatrick Hall, Notre Dame, IN 46556, United States; Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Notre Dame, 182 Fitzpatrick, Notre Dame, IN 46556, United States
Authors with affiliations: O'Neill, C.M., University of Notre Dame, 182 Fitzpatrick Hall, Notre Dame, IN 46556, United States; Wolf, E.E., Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Notre Dame, 182 Fitzpatrick, Notre Dame, IN 46556, United States
Abstract: The production of acrolein and methacrolein from propane and isobutane using consecutive catalytic beds for the oxidative dehydrogenation (ODH) of propane to propylene and isobutane to isobutene and the partial oxidation of propylene to acrolein (POA) and isobutene to methacrolein was studied. The ODH and POA reactions were generally first order in the hydrocarbon and zero to one half order in oxygen, while the competing combustion reactions were first order in both reactants. Experiments were performed in both a fixed bed reactor (FBR) and an inert membrane reactor (IMR), showing similar conversion. Selectivity to propylene and acrolein increased by 6 and 9%, respectively while decreasing the selectivity to CO2. These improvements in the selectivity supported the use of an IMR over a FBR for the ODH and POA reactions. The inclusion of a single IMR increased the selectivity toward acrolein and a dual-bed IMR further enhanced this effect. The dual bed IMR initially increased the selectivity to acrolein by 7%. The oxidation of isobutane to methacrolein through the intermediate isobutene follows similar kinetics to that of the propane to acrolein reaction network. Due to the similarity between these two reaction networks the methacrolein yield should be enhanced as in the case of acrolein in the partial oxidation of propane. This is an abstract of a paper presented at the 2007 AIChE Annual Meeting (Salt Lake City, UT 11/4-9/2007).

Authors: Onishi K., Ueyama T., Matsuoka T., Nobuoka D., Saito H., Xue Z.
Title: Applying differential analysis to cross-well seismic survey for monitoring CO2 sequestration
Source title: Society of Exploration Geophysicists - 77th SEG International Exposition and Annual Meeting, SEG 2007
Affiliations: Kyoto Univ., Japan; OYO Corp., India; RITE, India
Authors with affiliations: Onishi, K., Kyoto Univ., Japan; Ueyama, T., Kyoto Univ., Japan; Matsuoka, T., Kyoto Univ., Japan; Nobuoka, D., OYO Corp., India; Saito, H., OYO Corp., India; Xue, Z., RITE, India
Abstract: Capturing CO2 directly from large stationary sources such as thermal power plants and subsequently storing it in a nearby aquifer can be the most efficient way to reduce CO2 emissions into the atmosphere at a lower cost, and monitoring injected CO2 is important to verify practical effectiveness of the CO2 storage. The pilot-scale CO2 sequestration experiment has been undertaken at the Nagaoka gas and oil field, in Niigata Prefecture, Japan and we conducted time-lapse cross-well seismic tomography to detect the spread of injected CO2. When super-critical CO2 spreads into porous media saturated with brine water, the seismic velocity always decreases, which is confirmed theoretically and experimentally. Therefore, CO2 flood area can be estimated from seismic tomography records before and after CO2 injection. However, the tomography records before and after CO2 injection include not only the variation due to CO2 flood, but also differences occurred from the location and property of sources and receivers and they result analysis errors. Thus, in this study, we applied the differential analysis to cross-well seismic tomography for reducing the difference due to measurement conditions and getting more accurate monitoring results. In the normal procedure, velocity differences are calculated after applying inversion processing to each record separately, but in this differential analysis, first forward modeling is applied using the velocity distribution inverted from one referential record, second the set of the first arrival time is obtained from the modeling result and finally the inversion processing is analyzed from the data set of the first arrival time added with the difference of travel-times from the referential record. In the result, we can have an analysis result in which the distribution of CO2 flooding is clearly identified along with a caprock under the inversion analysis with the constrained condition of no velocity enhancement. © 2007 Society of Exploration Geophysicists. All rights reserved.

Authors: Oommen R., Hauser J., Dayton D., Swift J.
Title: Evaluation of air toxics concentrations and emissions for the San Juan, Puerto Rico MSA
Source title: Air and Waste Management Association - Symposium on Air Quality Measurement Methods and Technology 2007
Affiliations: Eastern Research Group, Inc., 1600 Perimeter Park Drive, Morrisville, NC 27560, United States
Authors with affiliations: Oommen, R., Eastern Research Group, Inc., 1600 Perimeter Park Drive, Morrisville, NC 27560, United States; Hauser, J., Eastern Research Group, Inc., 1600 Perimeter Park Drive, Morrisville, NC 27560, United States; Dayton, D., Eastern Research Group, Inc., 1600 Perimeter Park Drive, Morrisville, NC 27560, United States; Swift, J., Eastern Research Group, Inc., 1600 Perimeter Park Drive, Morrisville, NC 27560, United States
Abstract: Air toxics pollution continues to be a pervasive problem in many cities around the U.S. Acute and chronic exposure to certain pollutants can lead to cancer and/or noncancer effects. Over the last several years, efforts have been made by federal, state, local, and tribal agencies to reduce air toxics emissions and concentrations, thereby reducing associated risk. Understanding the relationship between emissions and concentrations, and integrating meteorological data can be useful in developing strategies for reducing air toxic pollution. An evaluation of air toxics emissions and concentrations was conducted for two monitoring sites in the San Juan, Puerto Rico (PR) Metropolitan Statistical Areas (MSA) that participated in the 2005 Urban Air Toxics Monitoring Program (UATMP). The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) sponsors the UATMP to obtain air toxics measurements data to characterize the composition and magnitude of pollution across the United States. Air toxics monitoring data from the same sampling day were reviewed at these two sites to determine if there is a significant difference in concentrations from the upwind and downwind locations. Air toxics pollutants analyzed include volatile organic compounds (VOCs) and carbonyls. An evaluation of emission sources from the 2002 National Emissions Inventory (NEI) potentially affecting downwind concentrations is also presented. The NEI is also managed by U.S. EPA, and contains emissions information from stationary (point and area nonpoint) and mobile (onroad and nonroad) sources. Data from the National Weather Service (NWS) and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) are used to identify predominant daily wind flow and for the construction of back trajectories.

Authors: Oppermann U.
Title: Carbonyl reductases: The complex relationships of mammalian carbonyl- and quinone-reducing enzymes and their role in physiology
Source title: Annual Review of Pharmacology and Toxicology
Affiliations: Structural Genomics Consortium, Botnar Research Center, University of Oxford, Oxford, OX3 7LD, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Oppermann, U., Structural Genomics Consortium, Botnar Research Center, University of Oxford, Oxford, OX3 7LD, United Kingdom
Abstract: Carbonyl groups are frequently found in endogenous or xenobiotic compounds. Reactive carbonyls, formed during lipid peroxidation or food processing, and xenobiotic quinones are able to covalently modify DNA or amino acids. They can also promote oxidative stress, the products of which are thought to be an important initiating factor in degenerative diseases or cancer. Carbonyl groups are reduced by an array of distinct NADPH-dependent enzymes, belonging to several oxidoreductase families. These reductases often show broad and overlapping substrate specificities and some well-characterized members, e.g., carbonyl reductase (CBR1) or NADPH-quinone reductase (NQO1) have protective roles toward xenobiotic carbonyls and quinones because metabolic reduction leads to less toxic products, which can be further metabolized and excreted. This review summarizes the current knowledge on structure and function relationships of the major human and mammalian carbonyl reductases identified. Copyright © 2007 by Annual Reviews. All rights reserved.

Authors: Osborn W.L., Demirci N., Gülgör A., Erkan B., Yildirim N.
Title: Carbonate scale inhibition in a high-gas geothermal well, germencik, Turkey
Affiliations: PowerChem Technology LLC, Minden, NV, United States; Gürmat Elektrik Üretim A.ş., Ankara, Turkey; General Directorate of Mineral Research and Exploration (MTA), Ankara, Turkey; Yildirim Jeotermal Ltd. Şti., Ankara, Turkey
Authors with affiliations: Osborn, W.L., PowerChem Technology LLC, Minden, NV, United States; Demirci, N., Gürmat Elektrik Üretim A.ş., Ankara, Turkey; Gülgör, A., Gürmat Elektrik Üretim A.ş., Ankara, Turkey; Erkan, B., General Directorate of Mineral Research and Exploration (MTA), Ankara, Turkey; Yildirim, N., Yildirim Jeotermal Ltd. Şti., Ankara, Turkey
Abstract: Germencik is the largest known high-temperature geothermal system in Turkey. Geothermal development in Turkey has been hampered, in part, by high CO2 concentrations and the resulting severe calcium carbonate scale precipitation. Germencik, originally drilled for production in the mid-1980's, is now being fully developed with additional production and injection wells, and a 50 MW power plant. A 10-day flow test was completed to demonstrate that uninterrupted power generation could be accomplished with cost-effective scale inhibition. High total inorganic carbon concentrations of 2.0 wt.% CO 2 in the 200°-230°C single-phase reservoir liquid results in high flowing wellhead pressure and gas/steam ratio in the well bore, and CO 2 concentrations in high pressure steam of 20 wt.%. At power plant gathering system design pressures, scale deposition is relatively minor in the well bore, but severe in surface piping, with general calcium carbonate deposition rates exceeding 1.5 meter/year, and locally up to 88 meter/years, if appropriate mitigation techniques are not implemented. Application of PowerChem Geosperse 8466 polymeric inhibitor reduced calcium carbonate deposition by more than 99.9% over an eight-day application. Scale inhibitor must be injected below the depth of gas breakout to fully mitigate scale formation in the well bore, but feeding additional inhibitor at the surface is not necessary to prevent scale formation from the wellhead to the power plant.

Title: Particulate matter forecasting in border region Polish and Czech Republic by using data mining methods

Affiliations: Institute of Meteorology and Water Management, Branch Krakow, Bratkow 10, 40 045 Katowice, Poland; Silesian University, Institute of Mathematics, Bankowa 14, 40 007 Katowice, Poland; Polish Academy of Science, Institute of Environmental Engineering, M. Sklodowskiej-Curie 34, 41 819 Zabrze, Poland; Medical University of Silesia, Department of Epidemiology, Medykow 18, 40 752 Katowice, Poland
Authors with affiliations: Osrodka, L., Institute of Meteorology and Water Management, Branch Krakow, Bratkow 10, 40 045 Katowice, Poland; Wojtylak, M., Silesian University, Institute of Mathematics, Bankowa 14, 40 007 Katowice, Poland; Krajny, E., Institute of Meteorology and Water Management, Branch Krakow, Bratkow 10, 40 045 Katowice, Poland; Klejnowski, K., Polish Academy of Science, Institute of Environmental Engineering, M. Sklodowskiej-Curie 34, 41 819 Zabrze, Poland; Kowalska, M., Medical University of Silesia, Department of Epidemiology, Medykow 18, 40 752 Katowice, Poland
Abstract: The paper presents an attempt to analyze the influence of meteorological factors on emergency-level episodes of high concentrations of particulate matter in border region Polish and Czech Republic for the common city Cieszyn/Cesky Tesin. The study analyzed the principal causes of air pollution and identified the best subset of features: meteorological data and air pollutants concentration, in order to predict its short-range concentration. The data comes from data acquisition stations belonging to Automatic Monitoring of Air Quality and installed in the both Cieszyn and Cesky Tesin. The emergence of high concentrations of air pollutants depends on a number of meteorological factors as well as on dispersion parameters like thermodynamic stability or the mixing layer and environmental conditions. The relation between weather conditions and levels of air pollutants are nonlinear and usual descriptive statistics might be unreliable. The system analyzes the data using data mining as artificial neural networks, including a self-organizing Kohonen network with exhaustion and fuzzy sets. The system creates the forecast using the Fuzzy Case Base Reason method. In addition to the data acquisition stations, data is input from the results of the numeric weather forecast. The forecast includes hourly calculated prediction values of the concentration PMIO.The final aim of the research is the implementation of a prognostic tool able to reduce the risk for the air pollution concentrations to be above the alarm thresholds fixed by the law (COM 447 2005).

Title: Designing today's CleanTech research facility: Sustainable, highly technical architectural and engineering design applied to the new york state Alternative Fuel Vehicle Research Laboratory (AFVRL)
Source title: 2007 NSTI Nanotechnology Conference and Trade Show - NSTI Nanotech 2007, Technical Proceedings
Affiliations: Flad and Associates, 644 Science Drive, Madison, WI; Affiliated Engineers, Inc., 5802 Research Park Boulevard, Madison, WI
Authors with affiliations: Ostafi, J., Flad and Associates, 644 Science Drive, Madison, WI; Sereno, D.F., Affiliated Engineers, Inc., 5802 Research Park Boulevard, Madison, WI
Abstract: The greatest challenges facing our world today are the need to reduce the pollutants entering our atmosphere AND the need to create fuels that can support our expanding global economies. The opportunity to support cutting-edge research on both challenges in one facility is truly inspiring. That is the basic premise behind the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation's Alternative Fuel Vehicle Research Laboratory (AFVRL). The creation of working environments to support complex science while mitigating the impact of the facility on the natural environment has never been as important as it is today. The challenge of designing a laboratory for the science of fuels optimization and emissions reduction, while reducing overall energy consumption has yielded results surpassing the goals of the State of New York, setting them on a path to a ground-breaking new science facility.

Title: Synthesis and photoinduced intramolecular processes of fulleropyrrolidine- oligothienylenevinylene-ferrocene triads

Abstract: Two new triads based on N-methylfulleropyrolidine, oligothienylenevinylenes (nTV) and ferrocene (Fc), namely C60-nTV-Fc (n = 2, 4) have been synthesized. A HOMOLUMO gap as low as 1.09-1.11 eV was experimentally determined by cyclic voltammetry. In both polar and nonpolar solvents, photoinduced charge-separation (CS) processes in C60-nTV-Fc predominantly take place from the singlet excited states of C60 and nTV; this result was indicated by steady and time-resolved emission spectroscopy. In the case of C60-4TV-Fc, the CS state was indicated by the nanosecond transient absorption spectra. In C60-2TV-Fc, although the CS process was also confirmed by the fluorescence quenching in nonpolar and polar solvents, the lifetimes of the CS states were shorter than those of C60-4TV-Fc. It was revealed that the introduction of Fc donor moiety at the end of the longer nTV chain in the C60-nTV dyad systems effectively increases the CS efficiency and the lifetimes of CS states. © 2007 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA.

Authors: Ouchida Y.
Title: Emission tax policy, relocation of polluting firms and pollution abatement investment
Affiliations: Department of Economics, Hiroshima University, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Ouchida, Y., Department of Economics, Hiroshima University, Japan
Abstract: Some developing countries have an incentive to relax environmental regulation in order to attract foreign direct investments. These so called “pollution havens” tempt relocation of firms from developed countries that have strict environmental regulations. The governments of developed countries must take this into consideration when they design domestic environmental policies. In this paper, I examine the emission tax policy for Cournot duopolists that relocate to another country with no emission tax. Introduction of a strategic emission tax for interruption of relocation to a “pollution haven” was found effective. However, there is still the possibility that duopolists in developed countries will relocate abroad even if the regulator precommits the emission tax rate. As pointed out by Petrakis and Xepapadeas [2003], the regulator faces a regulatory hold-up problem when the set-up cost of relocation is sufficiently low and environmental damage is serious. Therefore, adoption of an emission tax should only occur when the set-up costs are sufficiently large. © 2007, JAPAN SECTION OF THE REGIONAL SCIENCE ASSOCIATION INTERNATIONAL. All rights reserved.

Authors: Oudijk G.
Title: Compound-specific stable carbon isotope analysis of MTBE in groundwater contamination fingerprinting studies: Assessing weathering, source modes, and differentiating plumes
Source title: Battelle Press - 9th International In Situ and On-Site Bioremediation Symposium 2007
Affiliations: Triassic Technology, Inc., Hopewell, NJ, United States
Authors with affiliations: Oudijk, G., Triassic Technology, Inc., Hopewell, NJ, United States
Abstract: Methyl-tert-butyl ether (MTBE) is an oxygenate added to gasoline in the United States and elsewhere to boost the octane ratio and reduce tailpipe emissions. Because of its known usage time frame, the presence of MTBE can help estimate the age of gasoline releases to the environment. However, because of its 'ubiquity, its presence can no longer be used to fingerprint, or differentiate, gasoline plumes in groundwater. Compound- specific stable carbon isotope analysis has recently become a method for differentiating MTBE sources and plumes affecting groundwater. In the present study, groundwater samples were collected from 20 monitoring wells located at two gasoline service stations in central New Jersey in an attempt to differentiate the dissolved gasoline plumes and possibly identify their sources. The δ13C values for each sample were determined and the impacted area for each plume delineated. As biological degradation of MTBE proceeds, the carbon isotope ratio (13C/12C expressed as δ13C) become heavier; petroleum- degrading bacteria preferentially assimilate the lighter 12C isotope, thereby enriching the residual MTBE in the heavier 13C isotope. The isotopic composition of MTBE at different locations demonstrated the varying degree to which MTBE had been altered by biodegradation. The δ13C values can also provide insight into the type of release and the magnitude of biodegradation. Two types of leaks occurred at the sites: a shallow piping leak and deeper leak from a tank system. δ13C values in the vicinity of the shallow leak were heavier revealing increased biodegradation in the soil, while δ13C values in the vicinity of the tank leak were lighter revealing the lack of biological degradation in non- aqueous phase liquid (NAPL) trapped beneath the water table. An assessment is provided where physical site characteristics responsible for petroleum weathering are considered in comparison to the calculated δ13C values.

Authors: Ouhl J., Happ K.
Title: Building the world's largest kiln line
Source title: 2007 IEEE Cement Industry Technical Conference Record
Affiliations: Ste. Genevieve Plant, Holcim (US) Inc., United States; Pyroprocessing, FLSmidth Inc.
Authors with affiliations: Ouhl, J., Ste. Genevieve Plant, Holcim (US) Inc., United States; Happ, K., Pyroprocessing, FLSmidth Inc.
Abstract: The average clinker production plant size has been steadily increasing over the years, and now construction has begun on what will be the largest single clinker production line in the world. At 12,000 metric tons per day clinker and 4 million metric tons annual cement capacity, this massive greenfield plant is being built by Holcim in the United States along the Mississippi River in Ste. Genevieve County, Missouri. The uniqueness of this undertaking is not only the size, but also the strict efficiency goals and environmental regulations that will apply to the site development, construction, and operation. Preliminary evaluation of the Ste. Genevieve project began in the late 1990's, and Holcim ultimately underwent a six year process of reviews and permits involving eight federal and state regulatory agencies. With all permits finally in hand, Holcim awarded a contract in early 2006 to one supplier for all the main and auxiliary mechanical and electrical equipment as well as engineering services, training, and commissioning The focal point of the plant will be the single pyroprocess system with new generation clinker cooler and in-line preheater with low NO x and CO calciner. Furthermore, the supply of four (4) vertical roller mills has also reinforced this solution as the market standard for finish cement grinding. Because the plant will meet emission limits among the lowest permitted for any cement plant in the United States and the world, any environmental impact will be minimized. In addition, approximately 2200 acres (55% of the total property's acreage) will be preserved in its natural condition for the entire life of the plant. The success of the Ste. Genevieve project is based on the strong partnership and open relationship that has been developed between Holcim and the supplier. Start-up of the plant is scheduled for 2009. With a foundation of a sound technical solution and combined worldwide resources, this extraordinary project will no doubt be a source of pride for all parties involved. © 2007 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Clinker production; Electrical equipment; Kiln line; Site development; Cements; Environmental regulations; Plant management; Production control; Project management; Kilns

Authors: Oumejjoud K., Stuttaford P.J.
Title: Combustion instabilities and damping effectiveness evaluation on test rigs and gas turbine engines
Source title: Proceedings of the ASME Turbo Expo
Affiliations: Power Systems Mfg, 1440 West Indiantown Rd, Jupiter, FL 33458, United States
Authors with affiliations: Oumejjoud, K., Power Systems Mfg, 1440 West Indiantown Rd, Jupiter, FL 33458, United States; Stuttaford, P.J., Power Systems Mfg, 1440 West Indiantown Rd, Jupiter, FL 33458, United States
Abstract: Power generation companies have turned to gas turbines as a means to meet the stringent emission requirements set by regulation. The boundary between low emissions and an unstable combustor are narrower than ever. Hence, combustion instabilities have become a major design challenge as combustors are developed to run as lean as possible in order to achieve stringent emissions targets. These combustion instabilities can limit the operational envelope of the machine and are often responsible for damage to the gas turbine. Thus, preventing or controlling such conditions is the main focus of the design community. In order to lower the risk associated with combustion instabilities issues, a proper understanding of the design and acoustics of the combustion system has to be acquired early in the development stage. A damping strategy should be developed to mitigate risk in the event of unacceptably high dynamics. Combustion rig testing is crucial to a new combustor development program. Matching the acoustic environment of the combustion rig and the engine provide valuable insight into future potential combustion dynamics problems in the engine and provides valuable data to assist troubleshooting such issues on the engine. This work illustrates the ability of rig testing to be a valuable design and optimization tool in addressing combustion dynamics. Rig test data was used to successfully optimize subsequent engine combustion dynamics. The effectiveness of a damping system is also illustrated on the combustion test rig. Copyright © 2007 by ASME.
Index Keywords: Combustion dynamics; Combustion instabilities; Damping effectiveness; Combustion; Damping; Gas emissions; Gas turbines; Power generation; Internal combustion engines

Authors: Oxizidis S., Dudek A.V., Aquilina N.
Title: Typical weather years and the effect of urban microclimate on the energy behaviour of buildings and HVAC systems
Affiliations: Laboratory of Heat Transfer and Environmental Engineering, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, Greece; Norwegian Institute for Air research, Kjeller, Norway; School of Geography, Earth & Environmental Sciences, University of Birmingham, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Oxizidis, S., Laboratory of Heat Transfer and Environmental Engineering, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, Greece; Dudek, A.V., Norwegian Institute for Air research, Kjeller, Norway; Aquilina, N., School of Geography, Earth & Environmental Sciences, University of Birmingham, United Kingdom
Abstract: Building simulation programs require climate information in the form of hourly based typical weather years assembled from meteorological measurements. A thorough description of these weather data sets is presented in this paper followed by a classification based on the way they are derived from monitored data and a comparison between the different types. Finally, we analyse the efforts made to deliver urban specific climatic data to assess the effect of urban microclimate on buildings. © 2007 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Development of master plan 2007-2020 for air pollution reduction in ulaanbaatar city
Source title: 2007 International Forum on Strategic Technology, IFOST
Affiliations: Risk Study Center, NGO, Germany; Mongolian University Science and Technology, Mongolia; Institute ofPublic Health; Air Quality Bureau ofUlaanbaatar city
Authors with affiliations: Oyun, R., Risk Study Center, NGO, Germany; Jargalkhuu, L., Mongolian University Science and Technology, Mongolia; Saijaa, N., Institute ofPublic Health; Tugjsuren, N., Mongolian University Science and Technology, Mongolia; B.Mendbayar, Risk Study Center, NGO, Germany; Sanchir, I., Risk Study Center, NGO, Germany; Zoljargal, M., Air Quality Bureau ofUlaanbaatar city; Khaliunaa, B., Risk Study Center, NGO, Germany
Abstract: Dramatically - increasing and high concentrate air pollution of Ulaanbaatar city is a top issue that requires urgent and efficient solution. Master plan for reduction of air pollution is a strategy of Ulaanbaatar municipality towards achieve better air quality by saving energy, implementing clean technology, improving legislation, policy documents nd management at all levels ofgovernance, developing public and private partnership, and building capacity of residents. This paper introduces content of Master Plan, concepts followed and methodologies used for its development, and some outputs of the study. The plan is result of collaborative work of central and local government officials, researchers, professionals, engineers, and community and business representatives. © 2007 IEEE.

Authors: Ozdural P., Akyurtlu J.F., Erten-Unal M., Akyurtlu A.
Title: Catalytic wet air oxidation of orange II - Finding an efficient catalyst
Affiliations: Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, Old Dominion University, Norfolk, VA, United States; Chemical Engineering Department, Hampton University, Hampton, VA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ozdural, P., Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, Old Dominion University, Norfolk, VA, United States; Akyurtlu, J.F., Chemical Engineering Department, Hampton University, Hampton, VA, United States; Erten-Unal, M., Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, Old Dominion University, Norfolk, VA, United States; Akyurtlu, A., Chemical Engineering Department, Hampton University, Hampton, VA, United States
Abstract: Industrial wastewaters usually contain high concentrations of organic substances that have to be treated before being discharged into a municipal sewer system or the receiving water body. Different processes exist for the pretreatment of industrial wastewaters, depending on the composition and strength of the wastewater. Among the available pre-treatment technologies, catalytic wet air oxidation (CWAO) is a suitable technology for treatment of wastewaters containing high levels of refractory organic compounds that are not amenable to biological treatment, either as a complete treatment system by itself, or as a pre-treatment before biological treatment. Compared to conventional wet air oxidation, catalytic wet air oxidation offers lower energy requirements and much higher oxidation efficiencies [1]. Effluents from dying baths in textile industry are one of the most problematic types of wastewater generated by the textile industry. These types of wastewaters have very strong color and high COD concentrations, and impose serious environmental problems, both in terms of treatment and aesthetic concerns. Orange II (also known as Acid Orange 7) is one of the dyes that are produced in large amounts in the United States. It is commonly used in pharmaceutical, food, and cosmetics industries as well as in the textile industry, and it is not amenable to conventional biological treatment. This paper discusses the selection of an efficient catalyst for the catalytic oxidation of Orange II. The experiments were conducted in a one-liter batch stainless steel autoclave reactor, which is equipped with a stirrer, temperature and pressure controllers, gas introduction and vent lines, and a sampling port. Half-factorial experimental design was utilized to design the experiments to screen the catalysts. Total Organic Carbon (TOC) reduction is used as the primary parameter to determine the treatment efficiency. Color reduction is also measured. The results are discussed.
Author Keywords: Azo dyes; Catalytic wet air oxidation; Orange II; Textile wastewaters

Authors: Özsayin E., Dirik K.
Title: Quaternary activity of the Cihanbeyli and Yeniceoba fault zones: İnönü-Eskişehir fault system, Central Anatolia
Affiliations: Hacettepe University, Department of Geological Engineering, Tectonic Research Laboratory, TR-06800 Ankara, Turkey
Authors with affiliations: Özsayin, E., Hacettepe University, Department of Geological Engineering, Tectonic Research Laboratory, TR-06800 Ankara, Turkey; Dirik, K., Hacettepe University, Department of Geological Engineering, Tectonic Research Laboratory, TR-06800 Ankara, Turkey
Abstract: The Inönü-Eskişehir fault system (IEFS) is one of the most important fault systems in Central Anatolia and consists of a series of NW-SE- to WNW-ESE-trending fault zones extending from Uludaǧ (Bursa) in the northwest to Sultanhani in the southeast. Between İnönü and Sivrihisar, the Eskişehir fault zone of the IEFS trends WNW, but east of Sivrihisar the IEFS changes its direction to NW-SE and splays out into four fault zones, named the Ilica, Yeniceoba, Cihanbeyli and Sultanhani fault zones and extends to south of Tuzgölü in the east. The NW-SE-trending Yeniceoba fault zone (YFZ), exposed between Günyüzü in the west and Yeniceoba in the east, controls the northern margin of the Kelhasan horst and the southern margin of the Yeniceoba basin. Along this fault zone two sets of superimposed slickenlines indicate older pure right-lateral strike-slip faulting and younger normal faulting with a right-lateral component. The NW-SE-trending Cihanbeyli fault zone (CFZ) is well exposed between north of Sülüklü in the west and Cihanbeyli in the east. It controls the southern margin of the Kelhasan horst, and is marked by fault scarps, triangular facets, alluvial fans and alignment of springs. Recent detailed field mapping and kinematic analysis along the fault planes between Pliocene lacustrine carbonates and younger fluvial clastic rocks has shown that the CFZ consists of a series of parallel normal faults. However, kinematic analysis of the fault slip-plane data indicates that the fault planes cutting the Pleistocene-Holocene clastic sediments of the Cihanbeyli Graben at the southeastern tip of the CFZ are normal faults with a minor sinistral component. The kinematic analyses of fault-slip data clearly indicate that the area experienced NNE-SSW extension. Recent horizontal terrace deposits cut by a series of steeply-dipping normal faults with minor strike-slip component in l̇lhanyayla, Damlakuyu, (Çorca) village and nearly 4 kilometres southeast of Insuyu village, which are located on the YFZ and CFZ, indicate that the activity of both CFZ and YFZ continues, controlled by NNE-SSE-directed extension, in the Quaternary. The distribution of earthquake epicentres supports this view and suggests recent activity along the fault zones. Copyright © TÜBİTAK.
Author Keywords: Central Anatolia; Cihanbeyli fault zone; Inönü-Eskişehir fault system; Kinematic analysis; Neotectonic; Quaternary activity; Tuzgölü; Yeniceoba fault zone
Index Keywords: fault plane; fault zone; faulting; kinematics; neotectonics; Quaternary; Anatolia; Eurasia; Turkey

Authors: Paehlke R., Ross N.
Title: Greening politics
Authors with affiliations: Paehlke, R.; Ross, N.
Abstract: Canadian leaders strut their colors on the political stage. Bishop for the environment John Baird, after demolishing most of the country's climate change programs and announcing that Canada had no intention of meeting its Kyoto targets, is now proposing tough new legislation and say's he is now ready to work with other parties to consider ideas to improve the legislation. Another, Stephane Dion, who was environment minister when the Liberals were in power, has seen his climate change initiatives inefective, shown in higher emissions rather than lower. Questions now arise as to how his recent announcement to go further with his Project Green is still good news. Another is Jack Layton. Although he is among a growing group requesting a moratorium on oil sands development, he believes that Canada can still meet its Kyoto goals, though on a monumental feat. Another, Elizabeth May, says her party will implement a carbon tax and offset it by reducing taxation on societal goods such as payroll and income. Her approach includes carbon taxes, regulations, emissions trading and voluntary programs. Another is Bernard Bigras, whose party is focused on Quebec. The province has already committed to meet the Kyoto target even if the nation does not.
Index Keywords: climate change; emissions trading; Kyoto Protocol; politics; pollution tax; Canada; North America

Authors: Pagano T.S., Chahine M.T., Aumann H.H., Broberg S.E.
Title: Advanced Remote-sensing Imaging Emission Spectrometer (ARIES): An instrument concept for a next-generation imager/sounder
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: California Institute of Technology, Jet Propulsion Laboratory, Pasadena, CA 91109, United States
Authors with affiliations: Pagano, T.S., California Institute of Technology, Jet Propulsion Laboratory, Pasadena, CA 91109, United States; Chahine, M.T., California Institute of Technology, Jet Propulsion Laboratory, Pasadena, CA 91109, United States; Aumann, H.H., California Institute of Technology, Jet Propulsion Laboratory, Pasadena, CA 91109, United States; Broberg, S.E., California Institute of Technology, Jet Propulsion Laboratory, Pasadena, CA 91109, United States
Abstract: It is now possible to combine high spectral resolution observations (like AIRS) with moderate spatial resolution (like MODIS) in a single instrument. The ARIES instrument concept provides over 3000 spectral channels in the 0.4 - 15.4 μm spectral region with spatial resolution of 1.0 km while still scanning ±55°. The ARIES has size and mass less than half that of AIRS or MODIS primarily due to the advancements in focal plane assemblies and wide field optical systems developed under the NASA IIP and in US industry. The combined capability will allow more cloud free observations per unit area, and improve the overall cloud-clearing approach applied on AIRS. It will also improve sensitivity to atmospheric water vapor, temperature and trace gases in the boundary layer and facilitate studies of surface and atmospheric interaction for global climate studies. Improvements are expected in regional weather forecasts and hurricane prediction. This paper discusses the primary requirements for ARIES, the expected science and operational benefits and an instrument concept that demonstrates the viability and low risk of the approach.
Author Keywords: AIRS; ARIES; Atmospheric sounding; Hyperspectral; Infrared; Sounder
Index Keywords: AIRS; ARIES; Atmospheric sounding; Sounders; Image sensors; Imaging systems; Optical resolving power; Optical systems; Remote sensing; Spectrum analysis; Infrared spectrometers

Authors: Paine R.J., Connors J.A., Kaplan M.M.
Title: Regional challenges with permitting of new coal-fired facilities: PSD increment and regional haze issues
Source title: Air and Waste Management Association - Guideline on Air Quality Models: Applications and FLAG Developments 2006, An A andWMA Specialty Conference
Affiliations: ENSR Corporation, 2 Technology Park Drive, Westford, MA 01886, United States
Authors with affiliations: Paine, R.J., ENSR Corporation, 2 Technology Park Drive, Westford, MA 01886, United States; Connors, J.A., ENSR Corporation, 2 Technology Park Drive, Westford, MA 01886, United States; Kaplan, M.M., ENSR Corporation, 2 Technology Park Drive, Westford, MA 01886, United States
Abstract: Projections1 for future electrical generating needs in the West indicate a requirement for an additional 7500 MW of coal-fired generation by the year 2018. Emissions from new coal-fired facilities have never been lower, but the permitting challenges for these facilities have never been so numerous. Two primary issues to be dealt with for regulatory review are PSD increment consumption and regional haze modeling in Class I areas. At the same time, with numerous projects of voluntary flue gas desulfurization installations and the implementation of the Best Available Retrofit Technology (BART) program, the number of emission reduction projects for SO2 is noteworthy, and this issue needs to be taken into account in the consideration of new project permitting evaluations. This paper reviews permitting issues dealt with on a variety of recent power plant permitting efforts with the Federal Land Managers on PSD increment and regional haze modeling. Among the issues discussed in the paper are: 1) Modeling procedures and emission rates used in PSD increment consumption calculations, 2) Whether CALPUFF is adequate for the task of regional haze impact calculations, 3) Adequacy of meteorological databases, 4) Visibility postprocessing methods, especially alternatives to FLAG, such as the BART approach, and 5) Consideration of techniques used in a cumulative regional haze modeling analysis.
Author Keywords: CALPUFF; Coal-fired power plants; Federal land manager; FLAG; PSD class I; Regional haze; Visibility assessment

Authors: Paine R.J.
Title: Status report: Regional Haze BART Rule implementation
Source title: 100th Annual Conference and Exhibition of the Air and Waste Management Association 2007, ACE 2007
Affiliations: ENSR Corporation, 2 Technology Park Drive, Westford, MA  01886, United States
Authors with affiliations: Paine, R.J., ENSR Corporation, 2 Technology Park Drive, Westford, MA  01886, United States
Abstract: EPA finalized the Regional Haze Rule (RHR) Best Available Retrofit Technology (BART) guidelines on June 15, 2005, requiring older individual stationary sources in 26 industrial categories put into operation between 1962 and 1977 to be evaluated for installation of emission controls. States have until December 2007 to conduct the BART analyses and also determine whether the BART and other emission reductions will be sufficient to meet the reasonable progress goals of the RHR. Any BART-eligible source that is "reasonably anticipated to cause or contribute" to regional haze in any of the 156 Prevention of Significant Deterioration (PSD) Class I areas in 36 states and territories will be subject to BART, which must be installed and operating in the 2014-2015 time frame. The paper reviews various aspects of the rule's implementation, including the alternative trading provisions. The author discusses experience to date, gleaned collectively from a number of active projects for industrial facilities, as it pertains to both source-specific and statewide or regional assessments of visibility impacts for the BART analyses. There is also a discussion of the assessment of reasonable progress and the likelihood that the BART emission reductions will result in reasonable further progress toward the RHR goal of natural conditions by the first milestone in 2018. The paper also briefly addresses the issue of permitting new sources and the interaction of that program with the BART and the RHR programs.
Author Keywords: BART; CALPUFF; Federal land manager; PSD class I; Regional haze; Visibility assessment
Index Keywords: Emission control; Industrial emissions; Visibility; BART; Calpuff; Federal Land Manager; PSD Class I; Regional haze; Visibility assessment; Waste management

Authors: Pais A., Banerjee A., Bandi D.K., Klotzkin D., Papautsky I.
Title: High sensitivity on-chip fluorescence detection based on cross-polarization and thin-film organic photodetectors
Source title: TRANSDUCERS and EUROSENSORS '07 - 4th International Conference on Solid-State Sensors, Actuators and Microsystems
Affiliations: Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Cincinnati, Cincinnati, United States
Authors with affiliations: Pais, A., Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Cincinnati, Cincinnati, United States; Banerjee, A., Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Cincinnati, Cincinnati, United States; Bandi, D.K., Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Cincinnati, Cincinnati, United States; Klotzkin, D., Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Cincinnati, Cincinnati, United States; Papautsky, I., Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Cincinnati, Cincinnati, United States
Abstract: In this paper we present a novel, high-sensitivity, cost-effective cross-polarization scheme to filter out excitation light from a fluorescent dye emission spectrum. With this scheme, it is possible to achieve a detection limit of 10 nM which is a 1,000 fold reduction from previously published results. The concept is demonstrated using an inverted microscope with a halide lamp as the excitation source and an organic photodiode as the intensity detector. The excitation light is linearly polarized and used to illuminate a microfluidic device containing 1 μL of Rhodamine 6G dye dissolved in ethanol. The detector is shielded by a second polarizer, orientated orthogonally to the excitation light. The resulting emission signal was detected by the organic photodiode down to a concentration of 10 nM. This scheme opens the possibility to fabricating integrated microfluidic devices with fluorescence detection, suitable for point-of-care (POC) diagnostics, biomedical and environmental applications. ©2007 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Fluorescence; Microfluidics; On-chip; Optical detection; Organic photodiode; Polarizers

Authors: Pakou C., Fountoulakis M., Drillia P., Kampioti A., Stamatelatou K., Lyberatos G.
Title: Occurrence and fate of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons in sewage treatment plants using microwave-assisted extraction followed by liquid chromatography coupled with fluorescence detector
Affiliations: Laboratory of Biochemical Engineering and Environmental Technology, Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Patras, Karatheodori st. 1, 26500 Patras, Greece; Department of Ecology and the Environment, Technological Education Institute (TEI) of the Ionian Islands, Kalvos Sq. 2, 29100 Zakynthos, Greece; Institute of Chemical Engineering and High Temperature Chemical Processes, 26504 Patras, Greece
Authors with affiliations: Pakou, C., Laboratory of Biochemical Engineering and Environmental Technology, Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Patras, Karatheodori st. 1, 26500 Patras, Greece; Fountoulakis, M., Laboratory of Biochemical Engineering and Environmental Technology, Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Patras, Karatheodori st. 1, 26500 Patras, Greece; Drillia, P., Laboratory of Biochemical Engineering and Environmental Technology, Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Patras, Karatheodori st. 1, 26500 Patras, Greece; Kampioti, A., Laboratory of Biochemical Engineering and Environmental Technology, Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Patras, Karatheodori st. 1, 26500 Patras, Greece, Department of Ecology and the Environment, Technological Education Institute (TEI) of the Ionian Islands, Kalvos Sq. 2, 29100 Zakynthos, Greece; Stamatelatou, K., Laboratory of Biochemical Engineering and Environmental Technology, Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Patras, Karatheodori st. 1, 26500 Patras, Greece; Lyberatos, G., Laboratory of Biochemical Engineering and Environmental Technology, Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Patras, Karatheodori st. 1, 26500 Patras, Greece, Institute of Chemical Engineering and High Temperature Chemical Processes, 26504 Patras, Greece
Abstract: Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) are highly persistent compounds in the environment, recalcitrant to biodegradation and highly lipophilic, while some of them cause acute carcinogenic and mutagenic toxicity. Due to the risk of soil contamination whenever sewage sludge is disposed to agricultural land, the investigation of their presence in sewage sludge is a priority need. This work concerns the occurrence of five PAHs, selected from the priority list of the US Environmental Protection Agency (phenanthrene, fluoranthene, pyrene, benzo[b]flouranthene, and benzo[a]pyrene), in municipal sewage sludge and to assess their fate in a sewage treatment plant. An analytical method based on microwave-assisted extraction (MAE), followed by HPLC-UV coupled with a fluorescent detector (FD) was used for their measurement. The method efficiency was evaluated as to its linearity, repeatability, accuracy and sensitivity. The contamination levels of the PAHs were determined in sludge from the sewage treatment plants of three main Greek cities: Athens, Patras and Heraklion. PAHs ranged from 0.2 to 4 mg kg-1 d.m for each PAH in mixtures of primary and secondary sludge, while they were significantly lower in secondary sludge (less than 0.1 mg kg-1 d.m). © by PSP 2007.

Authors: Pal S., Ozanyan K.B., McCann H.
Title: An approach to detect carbon monoxide in combustion exhaust using mid-infrared techniques
Source title: 5th World Congress in Industrial Process Tomography
Affiliations: School of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, University of Manchester, Manchester, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Pal, S., School of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, University of Manchester, Manchester, United Kingdom; Ozanyan, K.B., School of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, University of Manchester, Manchester, United Kingdom; McCann, H., School of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, University of Manchester, Manchester, United Kingdom
Abstract: Various groups have attempted single channel multi-pass or long path-length measurement of CO using mid-infrared (MIR) techniques. Single-pass short path-length measurement is being assessed in our work for tomographic measurement of the distribution of different minor species in the exhaust of combustion systems. We report here the spectroscopic study of CO in different absorption lines of strong fundamental bands in the mid-IR range. Criteria for the selection of light sources in this context are also reported.Although strong spectral lines are available for CO in the mid-infrared region, strong water vapour and carbon dioxide interferences are also present. This work addresses the interference issues of major species present in the target combustion gas. The HITRAN 2004 database is used to predict the spectral lines of H2O and CO2 overlapping the fundamental spectrum of CO in the mid-IR range. The exhaust condition in respect of temperature and pressure is considered in order to study the broadening of the spectral lines. The Voigt profile is introduced to combine Doppler Broadening and Collisional Broadening to reflect both pressure and temperature effects. The percentages of absorption for different species and for different types of source are reported on the basis of computations. The optimum beam arrangement is discussed and a representative reconstruction with a three fan-beam arrangement is presented. © 2007, International Society for Industrial Process Tomography. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Combustion; Phantom; Spectroscopy; Tomography; Transimpedance
Index Keywords: Absorption spectroscopy; Carbon; Carbon dioxide; Carbon monoxide; Infrared devices; Light sources; Spectroscopic analysis; Spectroscopy; Tomography; Collisional broadening; Mid-infrared regions; Phantom; Pressure and temperature; Spectral lines of h; Spectroscopic studies; Temperature and pressures; Transimpedance; Combustion

Authors: Pandini D., Repetto G.A., Sinisi V.
Title: Clock distribution techniques for low-EMI design
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Central CAD, Design Solutions, STMicroelectronics, Agrate Brianza, 20041, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Pandini, D., Central CAD, Design Solutions, STMicroelectronics, Agrate Brianza, 20041, Italy; Repetto, G.A., Central CAD, Design Solutions, STMicroelectronics, Agrate Brianza, 20041, Italy; Sinisi, V., Central CAD, Design Solutions, STMicroelectronics, Agrate Brianza, 20041, Italy
Abstract: In modern digital ICs, the increasing demand for performance and throughput requires higher operating frequencies of hundreds of megahertz, and in several cases exceeding the gigahertz range. Following the technology scaling trends, this request will continue to rise, thus increasing the electromagnetic interference (EMI) generated by electronic systems. The enforcement of strict governmental regulations and international standards, mainly (but not only) in the automotive domain, are driving new efforts towards design solutions for electromagnetic compatibility (EMC). Hence, EMC/EMI is rapidly becoming a major concern for high-speed circuit and package designers. The on-chip clock signals with fast rise/fall times are among the most detrimental sources of electromagnetic (EM) noise, since not only they generate radiated emissions, but they also have a large impact con the conducted emissions, as the power rail noise localized in close proximity of the toggling clock edges propagates to the board through the power and ground pins. In this work, we analyze the impact of different clock distribution solutions on the spectral content of typical onchip waveforms, in order to develop an effective methodology for EMC-aware clock-tree synthesis, which globally reduces the EM emissions. Our approach can be seamlessly integrated into a typical design flow, and its effectiveness is demonstrated with experimental results obtained from the clock distribution network of an industrial digital design. © Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg 2007.
Index Keywords: Automobile electronic equipment; Clock distribution networks; Digital integrated circuits; Electric clocks; Electromagnetic pulse; Clock distribution; Clock distribution techniques; Clock tree synthesis; Conducted emissions; Electronic systems; Governmental regulations; International standards; Operating frequency; Electromagnetic compatibility

Authors: Panek L., Schönwald N., Thiele F., Dumbser M., Munz C.-D.
Title: Comparison of numerical approaches for the simulation of sound radiation from a scarfed inlet
Source title: 14th International Congress on Sound and Vibration 2007, ICSV 2007
Affiliations: Institute of Fluid Mechanics and Engineering Acoustics, Berlin University of Technology, D-10623 Berlin, Germany; Institut für Aerodynamik und Gasdynamik, Universität Stuttgart, Stuttgart, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Panek, L., Institute of Fluid Mechanics and Engineering Acoustics, Berlin University of Technology, D-10623 Berlin, Germany; Schönwald, N., Institute of Fluid Mechanics and Engineering Acoustics, Berlin University of Technology, D-10623 Berlin, Germany; Thiele, F., Institute of Fluid Mechanics and Engineering Acoustics, Berlin University of Technology, D-10623 Berlin, Germany; Dumbser, M., Institut für Aerodynamik und Gasdynamik, Universität Stuttgart, Stuttgart, Germany; Munz, C.-D., Institut für Aerodynamik und Gasdynamik, Universität Stuttgart, Stuttgart, Germany
Abstract: In recent decades great effort has been made to reduce the noise emission of aero-engines. Due to increasing bypass ratios the fan area in aero-engines has become larger. This development is advantageous for the efficiency and the reduction of jet noise, however, it relocates the noise problem to the engine intake. In the presented work two different numerical approaches for solving the linearised Euler equations (LEE) will be compared. Their application to the case of sound propagation in the JT15D aero-engine intake will be presented. The fist method, also called the Chimera-technique, is based on overlapping structured grids which exchange data using high order interpolation. It employs the well-known high order Dispersion Relation Preserving scheme (DRP) for the spatial discretisation and an optimised Runge-Kutta Method for temporal integration. The second method is based on unstructured tetrahedral meshes and uses a new version of explicit one-step Discontinuous Galerkin (DG) Finite Element schemes allowing for arbitrary high order of accuracy in space and time as well as for time accurate local time stepping (LTS). Both high order methods are optimised for sound propagation and are capable of simulating complex geometries such as a scarfed nacelle intake including the spinner. The first objective of this work is to gain insight into the acoustic far field characteristics of an intake in the presence of a realistic mean flow. Furthermore, the influence of an asymmetrical shape of the inlet mouth will be studied. The second objective is to compare the different numerical methods with respect to their accuracy and computational efficiency, this being a major criterion for industrial application.
Index Keywords: Complex geometries; Discontinuous galerkin; Finite element schemes; High-order dispersion; Local time stepping; Numerical approaches; Temporal integration; Unstructured tetrahedral meshes; Acoustic noise; Aircraft engines; Dispersions; Galerkin methods; Industrial applications; Noise pollution; Runge Kutta methods; Acoustic wave propagation

Authors: Pannirselvam N., Murugappan A., Arulmozhi R.
Title: Impact of emissions of CO2 from thermal power plants on climate - A case study
Affiliations: Mailam Engineering College, Mailam, T.N., India; Dept. of Civil Engineering, Annamalai University, Annamalainagar 608 002 T.N., India
Authors with affiliations: Pannirselvam, N., Mailam Engineering College, Mailam, T.N., India; Murugappan, A., Dept. of Civil Engineering, Annamalai University, Annamalainagar 608 002 T.N., India; Arulmozhi, R., Dept. of Civil Engineering, Annamalai University, Annamalainagar 608 002 T.N., India
Abstract: This paper aims at studying the impact of the continuous burning of lignite in the Thermal Power Plants of Neyveli Lignite Corporation Limited, Tamilnadu State, on the climatic conditions in the surrounding regions. Due to the burning of huge quantity of lignite in the thermal power plants of Neyveli Lignite Corporation Limited, huge emissions of CO2 are let into the atmosphere. The impact of the huge and continuous emissions of CO2 on the climatic conditions in the areas within 50 km radii around Neyveli is assessed. The increase in average annual temperature and decrease in rainfall in the locations surrounding the Neyveli Lignite Corporation Limited are an indication of the occurrence of Greenhouse effect. Author Keywords: Climate; Emissions of CO2; Thermal power plants
Index Keywords: carbon dioxide; climate change; climate conditions; climate effect; emission control; greenhouse effect; lignite; power plant; thermal power; Asia; Eurasia; India; South Asia; Tamil Nadu

Zatsepin, V.I., Skobeltsyn Institute of Nuclear Physics, Moscow State University, Moscow, Russian Federation
Abstract: The ATIC balloon-borne experiment measures the energy spectra of elements from H to Fe in primary cosmic rays from about 100 GeV to 100 TeV. ATIC is comprised of a fully active bismuth germanate calorimeter, a carbon target with embedded scintillator hodoscopes, and a silicon matrix that is used as the main charge detector. The silicon matrix produces good charge resolution for protons and helium but only partial resolution for heavier nuclei. In the present paper, the charge resolution of ATIC was improved and backgrounds were reduced in the region from Be to Si by using the upper layer of the scintillator hodoscope as an additional charge detector. The flux ratios of nuclei B/C, C/O, N/O in the energy region from about 10 GeV/nucleon to 300 GeV/nucleon obtained from this high-resolution, high-quality charge spectra are presented, and compared with existing theoretical predictions.
Index Keywords: Particle detectors; Scintillation counters; Silicon; Tellurium compounds; Balloon-borne experiment; Bismuth germanate; Charge detectors; Charge resolution; Cosmic-ray nucleus; High resolution; Relative abundance; Silicon matrix; Cosmic rays

Authors: Papagiannakis R.G., Rakopoulos C.D., Hountalas D.T., Giakoumis E.G.
Title: Study of the performance and exhaust emissions of a spark-ignited engine operating on syngas fuel
Affiliations: Thermodynamic and Propulsion Systems Section, Aeronautical Sciences Department, Hellenic Air Force Academy, Dekelia Air Force Base, Dekelia Attiki, Greece; Internal Combustion Engines Laboratory, Thermal Engineering Department, School of Mechanical Engineering, National Technical University of Athens, 9 Heroon Polytechniou St., Zografou Campus, 15780 Athens, Greece
Authors with affiliations: Papagiannakis, R.G., Thermodynamic and Propulsion Systems Section, Aeronautical Sciences Department, Hellenic Air Force Academy, Dekelia Air Force Base, Dekelia Attiki, Greece; Rakopoulos, C.D., Internal Combustion Engines Laboratory, Thermal Engineering Department, School of Mechanical Engineering, National Technical University of Athens, 9 Heroon Polytechniou St., Zografou Campus, 15780 Athens, Greece; Hountalas, D.T., Internal Combustion Engines Laboratory, Thermal Engineering Department, School of Mechanical Engineering, National Technical University of Athens, 9 Heroon Polytechniou St., Zografou Campus, 15780 Athens, Greece; Giakoumis, E.G., Internal Combustion Engines Laboratory, Thermal Engineering Department, School of Mechanical Engineering, National Technical University of Athens, 9 Heroon Polytechniou St., Zografou Campus, 15780 Athens, Greece
Abstract: To resolve the problem of depletion of petroleum based liquid fuels, various solutions have been proposed. One of them is the use of gaseous fuels that are generated from the gasification of woods, namely syngas or wood-gas fuels, as full supplement fuels in spark ignition internal combustion (IC) engines. This fuel consists of nearly 40% combustible gases, mainly hydrogen and carbon monoxide (CO), while the rest is non-combustible gases. In the present work, a comparison between experimental and computed results is presented for a conventional natural gas, spark-ignited engine, fuelled with syngas instead of natural gas fuel. For the theoretical investigation, a computer model is developed that simulates the syngas combustion processes in a conventional natural gas, spark-ignited engine. The combustion model is a two- zone one, where the combustion rate of syngas fuel depends on the velocity of the flame front that forms around the area of the burning zone and then spreads inside the combustion chamber. The flame front development takes into account the history of pressure and temperature inside the chamber and the local composition, in order to estimate the flame velocity. An equilibrium model is used to determine the concentration of the chemical species involved, the extended Zeldovich mechanism is used to determine the concentration of nitric oxide (NO) and a CO kinetics scheme is used to estimate the CO emission. To validate the predictive ability of the model, experimental measurements are used from the operation of a multi-cylinder, four-stroke, turbocharged, spark-ignited engine fuelled with syngas fuel, with the measurements corresponding to various values of the air to fuel ratio (load). The experimental results are found to be in good agreement with the respective computed ones obtained from the computer model. Comparing the computed results when operating the engine with natural gas as against syngas fuel, a serious effect of the syngas operation on the cylinder pressure diagrams and the engine brake efficiency is revealed, for all test cases examined. Moreover, as far as pollutant emissions are concerned, the use of natural gas instead of syngas has a positive effect on both NO and CO emissions (reduction). © 2007 Inderscience Enterprises Ltd.
Author Keywords: carbon monoxide; emissions; hydrogen; performance; spark ignition engine; syngas fuel

Authors: Parker G.B., Dahowski R.T.
Title: The elephant in the room: Dealing with carbon emissions from synthetic transportation fuels production
Affiliations: Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA 99352, United States
Authors with affiliations: Parker, G.B., Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA 99352, United States; Dahowski, R.T., Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA 99352, United States
Abstract: There has been considerable interest in producing synthetic transportation fuels via coal-to-liquids (CTL) hydrocarbon conversion, particularly in countries where there is an abundant domestic coal resource. In the United States, there is currently a public policy debate over the use of coal to produce liquid transportation fuels to increase energy security and decrease dependence on imported petroleum and refined products. There are a number of challenges to be faced by a possible CTL industry, and one of the largest relates to the magnitude of carbon dioxide (CO 2) generated, from the synthetic fuel production as well as from the combustion of the synthetic transportation fuel itself. Co 2, produced by conversion of hydrocarbons to energy, primarily via fossil fuel combustion, is one of the most ubiquitous and significant greenhouse gases (GHGs). Concerns over climate change precipitated by rising atmospheric GHG concentrations have prompted many industrialized nations to begin adopting limits on emissions to inhibit increases in atmospheric CO 2 levels. The United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change states as a key goal the stabilization of atmospheric GHGs at a level that prevents "dangerous anthropogenic interference" with the world's climate systems. This will require sharply reducing CO 2 emissions across the globe and ultimately a fundamental shift in the way in which energy is produced and consumed. This paper provides an overview of the challenge posed by the magnitude of CO 2 that would be produced from a developing CTL industry. The status and costs associated with carbon dioxide capture and geologic storage (CCS) technologies are discussed as a means of helping to mitigate the CO 2 issue, along with remaining challenges that must be overcome for an emerging CTL industry to move toward maturity. However, even if CCS can be safely and successfully applied to CTL plants, CO 2 emissions will still likely be greater than conventional liquid transportation fuel production from conventional petroleum.
Index Keywords: Anthropogenic interference; Atmospheric CO; Carbon dioxide capture; Carbon emissions; Climate system; Coal resources; Energy security; Fossil fuel combustion; Fuel production; Geologic storage; Hydrocarbon conversion; Industrialized nations; Liquid transportation; Refined products; Transportation fuels; United nations framework convention on climate changes; Carbon capture; Coal combustion; Coal transportation; Environmental regulations; Fossil fuels; Global warming; Greenhouse gases; Hydrocarbon refining; Hydrocarbons; Industry; Liquids; Petroleum transportation; Synthetic fuels; Carbon dioxide
