Authors: Rao Chitikela S.
Title: Air permitting of IGCC plants
Source title: Restoring Our Natural Habitat - Proceedings of the 2007 World Environmental and Water Resources Congress
Affiliations: ERM, 350 Eagleview Blvd., Exton PA 19341-1155, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rao Chitikela, S., ERM, 350 Eagleview Blvd., Exton PA 19341-1155, United States
Abstract: Coal gasification, cleaning of the synthesis gas (syngas), and combustion of the clean syngas is currently the upcoming IGCC (Integrated Gasification Combined Cycle) method in the thermal power production and control of several air contaminants and possibly the greenhouse gases. A good number of patented feed-gasifiers are commercially available. Once coal or other feed is gasified, the elemental sulfur is removed from syngas and, then it is possible to remove the carbon-dioxide (a greenhouse gas) as required by the upcoming local, state, and federal environmental regulations. Currently, the syngas with the carbon-dioxide is fired in the stationary combustion turbines (CTs) to produce power. IGCC process is, currently, the preferred choice over conventional thermal power production in regard to cleanup of fuel and significantly reduced contaminant emissions. The air permitting requirements include the review of: feed preparation and PM emissions; feed gasification and contaminant emissions; elemental sulfur recovery and SO2 emissions; options for carbon-dioxide recovery; syngas characteristics for combustion; CT design and combustion mechanisms; air contaminant emissions of CT; controlled CT emissions of nitrogen-oxides and carbon-monoxide gases using the SCR and oxidation catalysts, respectively; and, emission of volatile organic compounds (VOCs), and hazardous air pollutants (HAPs). However, the IGCC processes are being rigorously reviewed for the system integration and reliability, and significant reduction of air contaminant emissions (including the greenhouse gases). This paper included a review of IGCC air contaminant emission rates, and various applicable regulatory requirements, such as NSR (New Source Review), NSPS (New Source Performance Standards), and MACT (maximum achievable control technology). The IGCC facility's NOX, CO, SO2, PM, VOCs, and HAPs emission rates would be significantly low. Thus, effective, construction and installation, and operation air permits would be necessary for IGCC facilities. © 2007 ASCE.
Author Keywords: Air emissions; Coal gasification; Combustion turbines; Gasification; GHGs; IGCC; Syngas

Title: Field application of the digital opacity compliance system (DOCS) for fugitive emissions opacity determination
Source title: 100th Annual Conference and Exhibition of the Air and Waste Management Association 2007, ACE 2007
Affiliations: 5th AWB CEG/CEVOC, Environmental Management Directorate, OO-ALC/EMC, 7274 Wardleigh Rd, Hill Air Force Base, UT  84056-5137, United States; Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, Utah State University, 1405 Mount Logan Drive, Logan, UT  84321, United States; Department of the Army, Directorate of Environmental Compliance and Management (DEC AM), Attn: ECD (Air), 1638 Elwell St., Fort Carson, CO  80913-4356, United States; HQ, III Corps and Fort Hood, IMSW-HOD-PWE, Bldg 4219, 77th St., Fort Hood, TX  76544-5028, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rasmussen, S.L., 5th AWB CEG/CEVOC, Environmental Management Directorate, OO-ALC/EMC, 7274 Wardleigh Rd, Hill Air Force Base, UT  84056-5137, United States; McFarland, M.J., Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, Utah State University, 1405 Mount Logan Drive, Logan, UT  84321, United States; Atkins, S., Department of the Army, Directorate of Environmental Compliance and Management (DEC AM), Attn: ECD (Air), 1638 Elwell St., Fort Carson, CO  80913-4356, United States; Kennedy, R.L., HQ, III Corps and Fort Hood, IMSW-HOD-PWE, Bldg 4219, 77th St., Fort Hood, TX  76544-5028, United States; Olivas, A.C., 5th AWB CEG/CEVOC, Environmental Management Directorate, OO-ALC/EMC, 7274 Wardleigh Rd, Hill Air Force Base, UT  84056-5137, United States
Abstract: Most regulated facilities currently employ the US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Reference Method 9 (Method 9) to demonstrate compliance with enforceable fugitive emission visible opacity limits. However, Method 9 was neither designed nor intended by the EPA to be used to determine the visible opacity levels associated with fugitive emissions. Maintenance of Department of Defense (DoD) weapon systems, battlefield training exercises and construction/demolition activities invariably lead to the generation of fugitive emissions. DoD reliance on Method 9 for certifying compliance with fugitive emissions opacity regulations leaves installations and their vital combat readiness programs vulnerable to unnecessarily restrictive regulatory oversight including environmental enforcement actions. Recently, the DoD, working in conjunction with the EPA and several western states, has embarked on a technology field demonstration program focused on evaluating the ability of the Digital Opacity Compliance System (DOCS) to reliably determine the visible opacity associated with fugitive emissions. The DOCS technology utilizes digital photographs taken by standard commercial-off-the-shelf digital cameras to determine visible opacity. The photographs are analyzed using an innovative yet simple computer algorithm that compares the differences in spatial color intensity between scenes with and without the presence of fugitive emissions to quantify the level of visible opacity. Using an industrial fog generator to produce fugitive emissions of variable density, a field comparison of the DOCS technology and Method 9 was conducted at Hill Air Force Base, UT. Results demonstrated that the two methods yielded mixed findings under turbulent wind conditions. In the first set of opacity measurements (i.e., taken at 30 foot off-set distance), the DOCS technology and Method 9-certified observers were found to generate opacity measurements that were statistically different and that, on average, indicated that the DOCS technology consistently yielded a higher opacity value. The fact that all three digital camera/Method 9 stations generated similar results suggests that the downwind location did not affect the performance of one method more than the other. To document the inherent variability of the individual test methods, the average standard deviation of the opacity measurements was estimated. At an off-set distance of 30 feet, all DOCS Camera/Method 9 opacity stations reported DOCS opacity measurements that were less variable than Method 9 opacity results regardless of down wind distance. As the off-set distance was increased, the variability and inconsistency in performance between the DOCS technology and Method 9-certified observers increased. Preliminary evaluation of the field data suggests that development of a fugitive emissions opacity method must take into account the impact of local climatic conditions (e.g. wind shear) on opacity determination. Moreover, method development must also balance the need to comply with prescribed regulatory protocols (e.g., maintaining sun's position to the back of the opacity observer) when determining the visible opacity associated with fugitive emissions.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Densitometers; Digital cameras; Electric equipment protection; Environmental Protection Agency; Environmental regulations; Industrial emissions; Photography; Regulatory compliance; Testing; Video cameras; Waste management; Commercial off-the-shelf digital camera; Demonstration programs; Department of Defense; Digital photographs; Environmental enforcement; Inherent variability; Regulatory oversight; US Environmental Protection Agency; Opacity

Authors: Raupach M.R.
Title: Dynamics of resource production and utilisation in two-component biosphere-human and terrestrial carbon systems
Affiliations: CSIRO Marine and Atmospheric Research, Canberra, ACT 2601, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Raupach, M.R., CSIRO Marine and Atmospheric Research, Canberra, ACT 2601, Australia
Abstract: This paper analyses simple models for "production-utilisation" systems, reduced to two state variables for producers and utilisers, respectively. Two modes are distinguished: in "harvester" systems the resource utilisation involves active seeking on the part of the utilisers, while in "processor" systems, utilisers function as passive material processors. An idealised model of biosphere-human interactions provides an example of a harvester system, and a model of plant and soil carbon dynamics exemplifies a processor system. The biosphere-human interaction model exhibits a number of features in accord with experience, including a tendency towards oscillatory behaviour which in some circumstances results in limit cycles. The plant-soil carbon model is used to study the effect of random forcing of production (for example by weather and climate fluctuations), showing that with appropriate parameter choices the model can flip between active-biosphere and dormant-biosphere equilibria under the influence of random forcing. This externally-driven transition between locally stable states is fundamentally different from Lorenzian chaos. A behavioural difference between two-component processor and harvester systems is that harvester systems have a capacity for oscillatory behaviour while processor systems do not.
Index Keywords: biosphere; carbon cycle; model; nature-society relations; resource use; soil carbon

Authors: Ravin A.L., Hibbard C.S.
Title: Local implementation of global climate change commitments
Source title: 100th Annual Conference and Exhibition of the Air and Waste Management Association 2007, ACE 2007
Affiliations: Camp Dresser McKee Inc., One Cambridge Place, 50 Hampshire Street, Cambridge, MA  02139, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ravin, A.L., Camp Dresser McKee Inc., One Cambridge Place, 50 Hampshire Street, Cambridge, MA  02139, United States; Hibbard, C.S., Camp Dresser McKee Inc., One Cambridge Place, 50 Hampshire Street, Cambridge, MA  02139, United States
Abstract: More than 400 U.S. municipalities have committed to addressing climate change by reducing their contribution to global greenhouse gas emissions. Through the U.S. Mayors Climate Protection Agreement and the Cities for Climate Protection ™ program, mayors and local government officials from all political parties and in all 50 states have made commitments to address global climate change in an effort to improve quality of life for citizens as well as curb pollution at the local level. These high level commitments by elected officials are beginning to influence engineering and operations decisions by public managers, including urban planners, environmental officials, and public works and utility directors and this trend will only continue to rise. This paper will explore the implementation of these commitments and the implications for air and waste management for local governments. Policy and market drivers, including upcoming legislation and greenhouse gas registries, will be presented to lay the foundation for the local policy commitments. Examples are provided to demonstrate how local governments can make a difference by reducing greenhouse gas emissions for the facilities they manage. These will include: greenhouse gas management plans for wastewater and water treatment plants including methane digesters, landfill gas capture and cogeneration, and carbon sequestration through urban tree planting.
Index Keywords: Carbon; Cogeneration plants; Forestry; Gas emissions; Gas plants; Gases; Greenhouse gases; Laws and legislation; Methane; Reforestation; Waste management; Wastewater treatment; Water treatment; Carbon sequestration; Cities for climate protections; Climate protection; Global climate changes; Greenhouse gas management; Local government; Political parties; Quality of life; Climate change; Climates; Emission; Greenhouse Gases; Water Treatment

Authors: Read H.L., Hartman J.L., Goyette H.
Title: The great emissions roundup: The Texan approach to permitting maintenance, start-up and shutdown emissions and potential implications
Source title: 100th Annual Conference and Exhibition of the Air and Waste Management Association 2007, ACE 2007
Affiliations: Environmental Resources Management (ERM), 7700 Chevy Chase Drive, Austin, TX  78752, United States; 15810 Park Ten Place, Houston, TX  77084, United States
Authors with affiliations: Read, H.L., Environmental Resources Management (ERM), 7700 Chevy Chase Drive, Austin, TX  78752, United States; Hartman, J.L., Environmental Resources Management (ERM), 7700 Chevy Chase Drive, Austin, TX  78752, United States; Goyette, H., 15810 Park Ten Place, Houston, TX  77084, United States
Abstract: In recent years the EPA has been working to reduce air pollution from stationary sources by closely examining the use of affirmative defense as it pertains to emission events. To this end the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (TCEQ) issued rules and revisions to 30 TAC Chapter 101 in December 2005 for permitting planned maintenance, start-up and shutdown (MSS) emissions as a means of requiring the regulated community to quantify and then request authorization for specific MSS activities. As these rules are implemented, Best Available Control Technology (BACT) for each MSS activity will be established. The permitting of MSS emissions will put the focus squarely on the reliability and redundancy of control devices, and reevaluate the definition of economic reasonableness relating to MSS activities. This paper examines the process involved in identifying MSS activities, grouping and quantifying those emissions in a manageable way, and evaluating BACT and potential impacts in a manner that is defensible to the TCEQ given that agency guidance is not yet available. This paper also outlines strategies used to successfully quantify and potentially permit MSS emissions in Texas.
Index Keywords: Environmental Protection Agency; Redundancy; Satellites; Best available control technologies; Control device; Planned maintenance; Potential impacts; Stationary sources; Texas Commission on Environmental Quality; Waste management

Authors: Reimers C.E., Stecher III H.A., White H.K., Girguis P.
Title: Examining the efficiency and biogeochemistry of plankton-fed microbial fuel cells
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: College of Oceanic and Atmospheric Sciences, Oregon State University, Hatfield Marine Science Center, 2030 SE Marine Science Drive, Newport, OR 97365, United States; Hatfield Marine Science Center, Oregon State University, 2030 SE Marine Science Dr, Newport, OR 97365, United States; Organismic and Evolutionary Biology, Harvard University, Biolabs, 16 Divinity Avenue, Cambridge, MA 02138, United States
Authors with affiliations: Reimers, C.E., College of Oceanic and Atmospheric Sciences, Oregon State University, Hatfield Marine Science Center, 2030 SE Marine Science Drive, Newport, OR 97365, United States; Stecher III, H.A., Hatfield Marine Science Center, Oregon State University, 2030 SE Marine Science Dr, Newport, OR 97365, United States; White, H.K., Organismic and Evolutionary Biology, Harvard University, Biolabs, 16 Divinity Avenue, Cambridge, MA 02138, United States; Girguis, P., Organismic and Evolutionary Biology, Harvard University, Biolabs, 16 Divinity Avenue, Cambridge, MA 02138, United States
Abstract: Decomposition products, power output, electrode potentials, microbial communities and Coulombic efficiency were investigated as a function of discharge potential in two-chamber, seawater-filled, microbial fuel cells (MFCs) fed with marine plankton. In the aquatic environment, particulate organic carbon derived from plankton is the most abundant "biofuel" available for MFCs, and hence could be used to power autonomous sensors, beacons and communication devices for ocean monitoring and navigation. In this study, increased plankton decomposition rates were observed in active MFC experiments compared to those in an open circuit control cell. These increased decomposition rates coincided with peak electricity generation and sulfide removal and are interpreted to be due to the catalysis of organic matter degradation by andophillic microorganisms. Coulombic efficiencies for the MFCs were between 9-12%, and ~20% of the planktonic carbon added remained after 56.7 days. Optimization of MFC designs specifically aimed at plankton degradation reactions has the potential to improve these recoveries.

Authors: Reiner D.M.
Title: From public understanding to public policy: Public views on energy, technology, and climate science in the United States
Authors with affiliations: Reiner, D.M.
Abstract: An issue as technically complicated as climate change poses a series of demanding conditions in translating public support into public policy. The first hurdle is one of awareness. Many people simply do not pay attention to the issues involved in energy or environmental policy and so are unaware of many of the issues of concern relevant to climate policy. There is a relatively small informed audience for many policy questions. Researchers have concluded that fewer than one-fifth of the U.S. residents meet a minimal standard of civic scientific literacy. Given the low level of attentiveness to science or environmental issues among even highly educated members of the public, it is not surprising that many people have fundamental misunderstandings of the basic scientific facts. As part of its studies of environmental literacy, the National Environmental Education and Training Foundation (NEETF) has sought to develop a set of knowledge questions on basic environmental and energy facts. Not only science or technology but policy is also the subject of misunderstanding. Understanding the impact of information is critical for complicated technical questions that are subject to many misconceptions. Education clearly has a role to play. On the issue of climate change, there remains a stronger level of public support for taking action than realized by many politicians. © 2007 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.

Authors: Reinhardt H.-W., Schellhorn H.
Title: Tempered phonolite rock powder as an addition to concrete with a high k-value [Getempertes Phonolith-Gesteinsmehl als Betonzusatzstoff mit Hohem k-Wert]
Source title: Betonwerk und Fertigteil-Technik/Concrete Plant and Precast Technology
Affiliations: TH Stuttgart, Germany; MPA Universität Stuttgart, Otto-Graf-Institut, Germany; Referats Bindemittel und Zusätze, Außerdem Lang-Jähriger Mitarbeiter, Mehreren Arbeitsausschüssen des NABau Beim DIN, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Reinhardt, H.-W., TH Stuttgart, Germany; Schellhorn, H., MPA Universität Stuttgart, Otto-Graf-Institut, Germany, Referats Bindemittel und Zusätze, Außerdem Lang-Jähriger Mitarbeiter, Mehreren Arbeitsausschüssen des NABau Beim DIN, Germany
Abstract: Tempered phonolite rock powder with a high k-value can be counted towards the water/cement ratio and the minimum cement content. The cement content in concrete can be reduced through the use of puzzolanic additions. Additions reduce the cement content with regard to the durability of the construction materials and environmental protection. They contribute to reducing energy consumption and CO2 emission. Phonolite only has certain reactivity with calcium hydroxide in its initial state and this reactivity can be increased by tempering. The extent of phonolite was determined by the k-value resulting from the equation w/(c + k × q), where w is water content, c is cement content, and q is phonolite content in the fresh concrete. The cements and the respective mixes compiled with all the requirements makes on initial setting and volume stability.
Index Keywords: Phonolites; Tempered phonolite rock powder; Volume stability; Carbon dioxide; Cements; Concretes; Durability; Energy utilization; Environmental protection; Rocks; Tempering; Powders

Authors: Rendler S., Oestreich M.
Title: Polishing a diamond in the rough: "Cu-H" catalysis with silanes
Affiliations: Organisch-Chemisches Institut, Westfälische Wilhelms-Universität Münster, Corrensstrasse 40, 48149 Münster, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Rendler, S., Organisch-Chemisches Institut, Westfälische Wilhelms-Universität Münster, Corrensstrasse 40, 48149 Münster, Germany; Oestreich, M., Organisch-Chemisches Institut, Westfälische Wilhelms-Universität Münster, Corrensstrasse 40, 48149 Münster, Germany
Abstract: The value of a novel chemical transformation is often underappreciated at the time of its discovery. The reasons are doubtlessly manifold, but the "chemical zeitgeist" subtly determines how the new reaction will be received by the chemical community. The enantioselective reduction of carbonyls by copper-catalyzed hydrosilylation was certainly outshone by other asymmetric hydrogenation techniques. A seminal report at an early stage indicated the considerable potential of this catalytic process, yet it was disregarded for more than a decade. A refined mechanistic picture in connection with a plethora of new chiral ligands then led to copper-catalyzed 1,2- as well as 1,4-reductions of carbonyl compounds with excellent levels of enantioselection at high substrate-to-catalyst ratios and even more remarkable substrate-to-ligand ratios. The tide is turning for inexpensive copper catalysts in asymmetric hydride transfer reactions! © 2007 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA.
Author Keywords: Asymmetric catalysis; Carbonyl compounds; Conjugate reduction; Copper; Silicon
Index Keywords: Catalysis; Chemical polishing; Copper compounds; Hydrogenation; Silanes; Silicon; Asymmetric catalysis; Carbonyl compounds; Chiral ligands; Conjugate reduction; Hydrosilylation; Diamonds

Authors: Rest K.
Title: Silenced science: air pollution decision-making at the EPA threatens public health.
Source title: New solutions : a journal of environmental and occupational health policy : NS
Affiliations: Brattle Square Cambridge, Union of Concerned ScientistsMA  02238-9105, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rest, K., Brattle Square Cambridge, Union of Concerned ScientistsMA  02238-9105, United States
Abstract: The saga of the Environmental Protection Agency's new particulate matter (PM) rule is yet another example of this Administration's disregard for and disrespect of science and scientists--and may signal the beginning of a disturbing trend to reduce the role of science in protecting the quality of our air. Political interference in the PM case is clear. And more trouble may be in the wings when it comes to acceptable levels of ozone pollution and the process for setting the National Ambient Air Quality Standards (NAAQS). For several years, the Union of Concerned Scientists has been actively monitoring and documenting the misuse of science in public policy-making. Consider this a call to arms. Now is the time to engage your elected officials on these issues.

Authors: Reváková D., Nováková A., Polonec L.
Title: Directions and tendencies in European union energy sector
Source title: Proceedings of the 8th International Scientific Conference Electric Power Engineering 2007, EPE 2007
Affiliations: FEI, STU Bratislava, Ilkovičova 3, 841 04 Bratislava, Slovakia
Authors with affiliations: Reváková, D., FEI, STU Bratislava, Ilkovičova 3, 841 04 Bratislava, Slovakia; Nováková, A., FEI, STU Bratislava, Ilkovičova 3, 841 04 Bratislava, Slovakia; Polonec, L., FEI, STU Bratislava, Ilkovičova 3, 841 04 Bratislava, Slovakia
Abstract: The paper analyses actual trends and development of the entire EU energy market on the basis of member states. The first part deals with EU electricity markets development in the area of energy supply security, electricity market transparency, pan-European energy policy and the single regulator for the entire EU energy sector. The focus is mainly on problems that cannot be dealt adequately on a national basis, for example the growing dependence on electricity imports, high prices, problems with commission of supplies, as well as possibilities of big consumers to collaborate in generation. The second part deals with development of energy sector in selected EU member states in last years and means to solve disputes on a national basis. Paper further comments on different opinions to development in nuclear energy, opposition to building of new sources and power lines, deals with transmission grid access fees, cross-subsidy, vertical integration and the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions.

Authors: Reynolds T.G., Ren L., Clarke J.-P.B.
Title: Advanced noise abatement approach activities at nottingham east midlands airport, UK
Source title: Proceedings of the 7th USA/Europe Air Traffic Management Research and Development Seminar, ATM 2007
Affiliations: University of Cambridge, Cambridge, United Kingdom; Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, GA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Reynolds, T.G., University of Cambridge, Cambridge, United Kingdom; Ren, L., Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, GA, United States; Clarke, J.-P.B., Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, GA, United States
Abstract: Advanced noise abatement approach procedures incorporating Continuous Descent Approach, Precision Area Navigation and Low Power/Low Drag elements have been developed for a regional UK airport in partnership between academia and key stakeholders. The procedures were designed for a wide variety of aircraft types and equipages using a combination of advanced academic research tools, industry simulators and stakeholder input. Interactions between airspace constraints and procedure design were found to be critical. Flight trials of the procedures have demonstrated significant environmental benefits compared to non-trial flights: 3-6 dBA peak noise reductions and 10-20% fuel burn/emissions reductions have been observed. However, the importance of aircraft automation level, air traffic control coordination and the need for effective environmental performance metrics have been highlighted.

Authors: Rhodes P.R., Skogsberg L.A., Grimes W.H., Kane R.D., Trillo E.A.
Title: Evaluation of fitness-for-purpose test environments for sulfide stress cracking tests of casing steels
Affiliations: 810 Myrtlea, Houston, TX 77079, United States; 2207 McDuffie St., Houston, TX 77019, United States; Shell Global Solutions US, 3333 Highway 6 South, Houston, TX 77082, United States; Honeywell International, 14503 Bammel N, Houston, TX 77014, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rhodes, P.R., 810 Myrtlea, Houston, TX 77079, United States; Skogsberg, L.A., 2207 McDuffie St., Houston, TX 77019, United States; Grimes, W.H., Shell Global Solutions US, 3333 Highway 6 South, Houston, TX 77082, United States; Kane, R.D., Honeywell International, 14503 Bammel N, Houston, TX 77014, United States; Trillo, E.A., Honeywell International, 14503 Bammel N, Houston, TX 77014, United States
Abstract: In assessing risks of standard sulfide stress cracking (SSC) of low alloy steels under field conditions, the environmental effects in fitness-for-purpose (FFP) testing has focused on the H2S partial pressure, pH, and temperature. To gain information on additional variables, the literature has been reviewed and new test methods developed. Conclusions are presented on the effect of a number of variables, including (1) reduced H2S at high CH4 pressure, (2) flow, (3) solution composition, including the effect of C02. The focus is the link between corrosion reactions and the resulting level of absorbed hydrogen. Reasons for the lack or correlation between NACE method A tensile tests and fracture mechanics tests with DCB specimens are presented. Laboratory environments are contrasted with the very different environmental conditions of a condensing water phase that occurs following a tubing/connection/packer failure. © 2007 by NACE International.

Authors: Richards G.P., Borough C., Evans D., Reddin A., Ximenes F., Gardner D.
Title: Developing a carbon stocks and flows model for Australian wood products
Affiliations: Australian Greenhouse Office, GPO Box 787, Canberra, ACT, 2601, Australia; The Fenner School of Environment and Society, The Australian National University, Canberra, ACT, 0200, Australia; MBAC Consulting, PO Box 262, Deakin West, ACT, 2600, Australia; CRC for Greenhouse Accounting, Forest Resources Research, NSW Department of Primary Industries, PO Box 100, Beecroft, NSW, 2119, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Richards, G.P., Australian Greenhouse Office, GPO Box 787, Canberra, ACT, 2601, Australia, The Fenner School of Environment and Society, The Australian National University, Canberra, ACT, 0200, Australia; Borough, C., MBAC Consulting, PO Box 262, Deakin West, ACT, 2600, Australia; Evans, D.; Reddin, A., Australian Greenhouse Office, GPO Box 787, Canberra, ACT, 2601, Australia; Ximenes, F., CRC for Greenhouse Accounting, Forest Resources Research, NSW Department of Primary Industries, PO Box 100, Beecroft, NSW, 2119, Australia; Gardner, D., CRC for Greenhouse Accounting, Forest Resources Research, NSW Department of Primary Industries, PO Box 100, Beecroft, NSW, 2119, Australia
Abstract: This paper describes the development of a model for estimating Australia's stocks and flows of carbon in harvested wood products, including estimates of atmospheric emissions. The model estimates emissions in various forms, including those from wood products contained in Australia, encompassing both domestically produced (net of exports) and imported wood products. This estimate is the basis of Australia's National Greenhouse Gas Inventory report on wood products. The model can also estimate emissions from all (and only) wood products produced in Australia, and a third variant that presumes emissions from wood products at the time of harvest. The model represents a collaborative effort, involving relevant Commonwealth and state government agencies, industry groups and research bodies. The model uses available statistics on log flows from forest harvest and estimates of the carbon content of the various wood products processed (for example, sawn timber, plywood, pulp and paper and woodchips) to determine carbon inputs to wood products. The model uses estimates of the decay period of various classes of wood product to calculate the pool of carbon in wood products. Crosschecking with independent input data was done wherever possible to test the robustness of various input data used in the model development. The model is built in Microsoft Excel with all rate and age parameters easily accessed and varied for sensitivity testing using the @Risk software. Wood products in use are assigned to young-, medium-and old-age pools. Simulated losses of wood products from their service life occur from each of the young-, medium-and old-age pools. Material leaving service is either transferred to bioenergy, added to landfill, recycled or emitted to the atmosphere. Losses of carbon can also occur from the landfill pool. The recorded imports and exports of wood products are used to calculate emissions under two approaches. The first is from wood products produced in Australia (but not necessarily remaining within Australia), and the second from wood products stored in Australia (wherever they were produced). Further simulations, with and without consideration of storage and emissions from landfill, are then run for each approach. The results show that an accounting approach that presumes emissions from wood products at harvest over-estimates emissions to the atmosphere when compared with approaches that consider the service life of wood products. The storage of wood products in landfill is also significant. © 2007 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.
Author Keywords: Australia; Carbon; Flow; Forest products; Greenhouse gases; Lifespan; Models; Stocks
Index Keywords: Australia; Carbon; Pulp; Statistical methods; Government agencies; Harvested wood products; Stocks; Wood products; Forest Products; Greenhouse Gases; Wood Products

Authors: Ridgwell A.
Title: Application of sediment core modelling to interpreting the glacial-interglacial record of Southern Ocean silica cycling
Affiliations: School of Geographical Sciences, University of Bristol, Bristol, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Ridgwell, A., School of Geographical Sciences, University of Bristol, Bristol, United Kingdom
Abstract: Sediments from the Southern Ocean reveal a meridional divide in biogeochemical cycling response to the glacial-interglacial cycles of the late Neogene. South of the present-day position of the Antarctic Polar Front in the Atlantic sector of the Southern Ocean, biogenic opal is generally much more abundant in sediments during interglacials compared to glacials. To the north, an anti-phased relationship is observed, with maximum opal abundance instead occurring during glacials. This antagonistic response of sedimentary properties provides an important model validation target for testing hypotheses of glacial-interglacial change against, particularly for understanding the causes of the concurrent variability in atmospheric CO2. Here, I illustrate a time-dependent modelling approach to helping understand climates of the past by means of the mechanistic simulation of marine sediment core records. I find that a close match between model-predicted and observed down-core changes in sedimentary opal content can be achieved when changes in seasonal sea-ice extent are imposed, whereas the predicted sedimentary response to iron fertilization on its own is not consistent with sedimentary observations. The results of this sediment record model-data comparison supports previous inferences that the changing cryosphere is the primary driver of the striking features exhibited by the paleoceanographic record of this region.
Index Keywords: biogeochemical cycle; climate modeling; core analysis; glacial-interglacial cycle; marine sediment; meridional circulation; Neogene; paleoceanography; paleoclimate; polar front; silica; time dependent behavior; Atlantic Sector; Southern Ocean

Authors: Ridgwell A., Hargreaves J.C., Edwards N.R., Annan J.D., Lenton T.M., Marsh R., Yool A., Watson A.
Title: Marine geochemical data assimilation in an efficient Earth system model of global biogeochemical cycling
Affiliations: School of Geographical Sciences, University of Bristol, Bristol, United Kingdom; Frontier Research Center for Global Change, 3173-25 Showa-machi, Yokohama, Kanagawa 236-0001, Japan; Earth Sciences, Open University, Walton Hall, Milton Keynes, United Kingdom; School of Environmental Sciences, University of East Anglia, Norwich, United Kingdom; National Oceanography Centre, Southampton, European Way, Southampton SO14 3ZH, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Ridgwell, A., School of Geographical Sciences, University of Bristol, Bristol, United Kingdom; Hargreaves, J.C., Frontier Research Center for Global Change, 3173-25 Showa-machi, Yokohama, Kanagawa 236-0001, Japan; Edwards, N.R., Earth Sciences, Open University, Walton Hall, Milton Keynes, United Kingdom; Annan, J.D., Frontier Research Center for Global Change, 3173-25 Showa-machi, Yokohama, Kanagawa 236-0001, Japan; Lenton, T.M., School of Environmental Sciences, University of East Anglia, Norwich, United Kingdom; Marsh, R., National Oceanography Centre, Southampton, European Way, Southampton SO14 3ZH, United Kingdom; Yool, A., National Oceanography Centre, Southampton, European Way, Southampton SO14 3ZH, United Kingdom; Watson, A., School of Environmental Sciences, University of East Anglia, Norwich, United Kingdom
Abstract: We have extended the 3-D ocean based "Grid EN-abled Integrated Earth system model" (GENIE-1) to help understand the role of ocean biogeochemistry and marine sediments in the long-term (∼100 to 100000 year) regulation of atmospheric CO2, and the importance of feedbacks between CO2 and climate. Here we describe the ocean carbon cycle, which in its first incarnation is based around a simple single nutrient (phosphate) control on biological productivity. The addition of calcium carbonate preservation in deep-sea sediments and its role in regulating atmospheric CO2 is presented elsewhere (Ridgwell and Hargreaves, 2007). We have calibrated the model parameters controlling ocean carbon cycling in GENIE-1 by assimilating 3-D observational datasets of phosphate and alkalinity using an ensemble Kalman filter method. The calibrated (mean) model predicts a global export production of particulate organic carbon (POC) of 8.9 PgC yr-1, and reproduces the main features of dissolved oxygen distributions in the ocean. For estimating biogenic calcium carbonate (CaCO 3) production, we have devised a parameterization in which the CaCO3POC export ratio is related directly to ambient saturation state. Calibrated global CaCO3 export production (1.2 PgC yr -1) is close to recent marine carbonate budget estimates. The GENIE-1 Earth system model is capable of simulating a wide variety of dissolved and isotopic species of relevance to the study of modern global biogeochemical cycles as well as past global environmental changes recorded in paleoceanographic proxies. Importantly, even with 12 active biogeochemical tracers in the ocean and including the calculation of feedbacks between atmospheric CO2 and climate, we achieve better than 1000 years per (2.4 GHz) CPU hour on a desktop PC. The GENIE-1 model thus provides a viable alternative to box and zonally-averaged models for studying global biogeochemical cycling over all but the very longest (> 1000000 year) time-scales.
Index Keywords: air-sea interaction; alkalinity; biogeochemical cycle; calcium carbonate; calibration; carbon budget; carbon dioxide; carbon flux; chemical oceanography; data assimilation; deep-sea sediment; dissolved oxygen; Kalman filter; parameterization; particulate organic carbon; phosphate; remote sensing; three-dimensional modeling; timescale

Authors: Riley M.
Title: Climatic influences on fine particle pollution in Sydney
Source title: Proc. 14th International Union of Air Pollution Prevention and Environmental Protection Associations (IUAPPA) World Congress 2007, 18th Clean Air Society of Australia and New Zealand (CASANZ) Conf.
Affiliations: Department of Environment and Climate Change, NSW, PO Box 29, Lidcombe, NSW 1825, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Riley, M., Department of Environment and Climate Change, NSW, PO Box 29, Lidcombe, NSW 1825, Australia
Abstract: Fine particle pollution in the Sydney region is a key environmental indicator for NSW. Under certain conditions daily average PM10 levels can exceed the standard set by the National Environment Protection Measure for Ambient Air Quality (AAQ NEPM). In Sydney fine particle pollution events generally fall within two categories: extreme events such as bushfires and dust storms and "trapping" events where the dispersion of emissions is reduced due to meteorological conditions. The frequency and severity of events from each category is influenced by climatic variations. Particle measurements from the NSW Department of Environment and Climate Change air quality monitoring network and meteorological measurements from the Australian Bureau of Meteorology for the period 1995-2005 have been analysed using principal component analysis and cluster analysis to examine the impact that climatic variations have on fine particle levels in the Sydney region. The implications of climate change on fine particle levels and the need to adjust long term PM10 trends to account for climatic variations are briefly discussed.
Author Keywords: Bushfires; Fine particles; Multivariate analysis; PM10
Index Keywords: Fine particles; Multivariate analysis; Air quality; Climatology; Dispersions; Environmental impact; Particles (particulate matter)

Authors: Riley M.
Title: Climatic influences on fine particle pollution in Sydney
Source title: Proc. 14th International Union of Air Pollution Prevention and Environmental Protection Associations (IUAPPA) World Congress 2007, 18th Clean Air Society of Australia and New Zealand (CASANZ) Conf.
Affiliations: Department of Environment and Climate Change, NSW, PO Box 29 Lidcombe, NSW 1825, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Riley, M., Department of Environment and Climate Change, NSW, PO Box 29 Lidcombe, NSW 1825, Australia
Abstract: Particle measurements from the NSW Department of Environment and Climate Change air quality monitoring network and meteorological measurements from the Australian Bureau of Meteorology for the period 1995-2005 were analyzed using principal component analysis and cluster analysis to examine the impact that climatic variations have on fine particle levels in the Sydney region. Daily average PM10 exceeded the National Environment Protection Measure standard on 84 days during the study period. Seasonal analysis showed that exceedence events are heavily weighted towards the warmer months of the year with relatively few exceedences in winter. Exceedences of the PM10 standard during late autumn and winter were primarily due to local emissions. Reductions in regional PM10 during winter may be due to a number of factors including: improvements in solid fuel heater design, increased In Sydney fine particle pollution during the cooler months is not a significant issue on the regional scale. This is an abstract of a paper presented at the 14th International Union of Air pollution Prevention and Environmental Protection Associations World Congress 2007 (Brisbane, Queensland 9/9-13/2007).
Author Keywords: Bushfires; Fine particles; Multivariate analysis; PM10

Authors: Rimpo T.
Title: California's URBEMIS2007 land use emissions model
Source title: 100th Annual Conference and Exhibition of the Air and Waste Management Association 2007, ACE 2007
Affiliations: Jones and Stokes, 2600 V Street, Sacramento, CA  95818, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rimpo, T., Jones and Stokes, 2600 V Street, Sacramento, CA  95818, United States
Abstract: Within California, the URBEMIS (Urban Emissions) model is commonly used to estimate air emissions from land use development projects. Over the past decade, a consortium of California air districts have developed and improved this model. URBEMIS, which is a free, public- domain software package, generates estimates of a project's construction, area, and operational emissions. The software can also be used to estimate mitigated emissions. URBEMIS is most often used to prepare project specific emission inventories needed for environmental impact reports and to comply with indirect source rules. The model allows users to quickly generate air emission estimates that would result from residential, commercial, and/or industrial land uses. The most recent update of the model allows the user to make daily and annual emission estimates of reactive organic gases (ROG), oxides of nitrogen (NOx), carbon monoxide (CO), sulfur dioxides (SO2), carbon dioxide (CO2) and particulate matter (PM10 and PM2.5) emissions (both exhaust and fugitive dust). URBEMIS allows the user to generate construction emissions for demolition, site grading, and building construction phases. Construction equipment associated with each phase is based on project type, size, and location. The model has recently been updated to use the California Air Resources Board's OFFROAD2007 model to estimate off-road equipment emissions. URBEMIS has also recently been updated to use the California Air Resource Board's EMFAC2007 model to estimate on-road vehicle emissions. URBEMIS also incorporates mitigation measures that adjust vehicle trips and trip lengths based on a project's smart growth characteristics. Such characteristics include the ratio of residential units to near-by employment, the presence of retail land uses, proximity to transit service, presence of bike and pedestrian facilities, transportation demand management options, and the project's parking supply. © 2007 by the Air & Waste Management Association.
Index Keywords: Carbon dioxide; Carbon monoxide; Construction equipment; Crashworthiness; Environmental impact; Exhaust gases; Grading; Highway administration; Housing; Industrial emissions; Land use; Motor transportation; Nitrogen; Off road vehicles; Open source software; Sulfur dioxide; Building construction; California Air Resource Board; California Air Resources Board; Development project; Emission inventories; Mitigation measures; On-road vehicle emissions; Transportation demand management; Waste management

Authors: Ritter K., Shires T., Lev-On M.
Title: The role of consistent methodologies for assessing greenhouse gas emission reductions from individual projects
Source title: Proc. 14th International Union of Air Pollution Prevention and Environmental Protection Associations (IUAPPA) World Congress 2007, 18th Clean Air Society of Australia and New Zealand (CASANZ) Conf.
Affiliations: American Petroleum Institute, Washington, DC, United States; URS Corporation, Austin, TX, United States; LEVON Group, LLC, Thousand Oaks, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ritter, K., American Petroleum Institute, Washington, DC, United States; Shires, T., URS Corporation, Austin, TX, United States; Lev-On, M., LEVON Group, LLC, Thousand Oaks, CA, United States
Abstract: Mitigating climate change requires the deployment of both emerging technologies with low or zero emissions of greenhouse gases, as well as retrofits and improved operational practices at existing facilities. Increasing thermal and operational efficiency of existing systems and managing customers demands have been shown to contribute greatly to GHG emissions reductions. The policy frameworks for achieving these reductions might vary among countries and regions but in order to develop a robust and flexible global system of a common "carbon currency" there is a need for a consistent framework for quantitatively assessing these emission reductions at the individual initiative and project levels. Such common analytical tools will create the right incentives and recognition and will allow the quantification of the contribution of individual project to overall GHG emission reductions. The paper will compare and contrast existing methodological frameworks for assessing; calculating and reporting GHG emission reductions associated with projects and/or direct company actions. The paper also uses three different scenarios of Combined Heat and Power (CHP) projects to demonstrate how emission reductions will be derived.
Author Keywords: Climate change; Combined heat and power; Electricity generation; Emission reduction projects; Greenhouse gas accounting; Steam production
Index Keywords: Carbon; Climate change; Gas emissions; Project management; Emission reduction projects; Greenhouse gas accounting; Greenhouse gases

Authors: Rixen T., Ittekkot V.
Title: Chapter 7 Monsoonal Impacts on the Biological Pump in the Northern Indian Ocean as Discerned from Sediment Trap Experiments
Affiliations: Centre for Tropical Marine Ecology, Fahrenheitstr. 6, D-28359 Bremen, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Rixen, T., Centre for Tropical Marine Ecology, Fahrenheitstr. 6, D-28359 Bremen, Germany; Ittekkot, V., Centre for Tropical Marine Ecology, Fahrenheitstr. 6, D-28359 Bremen, Germany
Abstract: Sediment trap data obtained from the western Arabian Sea have been used to characterize monsoon-induced environmental conditions driving the export of material from the surface ocean into the deep sea. The ratio between particulate organic carbon (POC) and particulate inorganic carbon (PIC) of exported material was taken as an indicator of the impact of the biological pump on the oceanic uptake of atmospheric CO2. The results indicate that the biological pump is most effective in nitrogen-limited systems in which the availability of dissolved silica allows diatoms to play an important but not necessarily a dominant role within the plankton community. Accordingly, the biological pump can even be more efficient in oligotrophic systems than in eutrophic upwelling areas. A comparison with results obtained from other sediment trap experiments in the northern Indian Ocean reveals the highest annual mean POC/PIC ratios in the northern Bay of Bengal. The high POC/PIC ratios have been attributed to the impact of river discharges on the plankton community structure. The climate anomaly El Niño Southern Oscillation (ENSO) seems to influence the efficiency of the biological pump in the northern Bay of Bengal via its impact on the precipitation rates and consequently on the river discharge. © 2006 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Bay of Bengal; biological pump; POC/PIC ratios; sediment trap experiments

Authors: Robert O.E., Frank U.O., Ulamen O.A.
Title: Effect of combining rubber effluent with rock phosphate on some soil chemical properties and early growth of maize (Zea mays. L)
Affiliations: Department of Soil Science, Faculty of Agriculture, University of Benin, Benin City, Nigeria; Department of Crop Science, Faculty of Agriculture, University of Benin, Benin City, Nigeria
Authors with affiliations: Robert, O.E., Department of Soil Science, Faculty of Agriculture, University of Benin, Benin City, Nigeria; Frank, U.O., Department of Soil Science, Faculty of Agriculture, University of Benin, Benin City, Nigeria; Ulamen, O.A., Department of Crop Science, Faculty of Agriculture, University of Benin, Benin City, Nigeria
Abstract: Studies were conducted at the University of Benin, Benin City, Nigeria to examine the influence of combining rubber effluent with rock phosphate on some soil chemical properties as well as some agronomic characters of maize. The analysis of rubber effluent showed that it contains N, P, K, Ca Mg, Fe Mn, Zn and slightly acidic. It was also observed that the effluent had a pungent odour and colourless. In the first cropping, soil pH, N, Ca, Mg, K Na, Na, Fe, Mn, ECEC and Exchangeable acidity increased while the P and % carbon were reduced compared with control. In the second cropping, all the nutrient elements were reduced further. In the nutrient content of Maize, N, P increased up to 200,0001/(30 kg ha-1) while Ca, Na, Mg, K increased up to 2000001 (60 kg ha-1). The trace elements content were not consistent. Similar trends were also recorded in the second cropping but the nutrient contents were reduced further. The N, P, K, Ca, Na, Al, Fe, Zn and Mn uptake were higher at 150,0001 (30 kg ha-1) while the Mg uptake was higher at 250,0001 (120 kg ha-1) At final harvest, 150,0001 (30 kg ha-1) was significantly (p<0.05) better than other treatments including control in plant height, collar girth and leaf area. The number of leaves was not significantly different from one another in all the treatments. In the residual effect, all the agronomic characters measured were almost closing up with the first cropping. © 2007 Academic Journals.
Author Keywords: Effluent; Maize; Nutrient; Rock phosphate; Soil; Uptake
Index Keywords: acidity; agrometeorology; cation exchange capacity; cropping practice; effluent; leaf area; maize; nutrient uptake; phosphate rock; rubber; soil chemistry; trace element; Africa; Benin [Edo]; Edo; Nigeria; Sub-Saharan Africa; West Africa; Zea mays

Authors: Roberts C.
Title: Methods of reducing air pollution from tunnel exhausts
Source title: Proc. 14th International Union of Air Pollution Prevention and Environmental Protection Associations (IUAPPA) World Congress 2007, 18th Clean Air Society of Australia and New Zealand (CASANZ) Conf.
Affiliations: Queensland Department of Main Roads, GPO Box 1412, Brisbane, QLD 4001, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Roberts, C., Queensland Department of Main Roads, GPO Box 1412, Brisbane, QLD 4001, Australia
Abstract: In many countries road tunnels have proven to be a viable solution in solving many highway traffic problems, including traffic congestion through built up areas in cities and topographical constraints in mountainous countries. However, the beneficial effects of incorporating tunnels as solutions in traffic flow problems must be weighed up against the potential adverse effects of air exhaust emissions from vehicles, both in-tunnel and ambient air quality effects on the surrounding community. Various systems can be applied to upgrade the quality of the environment around tunnels and roads by making use of technologies such as movement and control, purification, and control and measurement. Air exhaust emissions can be substantially reduced by a correctly designed ventilation system and a variety of other methods including tall ventilation exhaust stacks, filter dust collector systems, electrostatic precipitators or denitrification or a ventilation control and measurement system based on the traffic volume and the polluted conditions in a tunnel at any point in time. The effective dispersion, dilution and achievement of satisfactory ground level concentrations of key air quality parameters (CO,NO2 and particulates)for these exhaust gases is essential to ensure non-negative health effects on the surrounding community. The paper will identify and discuss the types and character of air emissions, controls, the efficiency of the various control measures and estimated costs of some systems. Progress has been made in the field of emission treatment technology and viable technologies are now available to remove suspended particles, nitrogen dioxide, some portion of other oxides of nitrogen, and hydrocarbon vapours from road tunnel exhaust air.
Author Keywords: Air exhaust emissions; Air quality effects; Costs; Denitrification; Efficiency; Electrostatic precipitators; Filter dust collector systems; Road tunnels; Ventilation exhaust stacks
Index Keywords: Constraint theory; Denitrification; Exhaust gases; Highway traffic control; Air exhaust emissions; Air quality effects; Road tunnels; Ventilation exhaust stacks; Air pollution

Authors: Roberts J., Heil P., Phipps S.J., Bindoff N.
Title: AusCOM: The Australian community ocean model

Abstract: The Australian Community Ocean Model (AusCOM) is an initiative by the Australian climate sciences community (including government and academic research laboratories) towards a unified coupled ocean-seaice model for climate applications. The technical configuration and details of the sub-models are presented here. Initial results, and the development of a displaced pole bipolar ocean grid are discussed. An outlook for future model development is given. Copyright© 2007, Australian Computer Society Inc.

Authors: Rodgers C., McDonald C.F.
Title: Small recuperated gas turbine APU concept to abate concern about emissions, high fuel cost, and noise
Source title: Proceedings of the ASME Turbo Expo
Affiliations: ITC, 3010 N.Arroyo Drive, San Diego, CA 92103, United States; McDonald Thermal Engineering, 1730 Castellana Road, San Diego, CA 92037, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rodgers, C., ITC, 3010 N.Arroyo Drive, San Diego, CA 92103, United States; McDonald, C.F., McDonald Thermal Engineering, 1730 Castellana Road, San Diego, CA 92037, United States
Abstract: During the last decade microturbines in the 30 to 250 kW power range have been in service, but they have not been produced in significant enough quantities to impact the DG market due to a combination of factors including their high cost, modest efficiency, utility institutional concerns, and low interest in CHP use in the USA, although the latter could change as a result of fuel cost escalation. Very small gas turbines (ie. less than 10 kW) have been investigated periodically over the years, mainly for potential military use, but to date have not found a niche. This could well change with over 20 states now having instigated idling regulations that limit or prohibit heavy duty truck diesel engine idling. With emphasis on reducing emissions and noise levels this essentially implies that in the future a small APU will be required to provide the truck's stationary electrical needs and cabin climate control. While there will be several power source types vying for this potentially large market, a small gas turbine APU is viewed as having attractive features which include low emissions, low acoustic signature, vibration-free operation, compact and light weight package, obviates the need for oil lubrication and liquid coolant systems, ease of cold weather starting, immediate response, and the use of fuel from the truck tank. In this paper a small recuperated gas turbine APU concept rated at 5kW is discussed including component design considerations, layout features, engine performance, and target cost. The conservative design of the APU is based on the use of existing materials and state-of-the-art gas turbine technology, and is amenable to high volume automated manufacturing processes. A competitive cost is projected if the proposed APU of modular construction was fabricated in large quantities like the production of vehicular turbochargers in Europe. Copyright © 2007 by ASME.
Author Keywords: Anti-idling; APU; Gas turbine; Turbocharger
Index Keywords: Fuel cost escalation; Layout features; Liquid coolant systems; Microturbines; Turbochargers; Diesel engines; Electric power generation; Electric utilities; Emission control; Fuel economy; Noise abatement; Utility rates; Gas turbines

Authors: Ronald Bailey J., Griffith P., Simpson D.
Title: Deploying a hydrogen fuel cell powered electric bus
Source title: Electric Drive Transportation Association - 23rd Int. Electric Vehicle Symposium and Exposition 2007, EVS 2007 (Battery, Hybrid, Fuel Cell) Conf. Proc. - Sustainability: The Future of Transportation
Affiliations: University of Tennessee at Chattanooga, 615 McCallie Avenue, Chattanooga, TN 37403, United States; Advanced Technologies for Transportation Research Program, University of Tennessee, Chattanooga, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ronald Bailey, J., University of Tennessee at Chattanooga, 615 McCallie Avenue, Chattanooga, TN 37403, United States; Griffith, P., Advanced Technologies for Transportation Research Program, University of Tennessee, Chattanooga, United States; Simpson, D., Advanced Technologies for Transportation Research Program, University of Tennessee, Chattanooga, United States
Abstract: The task of deploying a hydrogen fuel cell powered electric bus for a metropolitan university campus is described. Major stakeholders include students, university facilities management, and the area transit authority that will operate the new campus shuttle bus. Requirements for the new bus and related hydrogen fueling station are outlined in this document. The rationale for selecting a hydrogen fuel cell is described in the context of energy independence, compliance with clean air regulations, and the desire to reduce greenhouse emissions. Prior to deployment, the new bus will be tested on a unique test track that was originally build by the Tennessee Valley Authority for testing alternative fuel vehicles during and following the last oil crisis. With support from the Federal Transit Administration, this facility is being re-commissioned to resume research activities aimed at development and testing of alternative energy systems for transportation. In conjunction with deployment of the hydrogen fuel cell bus, the university will also build the first hydrogen fueling station in the metropolitan area. Technical and financial considerations for hydrogen generation, storage and dispensing will be described in the context of a small scale campus shuttle bus operation. This work is to be conducted as part of the University of Tennessee at Chattanooga's Advanced Technologies for Transportation Research Program.
Author Keywords: "Campus shuttle"; "Electric bus"; "Fuel cell"; "Hydrogen"; "Test track"

Authors: Ros D., Jamelot G., Pittman M., Plé F., Kazamias S., Guilbaud O., Cassou K., Klisnick A., Habib J., Lagron J.-C., Jaeglé P., Huetz A., Chambaret J.-P., Sebban S., Zeitoun P., Mourou G.
Title: LASERIX: A European versatile high rep-rate facility for applications in the XUV range
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: LIXAM, Bât 350, 91405 Orsay, France; Laboratoire d'Optique Appliquée, chemin de la Hunière, 91761 Palaiseau, France
Authors with affiliations: Ros, D., LIXAM, Bât 350, 91405 Orsay, France; Jamelot, G., LIXAM, Bât 350, 91405 Orsay, France; Pittman, M., LIXAM, Bât 350, 91405 Orsay, France; Plé, F., LIXAM, Bât 350, 91405 Orsay, France; Kazamias, S., LIXAM, Bât 350, 91405 Orsay, France; Guilbaud, O., LIXAM, Bât 350, 91405 Orsay, France; Cassou, K., LIXAM, Bât 350, 91405 Orsay, France; Klisnick, A., LIXAM, Bât 350, 91405 Orsay, France; Habib, J., LIXAM, Bât 350, 91405 Orsay, France; Lagron, J.-C., LIXAM, Bât 350, 91405 Orsay, France; Jaeglé, P., LIXAM, Bât 350, 91405 Orsay, France; Huetz, A., LIXAM, Bât 350, 91405 Orsay, France; Chambaret, J.-P., Laboratoire d'Optique Appliquée, chemin de la Hunière, 91761 Palaiseau, France; Sebban, S., Laboratoire d'Optique Appliquée, chemin de la Hunière, 91761 Palaiseau, France; Zeitoun, P., Laboratoire d'Optique Appliquée, chemin de la Hunière, 91761 Palaiseau, France; Mourou, G., Laboratoire d'Optique Appliquée, chemin de la Hunière, 91761 Palaiseau, France
Abstract: LASERIX is a high power laser facility intended to realise and use for applications transient collisional excitation (TCE) X-ray lasers (XRLs) at various wavelengths, using grazing incidence pumping (GRIP) configuration with 10 Hz repetition rate. In addition new types of XRL schemes giving rise to emission at short wavelengths will be developed using the high energy LASERIX driver with 0.1 HZ rep-rate. Thus, this laser facility will both offer Soft X-ray lasers in the 40-10 nm range and synchronised auxiliary IR beam that could be also used to produce XUV sources. This experimental configuration highly enhances the scientific opportunities of the facility. Indeed it will be possible to realise both X-ray laser experiments and more generally pump/probe experiments, mixing IR and XUV sources. Then, this facility will be useful for the community, opening a large scale of investigations, including imagery and irradiation as illustrated in the case of laser Interaction with matter investigations using XUV interferometry.
Author Keywords: Intense XUV sources; Laser produced plasma; X-ray lasers; XUV interferometry

Authors: Rosan P., Hammarlund D.
Title: Effects of climate, fire and vegetation development on Holocene changes in total organic carbon concentration in three boreal forest lakes in northern Sweden
Affiliations: Climate Impacts Research Centre, Umeå University, 981 07 Abisko, Sweden; GeoBiosphere Science Centre, Quaternary Sciences, Lund University, Slvegatan. 12, 22362 Lund, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Rosan, P., Climate Impacts Research Centre, Umeå University, 981 07 Abisko, Sweden; Hammarlund, D., GeoBiosphere Science Centre, Quaternary Sciences, Lund University, Slvegatan. 12, 22362 Lund, Sweden
Abstract: Near infrared spectroscopy (NIRS), diatoms, pollen, charcoal, loss-on-ignition (LOI), and nutrient elements in lake sediments were used to assess important factors controlling Holocene changes in the total organic carbon (TOC) concentration, pCO2, color and pH of lake water in three boreal forest lakes in northern Sweden. The results suggest that mire formation, fire frequency and humidity are the most important forcing factors on millennial timescales. Mires produce humic acids that become available to the lakes, whereas fires may reduce the pool of carbon in the catchments, and humidity controls the transportation of allochthonous carbon into the lakes. Vegetation development and temperature as sole factors are of minor importance for the TOC concentrations in these lakes on a millennial timescale. Two of the sites indicate that liming and possibly fish introduction and rotenone treatment in recent time has led to increased TOC, color and pH in the lake water, and changed the diatom community composition to an assemblage that has never been present before. Given the predicted climate change scenario that suggests a more humid climate, expanding mires and less frequent fires, our paleolimnological data suggest that TOC concentrations can be expected to increase in boreal forest lakes in the future. Since super-saturation and emission of CO 2 from lakes is correlated to the TOC concentration of lake water, higher TOC concentrations may lead to increased emission of CO2 from lakes to the atmosphere.
Index Keywords: charcoal; climate change; climate effect; community composition; concentration (composition); diatom; fire history; fish; Holocene; infrared spectroscopy; lacustrine deposit; mire; organic carbon; pollen; Eurasia; Europe; Northern Europe; Scandinavia; Sweden; Bacillariophyta

Authors: Rosenfeld J., Jackson M.
Title: The economics and environmental benefits of electric drive technologies in heavy-duty trucks
Source title: Electric Drive Transportation Association - 23rd Int. Electric Vehicle Symposium and Exposition 2007, EVS 2007 (Battery, Hybrid, Fuel Cell) Conf. Proc. - Sustainability: The Future of Transportation
Affiliations: TIAX LLC, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rosenfeld, J., TIAX LLC, United States; Jackson, M., TIAX LLC, United States
Abstract: In this study two promising electric technologies were assessed for life cycle costs and environmental benefits for heavy-duty trucks in California - truck stop electrification (TSE) and electric transport refrigeration units (e-TRUs). Upfront capital costs, both truck-side and facilityside, were tracked along with operational cost savings due to reduced outlays for fuel and engine maintenance. This study estimated the emissions benefit of TSE and e-TRUs for the full spectrum of criteria pollutants - nitrogen oxides, diesel particulate matter and sulfur oxides - along with reactive organic gases, greenhouse gases and petroleum use. Results were estimated for three scenario years (2010, 2015, and 2020) and for two cases: an expected case, which assumes a natural level of market penetration, and an achievable case, which presumes the existence of aggressive public policies to support alternative transportation fuels. This study found that the adoption of TSE and e-TRUs results in cost-effective emission reductions for both pollutants and greenhouse gases due to their favorable life cycle economics. TSE in particular is estimated to offer environmental benefits at a net negative cost after accounting for fuel savings and reduced maintenance. Significantly, both TSE and e-TRUs are expected to be even more cost-effective in states that have not regulated diesel emissions as aggressively as California. At the same time, we believe that incentives to speed up the adoption of these technologies are warranted given a lack of consumer awareness of their benefits and the significant societal costs associated with the use of diesel engines.
Author Keywords: Environmental impact; Heavy-duty vehicles; Lifecycle cost; Transport refrigeration units; Truck stop electrification

Authors: Ross J.P., Reynolds J.S.
Title: Recent energy policy developments in the United States
Affiliations: Vote Solar Initiative, San Francisco, CA, United States; American Solar Energy Society, Boulder CO, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ross, J.P., Vote Solar Initiative, San Francisco, CA, United States; Reynolds, J.S., American Solar Energy Society, Boulder CO, United States
Abstract: Early in 2007 the American Solar Energy Society [ASES] published Tackling Climate Change in the U.S. This report showed potential carbon emissions reductions from recommended developments in energy efficiency and renewable energy by 2030. To implement these recommendations, ASES convened a group of environmental organizations, to prepare a list of energy policy objectives. This list is still evolving, and later developments will be presented at the Solar World Congress 2007 plenary. Topics include renewable energy, energy efficiency, transportation, buildings, federal leadership, and carbon emissions reductions.

Authors: Rotavera B.M., Petersen E.L.
Title: Shock-tube combustion studies of atomized fuels in the reflected-shock region
Source title: Collection of Technical Papers - 43rd AIAA/ASME/SAE/ASEE Joint Propulsion Conference
Affiliations: University of Central Florida, Orlando, FL, United States; Mechanical, Materials and Aerospace Engineering, P.O. Box 162450, Orlando, FL 32816-2450, United States; AIAA, United States; Department of Mechanical, Materials and Aerospace Engineering, P.O. Box 162450, Orlando, FL 32816-2450, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rotavera, B.M., University of Central Florida, Orlando, FL, United States, Mechanical, Materials and Aerospace Engineering, P.O. Box 162450, Orlando, FL 32816-2450, United States, AIAA, United States; Petersen, E.L., University of Central Florida, Orlando, FL, United States, AIAA, United States, Department of Mechanical, Materials and Aerospace Engineering, P.O. Box 162450, Orlando, FL 32816-2450, United States
Abstract: A liquid-spray injection system has been implemented at the University of Central Florida Gas Dynamics Laboratory to study fundamental combustion phenomena including ignition delay time measurements, soot production, and activation energies of petroleum-based and synthetic hydrocarbon fuels. The current approach uses a finely atomized jet of fuel that is injected from the endwall of a shock tube. The micron-scale fuel droplets are heated and combusted behind the reflected shock wave at elevated temperatures. Repeatability and initial characterization of the electronically controlled, autonomous system has been performed using ignition delay time measurements of kerosene droplets over consistent temperature (1260 K) and pressure (1.4 atm) conditions behind the reflected shock. Details on the first phase of the design and implementation of the technique are provided along with ignition delay time measurements of kerosene at low pressures.

Authors: Rother E., Cornel P.
Title: Potentials and limits of a pre-denitrification/nitrification biofilter configuration for advanced municipal wastewater treatment
Affiliations: Degussa AG, Department of Bio- and Environmental Process Technology, Rodenbacher Chaussee 4, 63457 Hanau-Wolfgang, Germany; Technische Universität Darmstadt (Darmstadt University of Technology), Institut WAR, Section Wastewater Technology, Petersenstr. 13, 64287 Darmstadt, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Rother, E., Degussa AG, Department of Bio- and Environmental Process Technology, Rodenbacher Chaussee 4, 63457 Hanau-Wolfgang, Germany; Cornel, P., Technische Universität Darmstadt (Darmstadt University of Technology), Institut WAR, Section Wastewater Technology, Petersenstr. 13, 64287 Darmstadt, Germany
Abstract: Pre-denitrification in biofilters is limited by the amount of easily degradable organic substrate, resulting in relatively high requirements for external carbon. The combination of pre-DN, N and post-DN filters is much more advisable for most municipal wastewaters, because the recycle rate can be reduced and external carbon can be saved. For minimum use of external carbon, 100-150% recycle rate should not be exceeded. Then, approximately 50-60% of the total NO3-N can be depleted in the pre-DN stage. On average, 10 g total (t) COD/g NO3-N were required in the pre-DN stage for denitrification in the pilot and full-scale plant and 0.4-0.5 kg NO3 N/(m3 DN d) can be reached without external carbon. As only 40-70% of the COD load is eliminated in the pre-DN, the remaining COD load is removed in the nitrification stage. 1 kg COD/(m3 d) suppresses nitrification rates by approximately 0.1 kg NH4-N/(m3 d). For nitrification rates, >0.5 kg NH4N/(m3 d) at 12°C not more than 2 kg COD/(m3N d) may be eliminated in the nitrification. © IWA Publishing 2007.
Author Keywords: Biofiltration; Denitrification; Municipal wastewater treatment; Nitrification

Authors: Rous H.

Abstract: Projects which involve federal actions or funds may trigger the requirement under the Transportation Conformity Rule to perform PM10 and/or PM2.5 Hotspots analyses. Although there are currently no EPA-approved models to quantify potential impacts, the EPA has provided guidance to perform qualitative analysis based on comparing the proposed project to an existing location with monitoring data, or analyzing data to establish predictive trends. States and local agencies may provide specific guidance and tools, or promulgate more protective rules and regulations.

Authors: Roy D., Beaudoin R., Bilodeau M., Labrie D., Caron G.
Title: Impact of electronic blasting detonators on rock quarry environment, productivity and energy savings
Source title: Australasian Institute of Mining and Metallurgy Publication Series
Affiliations: DynoConsult, 2697 Sainte-Sophie Boulevard, Sainte-Sophie, QC J5J 2V3, Canada; CANMET Mining and Mineral Sciences Laboratories, Natural Resources, Canada, 555 Booth Street, Ottawa, ON K1A 0G1, Canada; CANMET Mining and Mineral Sciences Laboratories, Natural Resources, Canada, Bells Corners Complex, 1 Haanel Drive, Ottawa, ON K1A 0G1, Canada; Dyno Nobel, 2697 Sainte-Sophie Boulevard, Sainte-Sophie, QC J5J 2V3, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Roy, D., DynoConsult, 2697 Sainte-Sophie Boulevard, Sainte-Sophie, QC J5J 2V3, Canada; Beaudoin, R., DynoConsult, 2697 Sainte-Sophie Boulevard, Sainte-Sophie, QC J5J 2V3, Canada; Bilodeau, M., CANMET Mining and Mineral Sciences Laboratories, Natural Resources, Canada, 555 Booth Street, Ottawa, ON K1A 0G1, Canada; Labrie, D., CANMET Mining and Mineral Sciences Laboratories, Natural Resources, Canada, Bells Corners Complex, 1 Haanel Drive, Ottawa, ON K1A 0G1, Canada; Caron, G., Dyno Nobel, 2697 Sainte-Sophie Boulevard, Sainte-Sophie, QC J5J 2V3, Canada
Abstract: In 2005, Dyno Nobel Canada Inc, DynoConsult and CANMET-MMSL used their pool of expertise in blasting, ground control, open pit and underground mining, mineral processing, information technology and applied mineralogy to launch a research project aimed at evaluating the role of electronic detonators in the development of a sustainable energy-efficient rock reduction process. The overall objectives were to improve health and safety in a mining environment and reduce energy consumption and greenhouse gas (GHG) production in the Canadian mining industry. The study was conducted in a quarry located in Nova Scotia, Canada, with the objective of taking advantage of the higher accuracy and flexibility of electronic detonators towards improving blast efficiency and measuring its impact on productivity in a quarry environment and energy savings. Optimising the blast sequence was the first aspect to be considered before starting to look at designing bigger blasts and achieving productivity improvements, without creating additional environmental concerns, as the quarry's location was representing a challenge in itself in the surrounding community. The use of high-speed cameras (500 fps) was an improved means of analysing blast dynamics during the firing sequence. Seismic monitoring and linear superposition techniques were also applied to validate the sequences to be tested in all three specific geological areas. The combination of field measurements allowed to identify the optimal blasting sequences that would then be delivered accurately with the electronic initiation systems. The data from 12 blasts (six with electronic detonators and six with pyrotechnic detonators) carried out in three different geological formations (soft, medium and hard rock) showed that the electronic blasting technology could increase rock fragmentation by 15 to 20 per cent. A more uniform distribution of rock fragment size was also obtained. Blast improvements on downstream processes resulted in a five per cent productivity increase in rock excavation and transportation, a ten. per cent energy reduction in primary crushing and a 15 per cent increase in the primary crusher throughput. A prototype soft-sensor based on primary crusher data (eg energy consumption, throughput, feed and product size distribution) and a simplified computer process model were developed for online measurement of a rock operating work index. Furthermore, rock samples were collected and specimens were prepared in order to determine the tensile and compressive strength of the rock materials, evaluate the aggregate crashing work index and examine the development of micro and macro-fractures under binocular and scanning electron microscopy (SEM). Blast-induced rock damage was evaluated at the end of the laboratory testing program. A reduction in rock hardness by about 30 per cent was observed after blasting. However, the impact of the blasting method (eg using electronic versus pyrotechnic detonators) on the induced rock damage was either absent or not perceptible within the measurement technique accuracy and the number of samples analysed.
