Authors: Zia A., Arenstein W.
Title: An evaluation framework for Indirect Source Review (ISR) programs: Current controversies and future prospects
Source title: 100th Annual Conference and Exhibition of the Air and Waste Management Association 2007, ACE 2007
Affiliations: Department of Environmental Studies, San Jose State University, One Washington Square, San Jose, CA  95192-0115, United States; Writrac Consulting, 7182 Chantilley Court, San Jose, CA  95139, United States
Authors with affiliations: Zia, A., Department of Environmental Studies, San Jose State University, One Washington Square, San Jose, CA  95192-0115, United States; Arenstein, W., Writrac Consulting, 7182 Chantilley Court, San Jose, CA  95139, United States
Abstract: With the implementation of the San Joaquin Valley Air Pollution Control District's (SJVAPCD) Indirect Source Review (ISR) program, It brings to the forefront a topic that has been shelved for many years in California. Though required by the California Clean Act Air (CCAA), most Air Districts have done little if anything to implement controversial ISR programs, which require new land use developments to comply with emission mitigation requirements. Air Pollution Control Districts were hesitant in implementing ISRs because they did not look forward to the challenges and lawsuits that are expected from the development community. One Air District (Placer County APCD) went forward with an ISR program over 12 years ago. It was developed cooperatively with the development community and has been operating successfully for all these years. In this paper, we address two issues: First, we elaborate the lessons learned and controversial challenges faced during the development and implementation of an ISR program by Placer County APCD. Second, since the implementation of the SJAPCD's ISR program will hopefully interest many other Air Districts in adopting ISRs (once they wait to see how the lawsuits come out!), it will be very important to have a workable framework to evaluate both the implementation and emission reduction reality of ISR programs. We describe the development of a research program and protocols that can be used by all stakeholders to evaluate ISR programs and list the areas that need further research to produce real-world emission reductions from new land use developments.
Author Keywords: Air quality; Clean air act; Land use; New development; Non-attainment; NOx; Ozone; PM; Policy evaluation; Transportation
Index Keywords: Air pollution; Air quality; Emission control; Gas emissions; Land use; Laws and legislation; Ozone; Pollution; Pollution control; Pollution induced corrosion; Promethium; Quality control; Transportation; Waste management; Clean air act; New development; Non-attainment; NOx; Policy evaluation; Air pollution control

Authors: Zitney S.E.
Title: Use of CAPE-OPEN standard in US-UK collaboration on virtual plant simulation
Affiliations: Collaboratory for Process and Dynamic Systems Research, National Energy Technology Laboratory, Morgantown, WV 26507-0880, United States
Authors with affiliations: Zitney, S.E., Collaboratory for Process and Dynamic Systems Research, National Energy Technology Laboratory, Morgantown, WV 26507-0880, United States
Abstract: The DOE?s National Energy Technology Laboratory and the UK Department of Trade and Industry have completed a collaboration on virtual plant modeling and simulation technology for advanced fossil-energy power generation systems. The key objective of this collaboration has been the development of compatible, open standards-based US and UK technology for process/equipment co-simulation. A discussion on the use of CAPE-OPEN standard in the collaboration covers achieving plug-and-play model interoperability concerns; use of the steady-state unit operation interfaces to integrate process simulation with a hierarchy of equipment models; overall performance of solid oxide fuel cell auxiliary power units; concerns related equipment models in the context of plant-wide simulations; and future trends in the development of competitive power plant solutions and ultimately zero-emission technologies with significantly reduced development costs and technical risk. This is an abstract of a paper presented at the 2007 AIChE Annual Meeting (Salt Lake City, UT 11/4-9/2007).

Authors: Zsebik A.
Title: Implementation of CHP plants the best investment possibilities in Hungary
Affiliations: Department of Energy Engineering, Budapest University of Technology and Economics, Muegyetem rkp. 3, H-1111 Budapest, Hungary
Authors with affiliations: Zsebik, A., Department of Energy Engineering, Budapest University of Technology and Economics, Muegyetem rkp. 3, H-1111 Budapest, Hungary
Abstract: Cogeneration is a very important tool for saving primary energy, avoiding network losses, and reducing emissions, in particular of greenhouse gases. In addition, efficient use of energy by cogeneration can contribute positively to the security of a nation's energy supply and to the competitive situation in both the private and public sectors of the energy market. For this reason, and because of Hungary's electricity price structure, companies with large electricity and heat consumption, or with possibilities to sell electricity or heat, are considering the technical and economical benefits of implementating local combined heat and power (CHP) plants to supply energy for their technology processes. This paper Introduces the Hungarian electricity price structure, and sShows the results of a feasibility study for implementation of a CHP plant.
Index Keywords: CHP plant; Combined heat and power plants; Economical benefits; Efficient use of energy; Electricity prices; Energy markets; Energy supplies; Feasibility studies; Heat consumption; Hungarians; Hungary; Network loss; Primary energies; Public sector; Electricity; Greenhouse gases; Power generation; Investments

Authors: Zubari H.K., Kumar K.
Title: Reserves estimation and classification challenges in a mature oil field
Source title: SPE Middle East Oil and Gas Show and Conference, MEOS, Proceedings
Affiliations: SPE, Bahrain Petroleum Co., Bahrain
Authors with affiliations: Zubari, H.K., SPE, Bahrain Petroleum Co., Bahrain; Kumar, K., SPE, Bahrain Petroleum Co., Bahrain
Abstract: Estimation of hydrocarbon reserves is governed by natural, technological and economic factors. Re-estimations and reviews continue almost till the end of exploitation in many instances. Estimation of oil reserves, when a field is in its initial stages of development is a relatively easy task. The estimation will not invite critical or close scrutiny, as the oil production at that stage is far lower than the reserves calculated. However as the field matures and the cumulative oil production approaches the estimated value of reserves, the accuracy in the estimation of reserves becomes crucial and more important. Also the estimation process itself is a challenging task, in the light of uncovering geological complexities and reservoir dynamics during the development and the exploitation methods employed to produce the oil. Bahrain field, the first discovery in the Arabian Gulf region, has been on production since 1933. It is a multi-stacked field with 16 oil and 4 gas reservoirs. Most of them are carbonate reservoirs. The nature of the fluids varies from tarry oil in the Aruma formation occurring at shallow depths to dry gas in the deep Khuff zones. The geology of the field is complex with a large number of faults on the structure. The major oil zone Mauddud - an oil wet system - has been on gas injection from 1938. The gas injection has lead to the transfer of oil and gas into layers above and below through the faults. Though many reservoirs of the field have reached mature stage, there are some zones containing oil resources still unexploited due to the heterogeneities, complex nature of the fluid distribution, unfavorable rock-fluid characteristics, compartmentalization, thin oil rim overlain by gas and underlain by water, etc. This paper brings out the challenges posed by the above situations while attempting to estimate and classify oil reserves. Copyright 2007, Society of Ptroleum Engineers.
Index Keywords: Carbonates; Hydrocarbons; Petroleum reservoirs; Cumulative oil production; Fluid distribution; Gas injection; Oil fields

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Cold-ironing aims to limit emissions in harbour
Abstract: Concerns for the environment and the health of residents in port communities are expected to foster increasing use of the practice of "cold ironing", whereby vessels shut down all power plant when in port, and draw electricity from the shoreside grid. Cold ironing is emerging as a technically feasible, cost-effective way of cutting emissions in port for container ships and cruise liners, and potentially for other ship types, which also make regular calls at a given terminal or berth. The scale of the hotel load borne by a large cruise ship gives special merit to the concept, which can eliminate pollutants, e.g., particulate matter, NOx, and SOx from the ship while alongside. A new regulation envisaged by the California Air Resources Board will require vessels visiting the state's ports to reduce air pollution from auxiliary installations through the use of cleaner marine distillate fuels or equivalent emission controls, including the use of shoreside electrical power. Cold ironing is also set to become an issue for ships calling at ports elsewhere in North America, while steps to provide shore power for regular callers have been taken at various ports in Germany, Japan, and elsewhere. Although there is no global technical standard governing ship-to-shore connection points, IMO has called on the ISO to develop a formula, and it is anticipated that work could be completed in 2008 or 2009.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Newsreel: Texas expands natural gas vehicle grant program
Abstract: A program that allows cities, counties, school districts and other public entities to tap into a $5 million grant to switch fleet vehicles from diesels to natural gas is expanding, according to Jerry Patterson, Commissioner of the Texas General Land Office. The Land Office grant program will give public partners in 34 counties an incentive to switch their fleets of heavy-duty vehicles to run on natural gas. The program, funded with a Texas Emissions Reduction Plan grant through the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality, will help cover the cost of replacing diesel fleet vehicles with natural gas-powered vehicles. Various vehicles, including street sweepers, forklifts, buses and garbage trucks, will be eligible for the grants.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: AEC fall management conference tackles challenges of managing a sustainable future
Abstract: The Aluminum Extruders Council's (AEC) 2007 Management Conference, which took place September 18-20, 2007 in Chicago, gathered nearly 200 AEC member executives to discuss several compelling issues facing the industry, including the impact of the 'green movement' on extrusion business. The conference was based on the theme, 'Adjust, Advance, Achieve: Management for a sustainable Future', reflecting the industry's evolving economic, environmental, and social directions. Economist Robert Genetski presented his assessment of economic trends and their impact on the US economy. He noted the spectacular growth in Chinese aluminum extrusion production and recommended that North American aluminum extruders can combat serious competition from China through innovative means. Dick Penna, AEC Washington Counsel, offered an inside view of pending climate and energy legislation and addressed concerns regarding the impacts of such guidelines on extrusion products across several market segments.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: CO2 reduction initiatives in the cement industry
Abstract: Some of the most effective ways to taken by the global Portland cement industry to reduce or capture emissions of carbon dioxide resulting from the manufacturing of cement are discussed. Several thermal energy consumption optimization techniques can be adopted to reduce carbon dioxide generation. Optimization of the number of stages in a preheater depends on the raw material moisture content. Increasing the number of stages in a preheater will result in reduced fuel consumption and increased power consumption. Increasing from 4-stages to 5-stages reduces fuel consumption more than the saving achieved when increasing from 5-stages to 6-stages. Rotary kilns producing cement clinker are uniquely suited for using waste materials as fuels. The use of flammable waste material in cement kilns is a well established practice and is highly regulated by state environmental agencies and by the US EPA.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of implementation plans Tennessee; Approval of revisions to the Tennessee SIP and the Nashville/Davidson County Portion of the Tennessee SIP; Prevention of significant deterioration and nonattainment new source review
Abstract: EPA is approving revisions to the Tennessee State Implementation Plan (SIP) submitted by the State of Tennessee on 2/23/2006, and amended on 4/16/2007; and revisions to the Nashville/Davidson County portion of the Tennessee SIP submitted by the State of Tennessee on 5/31/2006. The SIP revisions modify the Tennessee and Nashville/Davidson County Prevention of Significant Deterioration and Nonattainment New Source Review regulations in the Tennessee SIP to address changes to the federal new source review regulations, which were promulgated by EPA on 12/31/2002, and reconsidered with minor changes on 11/7/2003. The revisions include provisions for baseline emissions calculations, an actual-to-projected-actual methodology for calculating emissions changes, options for plant-wide applicability limits, and recordkeeping and reporting requirements. This rule will be effective 10/15/2007. The list of subjects in 40 CFR Part 52 include air pollution control, CO, NO2, O3, SOx, and VOC.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Government: Jakarta to experiment with wood stoves
Abstract: The Jakarta government has started distributing free eco-friendly wood-fired stoves to households, as part of its Clean Development Mechanism pilot project. The stoves will be provided by EnerXI GmbH. The plan forms part of the city administration's strategy to participate in global efforts to minimize both greenhouse gas emissions and the consumption of subsidized kerosene. The distribution of the stoves is expected to be more efficient in reducing greenhouse gas emissions than the central government's plan to substitute the use of kerosene with LPG.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Green energy drives growth
Abstract: The port of Rotterdam in Europe is the most important dry bulk port that offers cost-effective and time-saving solutions for the transhipment, storage, processing, and distribution of every type of dry bulk cargo. With water depths of 24 as the maximum, the largest ships with maximum of 350,000dwt can anchor at the terminal. The port also offers a number of specialized terminal operators and an extensive line of added value services. The huge amount of coal in the Rotterdam port is managed at the EMO terminal located in Maasvlakte. The maximum daily unloading capacity offered at the EMO terminal amounts to approximately 175,000 tonnes of coal, managed by four shore-based cranes and two floating cranes. Addressing the concerns regarding the aspirations for a green energy environment, Rotterdam has agreed to become one of 20 cities in reducing CO2 production by 50% by 2012 and all new plants must capture CO2 for storage in old gas and oil fields.
Index Keywords: Cargo handling; Cost effectiveness; Floating cranes; Port terminals; Ports and harbors; Sustainable development; Unloading; bulk cargo; container terminal; oil field; port operation; shipping; water depth; Benelux; Eurasia; Europe; Netherlands; Rotterdam; South Holland; Western Europe; Gruidae

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Evidence of political interference / EPA air pollution decision threatens public health: science disregarded, misrepresented on particulate matter standard.
Source title: New solutions : a journal of environmental and occupational health policy : NS
Abstract: Political interference with federal agency science threatens our health, safety, and environment. The Environmental Protection Agency's recent air pollution rules on fine particulate matter (PM) are particularly egregious assaults on public health and the integrity of science in federal policy making. The Union of Concerned Scientists (UCS) has been actively monitoring and documenting cases of such interference and mobilizing scientists and citizens alike to push for reforms. Information on the PM case, and many others, are available on the UCS website (http://www.ucsusa.org).
Index Keywords: air pollution; article; economics; ethics; government; government regulation; human; legal aspect; maximum allowable concentration; particulate matter; policy; politics; science; scientific misconduct; standard; United States; Air Pollution; Government Regulation; Humans; Maximum Allowable Concentration; Particulate Matter; Politics; Public Policy; Science; Scientific Misconduct; United States; United States Environmental Protection Agency
